column1: Repairing My Tesla Model S Has Been an Utter Nightmare -- and It's Mostly Tesla's Fault;3/7/2017;"Seven months
column2: three weeks
column3: and three days.That's how long it's been since myTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) Model S was involved in an accident and Istilldon't have my car back. That's nearly eight months of rather   large monthly payments for a car that I'm unable to drive; nearly   eight months of incrementally higher costs associated with   insurance and registration for a car that's sitting in the shop;   nearly eight months of having to find and arrange alternative   transportation; nearly eight months of having to buy gas again
column4: while the gas savings had previously offset part of said large   monthly payments; nearly eight months of impatiently waiting to   get back a car that I absolutely love; nearly eight months of   regularly prodding Tesla for updates with little to no   success.My Model S
column5: shortly before the accident. Image source:     Author.makeArticleAd();You may assume that my car was involved in some sort of   catastrophic incident that required a protracted period of time   to repair. Nope. It was a run-of-the-mill accident (more details   later). Tesla is predominantly responsible for why it is taking   so long
column6: because out of those eight months
column7: over five of them   were spent doing nothing but waiting for parts.Let me back up a bit and start from the beginning.Jan. 27
column8: 2016: Delivery dayIn late 2015
column9: my wife and I decided to take the plunge and buy   a Model S. We had been longtime supporters and investors in the   company
column10: firstbuying shares in 2011. We finally pulled the trigger in December of that year. In   order to save quite a bit of money
column11: we opted for a certified   pre-owned (CPO) model
column12: which cost about a third less than a   comparably equipped new Model S would have cost at the time.At the time
column13: the Colorado state tax credit ($6
column14: 000) for   electric vehicles could be claimed on used vehicles provided that   the car has never been registered in the state. (The state credit   was recently amended to exclude used vehicles
column15: effective starting   2017.) So we found one that was located in New Jersey
column16: and even   after paying the maximum transportation fee ($1
column18: it still   easily worked out in our favor. It was less than 2 years old and   had less than 20
column19: 000 miles on it; not bad for what we saved by   going CPO. It was even the exact same shade of dark green as my   first car
column20: a color option that had since been discontinued --   bonus nostalgia points.Delivery day at the Tesla service center. Image source:     Author.It took about a month for the car to arrive
column21: but we   immediately fell in love with it. We started taking road trips   more often (within the bounds of the Supercharger network
column22: of   course)
column23: and frequently found excuses just to drive and enjoy the   instant torque.Like most Tesla customers
column24: we became involuntary but not   unwilling advocates for the company
column25: fielding a constant string   of questions from friends
column26: family
column27: and strangers regarding how   the car worked as well as about the necessary behavioral   adjustments associated with going all-electric. We also attracted   the typical confounded stares when we'd put something in the   frunk
column28: or put the kids in the rear-facing seats that we had Tesla   retrofit post-delivery.A couple months after taking delivery
column29: we placed a reservation   for a Model 3 on March 31
column30: the day that Tesla unveiled the   vehicle and started taking deposits.July 11
column31: 2016: Accident dayI was actually at the Tesla factory in Fremont
column32: California
column33: when the accident occurred (I worked for Tesla very briefly   during the summer of 2016). My wife called me frantically
column34: exasperated that she had been involved in an accident. Most   importantly
column35: she was largely unharmed; just some minor whiplash   that she quickly recovered from. She was more concerned that the   car had been injured. She had been driving home from work
column36: sitting stationary at a stop light
column37: when a young driver failed to   hit the brakes in time and rear-ended the vehicle at a relatively   low speed.Here's the picture I asked her to take of the car immediately   after the impact:Immediately after the accident. Image source: Author.It looks worse than it was
column38: in part because the Model S and   Model X contain more aluminum than most vehicles. Aluminum   crumples much easier than steel since it's a softer metal. This   is also an important safety feature since the crumple zones are   both larger and able to absorb more impact
column39: with the downside   being that aluminum is more expensive. A consequence is that   Tesla accidents look really bad because the vehicles get mangled
column40: but the functional benefit is minimal intrusion into the   passenger cabin.Less than six months after we had taken delivery
column41: our Model S   was off to the shop.Nearly eight months later...While Tesla performs most routine service itself
column42: it   outsources major body work to a network of third-party body shops   that are certified by Tesla. The certification process is   expensive and time-consuming
column43: but certified body shops will   garner most of the local business (there is only one certified   body shop in my immediate area).Shortly after receiving my damaged car
column44: the body shop started   tearing down the vehicle to assess the damage
column45: and ordering the   parts that would be necessary for the repair. The vast majority   of the repair time has been gobbled up here. I had heard and read   stories about Tesla parts taking longer to deliver relative to   the rest of the industry
column46: but that's somewhat expected for a   young car company with just one factory.Anecdotally
column47: stories of it taking two to three months for Tesla to deliver   parts are not uncommon. After three months had passed and the   body shop had still not received all the necessary parts
column48: we   began reaching out to Tesla directly through their customer   service channels
column49: which serves as a liaison to the internal parts   department.At the body shop. Image source: Author.Initially
column50: no customer service representative that we   interacted with was willing to take ownership of our issue. We   kept getting passed between representatives with little to no   useful information (a customer service manager eventually took   ownership of handling our issue after repeated escalations).   Parts had started to trickle in
column51: but there still weren't enough   to start the repair so our car continued to sit idly. Two of the   more pertinent parts were a rear lift gate and rear quarter   panel
column52: which were still outstanding. During one of the   escalations in November (four months after the accident)
column53: Tesla guaranteed us that all parts would arrive at the body   shop no later than the last week of November. They didn't.In mid-December
column54: the shopfinallyreceived enough (but not all) parts to start working on the car.   At that point
column55: the holidays were nearly upon us
column56: and every   industry slows down around that time of year. The body shop would   begin the repair in early January 2017 after the holidays. There   were still a few outstanding parts
column57: including bulb rivets. I   would think that something as basic as rivets would be among the   easier parts to deliver
column58: but evidently I'm wrong (and not alone). We again contacted customer service
column59: and Tesla again assured   us they had just shipped the remaining parts for overnight   delivery. Frankly
column60: we didn't have much faith at this point
column61: as we   had been told this before. But in the final week of January
column62: the   shop confirmed that they had indeed received all remaining parts   necessary to complete the repair. It looked like light at the end   of the tunnel
column63: six months in. At this point in the story
column64: the car   has spentmore time in the shop than in our possession.A couple weeks ago
column65: the body shop updated us that the car was   about to enter the paint shop
column66: at which point it should only be a   couple more weeks to reassemble the painted pieces and then   perform electronics calibrations and a few other outstanding   items. It turns out that the 12V battery is also now in need of   replacement
column67: as it will no longer hold a charge (perhaps related   to how long the car has been sitting idle?). The shop ordered the   battery a week and a half ago. Tesla uses exactly one specific   supplier for its 12V batteries
column68: which is struggling to keep up   with Tesla's demands. We're now looking at yet another delay for   the 12V battery
column69: which is a part that most people are able to   purchase for their vehicles locally within 15 minutes.As soon as Tesla delivers this battery
column70: the car will be ready   within a day or two. It's supposed to be ready this week
column71: but at   this point I have incredibly low expectations
column72: as we are again   waiting on Tesla to deliver.Look
column73: Ma: No car!Tesla is known for having a generous loaner policy when   vehicles are being serviced
column74: but sadly this policy does not apply   to body work.The driver that hit us was uninsured
column75: so we had to file our   claims through our collision coverage
column76: and we have coverage for a   rental. But our rental coverage maxes out at 45 days
column77: which is   typically sufficient time for most body repairs. Having already   known that our repair would probably take at least two months
column78: I   knew we would need to arrange alternative transportation. Even if   we opted to use our insurance company's negotiated rental rates
column80: 000 per month to rent a car.   That'sin additionto the monthly loan payments that we are still paying.Fortunately
column82: and as such have little   need for their cars. My mother graciously agreed to let me borrow   her car as long as needed
column83: which relieved us of having to bleed   out a small fortune ($7
column84: 000 by now) in rental fees for an   indefinite and still ongoing period of time.What this means for investorsTo say that this whole experience has been traumatizing would   be an understatement. As long-standing investors and   newfound customers
column85: it has profoundly shaken our faith in Tesla   as a company. Thus far
column86: Tesla has not given us a reason as towhyour parts were so severely delayed
column87: so we have no indication as   to whether or not this is a one-off exception or if there is some   systemic problem within Tesla's parts operations. While we've   been waiting
column88: Tesla has delivered tens of thousands of vehicles
column90: 000 Model S sedans.Some of Tesla's weakness here is certainly related to its own   ability to produce parts
column91: which continues to improve every month.   Theoretically
column92: parts production should improve as Tesla continues   to ramp its overall manufacturing capacity
column93: but it seems like   this can't be the only reason. I'm mildly confident that my case   is an outlier
column95: it's still disconcerting that   situations like this can slip through the cracks after repeated   escalations and assurances.It also calls into question Tesla's ability to support its   existing customer base
column96: which is of critical relevance to whether   or not Tesla can support amassivelylarger customer base. The company is still targeting 500
column97: 000   units in 2018. As many analysts and pundits point out
column98: the   mainstream is far less forgiving for this sort of thing compared   to enthusiastic early adopters.We are now questioning our Model 3 reservation. We haven't   finalized our decision
column99: nor will we have to for a few more   months. Owning two Teslas now seems like a significant risk   should one of them ever be involved in any type of accident
column100: small or large. In sharing our story with other Model 3   reservation holders

column1: Amazon (AMZN) CEO Jeff Bezos Wants to Dominate Outer Space;3/7/2017;"The Milky Way (Shutterstock Photo)Is there any place in the universe too big for Jeff Bezos to want to conquer?After crushing the world of retail
column2: technology
column3: shipping logistics
column4: and a host of current projects poised to disrupt or create new markets
column5: why wouldn’t Bezos think he could dominate outer space? The Amazon (AMZN) CEO
column6: who currently ranks at the world's third-wealthiest person
column7: has pioneered space launch company
column8: Blue Origin
column9: which is expected to reveal some customers and new initiatives this week.makeArticleAd();With what began as just an interesting idea
column10: Bezos
column11: a self-proclaimed ""space geek
column12: ” has already established tons of credibility for Blue Origin
column13: which offers a family of reusable rockets powerful enough to penetrate deep into the solar system for suborbital voyages. Bezos envisions one day humans establishing a permanent settlement on the moon. It’s more than just a pipe dream. And given his Midas track record
column14: Bezos’ space exploration plans should be taken seriously.The capabilities of Blue Origin
column15: which has grown over the past year
column16: can now blast both manned and robotic missions not only to the moon
column17: but also to various planets. Flight safety tests are ongoing on the company’s New Shepard suborbital rocket
column18: which Blue Origin built in-house and reportedly can take paying passengers into outer space some time next year.Blue Origin rivals the powerful rockets currently being touted by Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk's SpaceX. While Musk appears to have a sizable lead on Bezos
column19: given that SpaceX already has several rockets under development
column20: Blue Origin has already caught the attention of NASA
column21: which is already working on its own version of a deep-space booster and capsule
column22: according toThe Wall Street Journal.What’s more

column26: as the world’s third-richest person with almost $70B in net worth
column27: Bezos can buy time to perfect Blue Origin. This race for outer space suggests that space is indeed the new frontier. Whether it’s the final frontier
column28: as Star Trek claims? That remains to be seen."

column2: Inc. (AMZN);3/6/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) sold off hard following a fourth-quarter earnings report that fell short of the market's lofty expectations. Despite reporting better-than-expected revenue of $2.28 billion on the quarter
column4: Tesla stock delivered an earnings loss much larger that the market anticipated.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAs Tesla stock was already up more than 26% year-to-date headed into earnings
column5: it's not surprising that the stock sold off.I've written many times about the dangers of investing in Tesla stock at its current market valuation.Tesla's 2017 run pushed the stock's market cap to around $45 billion
column6: roughly in line with that ofFord Motor Company(NYSE:F). It's difficult to fathom such a high valuation for a company that shipped just 76
column7: 000 vehicles last year and burned through another $448 million in cash in Q4.The market may have higher hopes for Tesla stock than any other stock on the market. But long-term TSLA bulls don't care about Q4

They believe Tesla Inc. will change the world.The Tesla Stock Bull Case Is About QualityTesla stock bulls believe that it doesn't matter how many cars the company delivers in the short term. They feel the autonomous driving technology that CEO Elon Musk is developing will make Tesla vehicles the best in the world in the next decade.General Motors Company(NYSE:GM) has gotten a head-start on the long-range electric vehicle mass market. But TSLA appears to be on track to be the first to market with a fully-autonomous vehicle.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowLast year

column13: its data advantage will quickly compound exponentially. column1: Why Utilities and Solar Companies May Be Finding Common Ground;3/6/2017;"As the solar industry becomes more competitive
column2: both within   the industry and with fossil fuels
column3: companies are having to   figure out where they most efficiently fit into the market. For a   while
column4: solar companies thought they may have an advantage in   developing and owning solar projects
column5: leading to the structure of   many of the companies you know today.First Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column6: SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column7: andCanadian Solar(NASDAQ: CSIQ) all bought development companies to build large   projects
column8: andTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) SolarCity was always a solar developer that   owned the systems it built. And all of these companies either   planned to own solar systems long term or drop them down to   yieldcos.As this was happening
column9: utilities across the country began to   develop their own renewable energy strategies. The beginning was   buying renewable energy projects from developers
column10: including the   solar companies mentioned above. But with more experience
column11: they've moved more and more into solar project development   themselves
column12: cutting out the middleman.As the solar industry and utility industry begin to collide
column13: each has to figure out where they fit in the new world of energy.   And we may be seeing some hints about where the industry will   land in the long term.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Utilities learn their renewable energy roleAs utilities have entered the solar market
column14: they've found that   that there are places where they hold an advantage over solar   companies. They may not ever manufacture solar panels or create a   great racking system
column15: but they have a lower cost of capital than   solar companies. When the yieldco yields rose and made it   difficult for solar companies to drop downs assets to an entity   they controlled
column16: utilities had an opening because they still had   a low cost of capital.What also makes sense is that utilities will move from buying   completed solar projects to developing them in-house.NextEra Energy
column17: NRG Energy
column18: andDuke Energyhave all developed renewable energy development arms that do more   than just buy projects.To that end
column19: AES(NYSE: AES) bought solar developersPowerfor $1.58 billion late last month. AES has been a leader in   developing energy storage solutions around the country
column20: and now   it's a leader in solar as well.What about solar companies?While utilities are moving more into development
column21: there's   still a big role for solar companies to play. They may not be   doing financing and site selection
column22: but they'll be making panels
column23: designing tracking solutions
column24: and making integrated solutions   that utility developers will use.If you look at the strategy changes at First Solar and   SunPower over the past year
column25: they fit into this new energy world   perfectly. They've moved from project development to supplying   solutions
column26: such as Oasis from SunPower and the Series 6 product   from First Solar. They're expanding their offerings beyond solar   panels into racking
column27: site design
column28: and inverters
column29: but they may not   be moving as far into the industry as owning projects long   term.Even Tesla is selling most of its energy storage solutions to   utilities or other third-party developers rather than storing   them on the balance sheet.Sticking to what you do bestThere will continue to be tension between utilities and the   solar companies upending their business
column30: but the tension may not   be focused on the utility side in the future. It makes sense for   utilities to stick to project ownership and some development   work
column31: while solar companies offer plug-and-play solutions where   developers need energy. This may lead to a more stable solar   industry long term
column32: and it will make it less risky for investors

column1: How Apple Could Spend Its Cash Hoard;3/6/2017;"The problem ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) cash balance is a ""first-world problem"" in   the most literal sense of the phrase.Slightly larger than the annual economic output of Chile
column2: Apple's cash and marketable securities stockpile lies largely   overseas. As of the company's most recent earnings report
column3: $230   billion of Apple's $246 billion
column4: roughly 93%
column5: was held in   accounts controlled by Apple's international subsidiaries.Apple has caused quite a stir thanks to its controversial   decision to park its foreign profits abroad rather than pay what   it argues are onerous and unfair repatriation taxes. However
column6: the   whiff of tax policy overhaul percolating on Capitol Hill means   this dynamic could soon change. In anticipation of such a   scenario -- and in part because it's just fun to consider -- here   are three realistic ways Apple could deploy its billions in the   bank in the years ahead.makeArticleAd();Image source: Apple.Idea 1: Major acquisitionApple being a mature company
column7: you often see investors float   the idea of the Mac maker using its cash to fund a major   acquisition whenever this discussion appears. The idea isn't   without merit
column8: either
column9: although it is more complex than it might   seem on the surface for a few reasons.The first hurdle lies in correctly identifying a large company   that jives with Apple's plans for its own future. In terms of   companies that I (subjectively) think could conceivably pair well   with Apple
column10: only a handful of plausible candidates come to mind.   Among them areTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column11: Netflix(NASDAQ: NFLX)
column12: andComcast(NASDAQ: CMCSA) (NASDAQ: CMCSK)
column13: three legitimately viable   options among publicly traded companies.We know Apple is interested in -- or possibly in the midst of   --developing an electric vehiclefrom the many leaks about its Project Titan
column14: though we don't know   much more than that. Tesla makes the most sense among automakers   for a few reasons. Much like Apple
column15: Tesla's mission is to   fundamentally alter the industries in which it operates. Its   headquarters in California would make working together simpler   than coordinating across the country with Detroit.In a similar vein
column16: Comcast and Netflix both cater to Apple's   long-held desire to launch its own content streaming service.   Apple's ability to secure content rights from major producers has   been the main thorn in its side. Both Netflix and Comcast control   considerable content rights
column17: though Netflix is newer to this   game. As such
column18: owning either Comcast or Netflix could supply   Apple with the negotiating leverage it needs to finally bring the   required parties to the table.Unfortunately
column19: acquiring any of these companies would require   Apple pay a significant premium to their current prices
column20: which   could be particularly troubling for already-expensive stocks like   Netflix and Tesla. There are also integration
column21: cultural
column22: and   regulatory considerations that could make such a maneuver highly   complex for Apple
column23: though the idea isn't entirely without   merit.Idea 2: More capital return?This comes from the ""if it ain't broke
column24: don't fix it"" school   of thought since Apple has thus far used its cash reserves to   finance its dividends and share buybacks. To do so
column25: Apple has   cleverly used its overseas riches as collateral to borrow against   to fund its massive capital return programto great effect.Apple has paid out a whopping $201 billion of its current $250   billion capital return program as of its most recent earnings   report
column26: including $15 billion in dividends and buybacks in its   latest quarter (Q1 FY 2017). Apple generated $27 billion in   operating cash flow last year
column27: and its capex requirements are   minimal -- $3 billion last quarter. This makes the status quo   seem sustainable
column28: although the recent rally inApple stockmakes this option increasingly less appealing.AAPL PE Ratio (TTM)data byYCharts.Stock buybacks become less effective as a company'svaluation increases
column29: so Apple's dramatic multiple expansion has made this tactic   less attractive than it was a year ago. However
column30: with Apple still   trading at a discount to the market
column31: and its cash balance rising
column32: there's certainly a fair case to be made that further buybacks   and dividends remain a worthy use of Apple's riches.Idea 3: Finance important capex?If Project Titan is indeed real
column33: I think the chances of Apple   implementing this third idea are quite strong. One of the most   important questions Apple must answer along the way is how will   it manufacture the electric vehicle?As I havenotedin the past
column34: automobile manufacturing is a capital-intensive
column35: low-margin business. This leaves Apple facing a potential   catch-22 with Project Titan
column36: driving meaningful sales growth   while also dramatically eroding its now-cushy profit margins in   the process.Perhaps the best solution to this problem is to follow a   tactic similar to Apple's contract manufacturing arrangements   with Asian assembly specialistsFoxconn. Apple designs products and maintains quality control
column37: but it   hands over the actual widget-making
column38: the low-margin part of the   process
column39: to someone else. This is how the majority of Apple's   consumer electronics get made today.The key speed bump with this idea is that there are no   large-scale automotive contract manufacturers that exist today to   provide this service to Apple
column40: and that's where Apple's mountains   of money come into play. Assuming it finds a willing and capable   partner to build Project Titan
column41: Apple could use its cash to   finance the construction of the factory infrastructure necessary   to bring Project Titan to life.In fact
column42: Apple has pursued a similar strategy in the past. It   partnered with the now-defunct GT Advanced Technologies to   finance the construction of a factory that GT Advanced planned to   use to produce commercial sapphire for Apple's fingerprint   scanners. If it does so
column43: Apple will want to take great care to   avoid past mistakes
column44: like bankrupting GT Advanced under the   onerous terms of its financing deal. Regardless
column45: this idea is   sound as long as Apple's auto ambitions are indeed as real as   portrayed in the media.Cash is kingOf course
column46: this only scratches the surface in terms of   possible uses of Apple's cash. U.S. tax policy overhaul will also   have a significant influence on Apple's options
column47: so interested   investors will want to stay in tune with the national discussion   around it in the coming months. At the end of the day
column48: though
column49: Apple's billions in the bank provide it with unparalleled   flexibility to pursue any number of possible actions
column50: and that's   something in which Apple investors can and should find great   comfort.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column6: and let them drive farther
column7: at half the   price of car batteries today?Or perhaps you caughtNOVA'sFeb. 1 episode
column8: which offered a slightly different take on   America's ""search for the super battery"" that will power our   smartphones
column9: our laptops
column10: and even our cars in the future?If so
column11: you may have noticed: All of a sudden
column12: battery science is cool.Building a better TeslaIf you've been following the story of Elon Musk and the   Gigafactory thatTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is building in the Nevada desert
column13: you may be under   the impression that Musk's ""18650"" lithium-ion batteries are   currently the height of battery technology. Well
column14: they are and   they aren't.Lithium-ion batteries were first commercialized bySony(NYSE: SNE) back in 1991. And
column15: yes
column16: if you pack enough of them   onto a car chassis
column17: you can make a Tesla drive 200
column19: or even   300 miles on a single charge
column20: and yes
column21: that's a greater range   than most other electric cars offer today. But even the 18650s   that the high-tech Gigafactory will churn out employ the same   basic lithium nickel-cobalt-aluminum chemistry that's been in use   for more than a decade.Employing a liquid electrolyte to shuttle lithium ions between   anode and cathode
column22: 18650 batteries still carry at least a (small)   risk of incurring a catastrophic meltdown
column23: such as the incidents   thatsunk Samsung stocklast year. And relying on a limited volume of lithium ions (about   2% of the battery's volume)
column24: intercalated within a graphite   anode
column25: 18650s still provide less power than you could get from a   pure lithium metal anode -- the aforementioned ""holy grail.""Luckily for electric-car enthusiasts and ""green power""   afficionados
column26: there's a better battery on the way.Introducing Ionic MaterialsIt's called the solid polymer lithium metal battery
column27: and it   was invented in 2011 by Tufts professor and former Bell Labs   researcher Mike Zimmerman
column28: who's now working to   commercialize the prototype for mass production through his new   company
column29: Ionic Materials.Instead of a liquid electrolyte
column30: Ionic uses a solid polymer (a   plasticlike material) to allow lithium ions to flow from anode to   cathode and back again. According to Ionic
column31: this novel type of   electrolyte::offers the ability to function as the cathode     electrolyteexhibits high conductivity at room temperaturehas high voltage stabilityis non-flammableis conducive to high-volume manufacturing techniques.Ionic also uses a lithium metal battery
column32: so there are more   lithium ions to move. That means Ionic's battery packs a   whole lot more punch than the lithium-ion batteries in use today.   Oh
column33: and because it's basically a piece of plastic
column34: it's almost   infinitely malleable and can be manufactured in form factors   conducive to different uses -- long
column35: wide
column36: and flat for powering   tablets or cylindrical to power flashlights. Why
column37: it could even   be molded to fit where needed within a car chassis.As a bonus
column38: it's worlds away from today's lithium-ion   batteries in terms of safety. On last month'sNOVAepisode
column39: host David Pogue attacked Ionic's battery with a   vengeance
column40: piercing it with a screwdriver and snipping off bits   with scissors. Not only did the solid polymer lithium metal   battery not explode (as any other lithium-ion battery would   have)
column41: it actually kept working
column42: powering an iPad even as it was   hacked to pieces.When will it arrive?No
column43: you cannot buy one
column44: at least not right away.Ionic Materials was recently awarded a $3 million Advanced   Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E) grant from the   Department of Energy. Funding will begin early this year
column45: which   will help to get the ball rolling
column46: but Ionic's battery is not yet   available commercially.The company is ""actively discussing potential partnerships   with leading multi-national materials companies
column47: battery   manufacturers and device OEMs."" But Ionic has released no details   on its potential partnerships as of yet -- meaning we don't yet   knowhow   to investin the technology.That said
column48: Ionic Materials says it expects to find a partner   and begin manufacturing its polymer super-battery as early as   next year. So stay tuned.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

Its smart wearables like the Blaze weren't enough to fend off the Apple Watch.The U.S. market (where its marketing is focused) is approaching saturation for basic fitness trackers. column19: for Q4 Apple Watch sales were up 13% (to 4.6 million units for the quarter) and Xiaomi was up 96.2% (5.2 million units). Fitbit maintained its first-place position
column20: but sold just 6.5 million units
column21: a 22.7% drop compared to last year.Q4 Smartwatch Sales Show AAPL's Fitness Focus Paying OffThe IDC numbers vindicate Apple CEO Tim Cook's comments in December. Speaking in response to a a report (from IDC
column22: ironically) that suggested the smartwatch category was in trouble and the Apple Watch would face ""muted"" success
column23: Cook responded:""Our data shows that Apple Watch is doing great and looks to be one of the most popular holiday gifts this year. Sales growth is off the charts. In fact
column24: during the first week of holiday shopping
column25: our sell-through of Apple Watch was greater than any week in the product's history. And as we expected
column26: we're on track for the best quarter ever for Apple Watch.""That comment was looked at with some suspicion at the time. It seemed a little defensive and vague.Is the Reversal in Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock a Buying Opportunity?The Apple Watch series 2
column27: launched in September
column28: featured a renewed focus on fitness and activity
column29: including a built-in GPS that freed it from the smartwatch for running. A partnership withNike Inc(NYSE:NKE) resulted in theApple Watch Nike+aimed offered sports enthusiasts.At the same time
column30: Apple tweaked the performance of the Apple Watch and has continually improved its watchOS operating system.With record Q4 Apple Watch sales that exceeded the numbers from its launch year -when excitement about the all new smartwatch was running high- AAPL's strategy is clearly paying off. And contrary to that earlier IDC report from last year
column31: the Apple Watch is enjoying better than ""muted"" success.As of this writing

column1: Buying Snap Today Could Be Like Buying Apple 35 Years Ago;3/3/2017;"Snapchat (Shutterstock photo)Many on Wall Street are comparing Snap Inc. (SNAP) to Facebook (FB) or Twitter (TWTR) and for now
column2: that's okay. All three can be considered social networks
column3: rely on daily active users and generate the majority of their revenue from advertising.In the future
column4: however
column5: Snap may wind up being more like another Silicon Valley giant than the aforementioned ones -- Apple (AAPL).makeArticleAd();Buying stock in Snap today is a bet on CEO Evan Spiegel more than it is on the company's prowess as an advertising behemoth. Spiegel
column7: is a product visionary the world has not seen seen Apple's Steve Jobs and to some extent
column8: Tesla Inc. (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk.There are similarities between Jobs and Spiegel
column9: both starting their companies after dropping out of college
column10: are wonderful salesmen and marketers
column11: but the similarities go further than that.Jobs is Spiegel's idol; he has a portrait of the legendary Apple co-founder hanging in his office. When unveiling Spectacles toThe Wall Street Journalthis past fall
column12: he even used Jobs-ian language
column13: saying ""You wanna see it?"" as he took off the towel covering the product. This mentality plays to the culture of secrecy at both companies
column14: not releasing products until they are ready to be talked about.And unlike other technology companies
column15: neither Snap or Apple have ""beta"" products. There is no group of early adopters buying and using a product so the companies can get an idea of how users are interacting with it and then continue to refine. Every meticulous detail is thought out and obsessed over and is not released until it's perfect.Aegis Capital analyst Victor Anthony said the company's most valuable asset is its demographic
column16: with 13-24 year olds comprising nearly 60% of its user base. While these are highly coveted by advertisers such as Procter & Gamble
column17: Clorox and others
column18: Spiegel is the company's most valuable asset. The ability to know what people want before they want or see it is an invaluable trait that very few executives have. It can not be measured or valued
column19: but it's something that investors need to keenly aware of when looking at where to put their investing dollars.Snap has positioned and sold itself as a camera company
column20: having mentioned that multiple times in its S-1. This can allow them to expand into everything and anything that has a camera.Despite the optimism surrounding Spiegel
column21: the stickiness of Snapchat (engagement levels are shockingly high) and the coveted user base
column22: it's not all roses for Snap at this stage.There are concerns about the company's financial picture
column23: as it still generates the majority of its revenue from advertising. Going up against Facebook and Google
column24: which have mountains of user data that advertisers love
column25: can be a daunting task (just ask Twitter).Issues surrounding slowing user growth
column26: the ability for competitors to copy product features
column27: lack of data analytics
column28: no voting control with Class A shares are all valid reasons to be wary of Snap
column29: especially at a $35 billion valuation.But again
column30: it comes down to be at the forefront of an area that's only going to expand with a product visionary for a CEO.Images
column31: whether it's augmented reality
column32: virtual reality
column33: moving or static
column34: are humanity's future. All you have to do is just look at the popularity of Instagram to see why. Snap
column35: with Snapchat
column36: its burgeoning hardware portfolio and most importantly Spiegel
column37: is poised to be at the forefront of this trend for many years to come."

column1: Tesla's Guidance for Model S and X Deliveries: What Investors Should Know;3/2/2017;"InTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) fourth-quarter shareholder letter
column2: management   understandably refrained from providing guidance beyond the first   half of 2017. Given that the second half of the year is expected   to include the unpredictable production ramp of Tesla's upcoming   higher-volume Model 3
column3: guidance for such an uncertain outcome   could do more harm than good for investors.But what's interesting about the guidance for vehicle   deliveries Tesla did provide is that it's not nearly as ambitious   as it looks at first glance.Model S (left) and Model X (right). Image source:     Author.makeArticleAd();Understanding Tesla's guidanceFor its expectations for deliveries before Model 3 debuts   during the second half of the year
column4: Tesla said it expects to   ""deliver 47
column6: 000 Model S and Model X vehicles combined   in the first half of 2017
column7: representing vehicle delivery growth   of 61% to 71% compared with the same period last year.""This is some big growth
column8: right? It depends on how you look at   it. On a year-over-year basis
column9: this growth is an acceleration   from the 27% year-over-year growth Tesla posted in its fourth   quarter. But when investors zoom out and look at what this means   for the trajectory of Tesla's combined Model S and X units on a   sequential basis
column10: Tesla isn't expecting much growth at all.   Compared to combined Model S and X deliveries in the second half   of 2016
column13: 000 deliveries in the first half of 2017   would be up just 0% to 6%.And assuming Tesla's late 2015-introduced Model X continues to   account for a larger percentage of the electric-car maker's sales   over the next few quarters as the company ramps up production of   the newer vehicle
column14: this guidance may mean management expects its   Model S sales to decline. In fact
column15: Model S sales have already   turned downward. In Tesla's fourth quarter of 2016
column16: Model S sales   were down 21% sequentially and 26% year over year.Still a successOf course
column17: if Tesla's combined Model S and X deliveries do   level off at the 100
column18: 000-unit run rate they're at today
column19: this   would still be an impressive volume for two luxury models priced   between $68
column21: 000. Indeed
column22: Model S is already the   best-selling large luxury sedan in this price range in the U.S.   by a long shot. And Tesla's Model X SUV already accounts for   about 6% of U.S. large luxury SUV sales.Furthermore
column23: based on Tesla's update on demand for Model S and   X in the company's fourth-quarter shareholder letter
column24: a   meaningful decline in combined Model S and X sales in the coming   quarters looks highly unlikely.""Model S and X net order growth remains strong
column25: as we are   continually evolving our products by elevating performance
column26: convenience
column27: and safety
column28: management explained. Tesla also said   Model S and X orders hit a record high during the quarter and   were up 49% year over year.Finally
column29: it's worth noting that abrupt pauses in Tesla's   sequential growth have occurred in the past on several occasions.   Indeed
column31: combined Model S and X deliveries declined 15%   and 3% sequentially in Q1 and Q2
column32: respectively
column33: before they   skyrocketed 72% sequentially in Q3.Model X. Image source: Author.It's fair to say
column34: therefore
column35: that year-over-year growth has   proved to be the best way for investors to see the bigger picture   when it comes to Tesla's ability to grow sales. And despite   Tesla's expectations for flat sales going into the first half of   2017 compared to the second half of 2016
column36: it would likely serve   investors well to still take a moment to acknowledge just how   sharp Tesla's year-over-year growth remains.Sure
column37: this doesn't mean Tesla can continue growing Model S and   Model X sales sharply or even at all. But Tesla's continued   ability to increase sales at 50%-plus rates annually since Model   S was first launched demonstrates Tesla's consistent execution on   its growth plans on a year-over-year basis
column38: and it bodes well for   the company's ambitious growth outlook for Model 3.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip

column1: Best Buy Inc Co (BBY) Stock Dives Into the Retail Dumpster;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBest Buy(NYSE:BBY) announced slightly lower same-store sales during the holiday season
column3: and investors dumped BBY stock in a hurry.makeArticleAd();Source:Austin Kirk via FlickrThe drop was minor
column4: less than 1%. But it was unexpected
column5: and missed analyst estimates of a top-line gain of 0.5%.For the quarter
column6: Best Buy reported earnings of $607 million ($1.91 per share) on revenue of $13.48 billion. This compared with earnings of just $479 million ($1.40) but revenue of $13.62 billion a year earlier. More importantly
column7: while adjusted profits of $1.95 per share easily beat estimates of $1.67
column8: revenues fell short of analysts' expectations
column9: also for $13.62 billion.The revenue shortfall meant analysts threw Best Buy stock into the dumpster with retailers such asMacy's Inc.(NYSE:M)
column10: with shares down almost 5% early Wednesday
column11: to $42.40. During the Christmas season
column12: on Dec. 8
column13: the shares traded as high as $49.31.Were the analysts right
column14: or did they just offer smart investors a bargain? IsAmazon.com
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) about to kill all retailers
column16: or is this just a case of Moore's Law in action?Great Expectations for Best BuyBest Buy even trounced the higher earnings whisper number of $1.66 per share. But actual estimateswere all over the map
column17: with some very bearish about the company's ability to cut costs and others bullish on margins.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017The Zacks Metric Model noted that BBY stock had beaten estimates for four quarters
column18: and that shareholders had been rewarded with a 36% gain. In particular
column19: Best Buy was posting big gains in online sales - the so-called ""omni-channel"" approach - and Zacks was expecting an upside surprise.On the bottom line
column20: of course
column21: Best Buy delivered one. And considering the sizable beat
column22: BBY shares should've rocketed higher.But something else is at play … and that something is Moore's Law.Moore's Law Hits the Top LineMoore's Law
column23: which turned 50 in 2015
column24: was described byIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) co-founder Gordon Moore as an expected increase in circuit density on silicon
column25: doubling every 18 months ago as far as he could see
column26: in 1966.But
column27: as I have been writing for many years now
column28: Moore's Law alsoturned traditional economics on its head. Moore's Law is deflationary
column29: and the deflationary impact grows with time
column30: as integrated circuits are incorporated into more and more things
column31: and as the impact is compounded by its use in various ways.In the case of Best Buy
column32: this means the products it sells lose value as soon as they leave the factory
column33: and the retailer is under enormous pressure to get them out the door before their value disappears. This isn't new
column34: but in 2016 it hit one of the company's primary growth sectors: big-screen TVs.A TV that would have been unaffordable just a few years ago - 5 feet wide on the diagonal - is now available at Best Buy forjust $600. More important
column35: flat-screen sets just don't break. I still have one from 2001.Could Amazon.com
column36: Inc. (AMZN) Take a Hint From Best Buy Co Inc (BBY)?Best Buy still makes money on that 60-inch set
column37: but the price point is lower
column38: and this is true for all consumer electronics. Whole categories that used to represent big profits
column39: like back-up drives
column40: DVD players and packaged software
column41: have disappeared as consumers find they can get and save files to cloud services.Bottom Line on BBY StockThe new administration wants to whip deflation now and
column42: by allowing price hikes on oil and other resources
column43: they could achieve the goal. China
column44: too
column45: seems dedicated to fighting deflation
column46: giving raises to many workers in a more competitive market.This should mean good news for Best Buy
column47: which is focusing more on products like ovens and washing machines that have mechanical parts which sometimes break. A new round of high-end phones should also help the top line.Bottom line? At a price-to-earnings multiple of under 14
column48: and a dividend yielding 2.5% (that the company is in a great position to raise)
column49: BBY stock might be Best Buy's best bargain.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. His latest novel isBridget O'Flynn vs. Something Big & Ugly.Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing

column1: Could Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Take a Hint From Best Buy Co Inc (BBY)?;3/1/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) buysMacy's Inc(NYSE:M). It's a crazy idea
column5: right? AMZN stock has barely budged over the past couple of weeks sincereportssurfaced that Canada'sHudson's Bay Co(OTCMKTS:HBAYF) was in talks to buy America's largest seller of apparel. Clearly
column6: investors aren't holding their breath.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe media
column7: on the other hand
column8: has been busy speculating on the odds of a company like Amazon getting into a bidding war with the iconic Canadian retailer that is run by an American and also ownsSaks IncandLord & Taylor.Opinions vary on whether Amazon boss Jeff Bezos would make such a move
column9: but let me assure you
column10: it won't be for the real estate.No
column11: if AMZN does make a play for Macy's it will be for other
column12: more-sensible business reasons. In fact
column13: you could say Amazon would be taking a page out of the playbook ofBest Buy Co Inc(NYSE:BBY)
column14: one of Amazon's biggest rivals in electronics retail.How's that
column15: you say? Let me explain.AMZN Apparel Market ShareIn case you missed it
column16: Amazon has been slowly entering the apparel businesssince debutingits own private-label brands in early 2016 with 1
column17: 800 products available for sale under names such as Scout and Ro
column18: Franklin and Freeman
column19: and Society New York.Essentially
column20: it's trying to fill the gaps not covered by its third-party sellers. However
column21: a bigger attraction of doing its own thing isn't lost on investors of AMZN stock
column22: which is that you make more selling your own stuff than you do somebody else's.7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightAccording to Cowen & Co.
column23: Amazon is expected to pass Macy's in 2017 as America's top apparel seller and by 2022 should have16.2% market share.While it could do most of this through its websites
column24: having brick-and-mortar stores has always been on the minds of analysts and retail experts alike.""We believe this deal could address some of (Amazon's) major consumer pain points
column25: wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen in a recent report discussing the possibility of it buying Macy's. ""Amazon needs better brands
column26: a more curated assortment
column27: a physical place to return items
column28: and customers could use help with ensuring fit - Macy's would also give Amazon greater credibility in curation and fashion authority.""That last part's a bit of stretch. I'm pretty sure if Amazon knocked on your door and you're a private label apparel manufacturer
column29: you'd let them in.Real EstateTo take full advantage of its private label expansion
column30: real estate is going to become an important part of the equation as AMZN expands into brick-and-mortar locations. It's not a matter of if Amazon will do this
column31: in my opinion
column32: but when.Right now there is an abundance of retail real estate coming on stream through all the various store closings across America
column33: including68 Macy's stores- part of the bigger 100 store closings announcement from last summer - in 2017
column34: so finding space isn't going to be a problem for AMZN.If you remember what happened toTarget Corporation(NYSE:TGT) in Canada
column35: buying all those leases in one big deal ultimately was its undoing because it put way too much pressure on its employees to execute such a big undertaking.So
column36: there is the argument that Amazon could expand one target market at a time until it has stores across the U.S. Unfortunately
column37: that would take a decade or longer to execute. If it really wants to open retail stores this isn't an appropriate solution for a growth company like AMZN.Why Best Buy?Business wasn't looking good for the Minneapolis-based electronics retailer until CEO Hubert Joly turned the company upside down in 2012 implementing its infamous ""Renew Blue"" turnaround plan that turned physical store locations into local distribution hubs for its e-commerce business.Former CFO Sharon McCollamcalled the ship-from-storeinitiative in February 2016 ""one of the most important and strategic decisions in (Best Buy's) history.""The numbers don't lie. In November
column38: Best Buydelivered strongstrong Q3 2017 results that included continued growth for its e-commerce business along with positive same-store sales growth. It's taken multi-channel retail to the next level.Why Apple Inc. (AAPL) Will Become a Trillion-Dollar Company""Best Buy's third quarter online growth of over 24% results in a very solid quarter
column39: and continues to validate the company's multi-channel transformation
column40: Moody's lead retail analyst Charlie O'Sheasaid in November.Renew Blue's been such a success that retail expert Walter Loeb named Joly his 2016 Retailer of the Year.Bottom Line on AMZN StockBy acquiring Macy's
column41: AMZN would be able to push its products onto the store floors where it could learn more about what apparel shoppers want
column42: while seriously lowering its shipping expenses by implementing a ship-from-store initiative much like Best Buy.Yes
column43: it's already invested billions in warehouses across the country
column44: but getting closer to the customer is never a bad thing; buying Macy's might not happen but if it does
column45: it's got nothing to do with owning real estate and everything to do with AMZN owning the customer.As of this writing

column1: Make No Mistake: Tesla Inc Looks To Be Winding Down SolarCity's Ambitious Plans;2/28/2017;"WhenTesla Inc(NASDAQ: TSLA) bought SolarCity for $2.6 billion late in 2016
column2: a   lot of people (including myself) called the deal a bailout of Elon Musk's high-profile solar   company. The deal didn't seem to do anything to advance Tesla's   electric vehicle (EV) business
column3: it will be a drain on cash
column4: and   it was a huge distraction given the business-model change and   manufacturing expansion SolarCity had undertaken.Fourth-quarter results from Tesla released after the market   closed on Wednesday didn't do a lot to change the narrative that   SolarCity and Tesla are still a strange fit together. In fact
column5: it   could be argued that Tesla is winding down some of SolarCity's   business. Here's how to look at Tesla's solar results last   quarter.Tesla's solar roof is under development at the same time     SolarCity's business is shrinking. Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();The shrinking solar ambitions of TeslaSolarCity has been reducing its installation guidance for a   year now
column6: so it shouldn't be shocking that Tesla's results fell   way short of expectations. At the start of 2016
column7: SolarCity   expected to install 1
column8: 250 MW of solar in 2016. By the end of the   third quarter
column9: the company had reduced guidance to 900 MW
column10: implying about 300 MW of installations in the fourth quarter.In reality
column11: SolarCity and Tesla installed 201 MW in the fourth   quarter and hit just 803 MW of installations for 2016. This is an   incredibly disappointing result and the fourth quarter is   traditionally a peak for the company as people try to get   year-end tax incentives.The move to sales from leases is good
column12: right?Tesla touted the $77 million in cash generated during the   final six weeks of the year and the sale of 28% of solar systems
column13: rather than capital-intensive leases. And on the surface both   look good
column14: but that may not be the case.The cash generation includes tax equity funds being raised   that will be lumpy from quarter to quarter
column15: so it isn't as if you   can extrapolate $77 million in cash generated during those six   weeks into a cash flow projection for the year. In fact
column16: management said on the conference call that SolarCity's leasing   business would hopefully have no impact on its cash position this   year.What's more concerning is that the energy generation and   storage line item on the income statement showed just $3.6   million in gross margin for the quarter to $131.4 million in   revenue
column17: or a 2.7% gross margin. By comparison
column18: SolarCity   generated a 35.7% gross margin for the third quarter of 2016.   This could tell us that slow sales didn't offset higher costs
column19: energy storage margins are low or negative
column20: or that solar system   sales are incredibly low margin. No matter what the cause
column21: a   margin that bad can't be good.The move to sales will also come with more competition. A   customer may be more likely to shop around to find the best price   if Tesla is selling systems for cash
column22: which will likely lead to   lower margins.Remember that SolarCity came with over $1 billion in run rate   annual operating expenses
column23: which have to be paid for with the   gross profits from running the business. If profit margins are   terrible
column24: it could lead to the solar business being a cash sink   for Tesla long-term.Is SolarCity's installation arm in trouble?Tesla is talking a lot about turning the solar business into a   more sales-focused business and getting away from leases (more of   a necessity than a choice
column25: in reality). If Tesla is going to move   to a more opportunistic sales model through its retail stores
column26: it   would make more sense to contract installation through local   contractors that will be the boots on the ground
column27: leaving Tesla   to act as a sales and engineering company. This isn't uncommon
column28: like whenHome DepotorLowe'ssell a kitchen setup orToll Brothersbuilds a house
column29: they use local companies to do the actual   work.But that could entail Tesla laying off thousands of installers   and salespeople who were once at the heart of the business. But   it looks like that's what Tesla is setting up to do
column30: and when you   look at the $1 billion in operating costs
column31: it's the thousands of   workers that SolarCity had on the payroll that add a ton of risk   to Tesla's operations.Tesla hasn't made any announcements yet
column32: but with the scaling   back of solar ambitions and the move to start selling solar   systems through Tesla stores
column33: it would make sense to jettison the   installation arm. And the slowdown in installations last quarter   may be in anticipation of the change.Powerwall. Image source: Tesla.What is Tesla doing with solar manufacturing?Musk and Co. talked a lot about solar manufacturing on   Wednesday and dubbed the Buffalo solar plant Gigafactory 2. Time   will tell if Tesla will be able to make solar panels   cost-effectively
column34: but even if it can
column35: the low output and   potential transition of installations might be a problem for the   plant.When the state of New York gave SolarCity a$750 million subsidy to build the Buffalo   plant
column36: it came with a requirement to ""employ 1
column37: 460 high-tech jobs for   the manufacturing operation"" as well as ""employ at least 2
column38: 000   other personnel in the State of New York to support downstream   solar panel sales and installation for five years."" This is on   top of 1
column39: 440 support and contractor jobs that SolarCity was   supposed to indirectly provide. Tesla may have a hard time   hitting that commitment if it scales back on its installation   fleet.On a more fundamental level
column40: Tesla's move into solar   manufacturing is confusing and disappointing. I don't know why   the company would want to be in the highly competitive solar   manufacturing business
column41: where dozens of companies have gone   bankrupt. And the company's Silevo acquisition
column42: which drove the   move into manufacturing
column43: happened in June of 2014
column44: and we still   haven't seen any sort of manufacturing at scale. There are   promises that the second half of the year will see solar panels   with Panasonic technology start rolling out along with the solar   roof
column45: but until we see product
column46: spec sheets
column47: and pricing
column48: investors should be skeptical.Tesla isn't making a big bet on solarWith all of these factors considered
column49: it's safe to say that   Tesla is scaling back SolarCity's solar growth ambitions and may   even be shrinking the business altogether. And long-term
column50: that   might be the right move given the tough economics in residential   solar.Investors should keep an eye on the transition Tesla is making   to more cash solar sales and solar at retail stores to see how   strong the investment in solar really is -- and what the returns   are. It may just be a bolt-on product made to make electric cars   look cooler
column51: which may not be the worst thing at the end of the   day
column52: all things considered.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column53: it can pay to listen. After all
column54: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column56: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfter a fast start to 2017

column26: but new highs in the near-term would likely prove challenging. At the same time
column27: I want to cover my ""you know what"" in the event Tesla stock fails to hold support on the price chart.One modified spread that fits these parameters nicely is the April $250/$260/$270/$275 call condor. With shares at $246.23
column28: the packaged $10 bull call spread and tighter $5 bear vertical costs around $2.70.The breakeven at April expiration is $252.70 and requires TSLA to be modestly higher by about 2.6%. Above $260 and all the way up to $270
column29: the max profit from the bull vertical translates into a profit of $7.30. Below $250
column30: the entire debit will be forfeited.Play Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Before It Swings Back NorthFrom $270 to $275 the smaller $5 bear spread begins to eat into those gains dollar-for-dollar
column31: but ultimately would leave this trader with $2.30 in net profits above $275 in Tesla stock.Bottom line
column32: the imposed limitation on upside is squarely in TSLA stock's pre-earnings and more euphoric price action. And in our view
column33: it's a nice trade-off for helping reduce downside risk during the life of this spread.Investment accounts under Christopher Tyler's management do not currently own positions in any of the securities or their derivatives mentioned in this article. column1: BP plc (ADR) (BP) Stock Can Ride Out Low Oil Prices
column2: But …;2/28/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBP plc (ADR)(NYSE:BP) is among several oil stocks having a difficult time in 2017. The price of oil has moved up and down as investors try to discern demand for oil against the supply that energy producers bring to market. Presently
column4: there appears to be plenty of supply
column5: and this is depressing prices - including in BP stock
column6: which is off 9% this year.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrOil prices have recently rallied to nearly $55 per barrel. A recent report detailed that the inventory of crude oil in the U.S. dropped to 512.7 million barrels
column7: and OPEC
column8: the large international oil cartel that essentially controls the overall level of oil and gas production in the world
column9: is trying to reduce supply.Unfortunately
column10: both oil and natural gas prices remain depressed. Oil is a far cry from the $100 per barrel it traded at just a couple of years ago. At a current price nearly half that high
column11: the largest players in the industry - such as BP stock - are struggling to turn a profit and generate enough cash flow to sustain paying dividends while continuing to explore for even more oil.The key problem with investing in oil and gas stocks is the difficulty in predicting where oil prices are heading. This uncertainty has hit the share prices of the industry's largest companies. I have been covering industry giantExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) insome detaillately and have found that its high dividend yield is great consolation as management comes to terms with the fact that oil and gas prices are depressed
column12: and are likely to remain low for some time.The 10 Best Oil Stocks to Buy Now for Big-Time GainsExxon's current dividend yield is 3.68%
column13: and XOM stock is hovering close to its low point over the past year. But
column14: since we're getting paid to wait
column15: why not gun for a competitor with an even higher yield?BP is a competing energy giant with a current dividend yield of 7.06%. Shares are also bumping against 52-week lows
column16: and BP stock trades at a reasonable forward P/E near 15x.In contrast
column17: Exxon stock trades closer to 19 times earnings estimates for this year.BP Has a Cash Flow ProblemBP's predicament is similar to Exxon's
column18: in that it's currently spending more than it makes. Back in February
column19: management reported 2016 results. Operating cash flow was $10.7 billion
column20: but the company spent $16.7 billion to explore for and produce oil and gas (the upstream business)
column21: as well as refine it into chemicals and related commodities (the downstream business).Further
column22: BP sold assets and businesses to bring in approximately $2.6 billion
column23: but still didn't generate enough cash to support its shareholder dividend. Last year
column24: it paid out $4.7 billion in dividends
column25: which was well below the $6.7 billion paid in 2015.Management plans to continue straightening out the company's finances this year. BP plans to cut capex to nearly $16 billion and expects to raise as much as $5.5 billion by selling more assets and businesses.However
column26: the company still has to pay out billions related to the Deepwater Horizon debacle in the Gulf of Mexico. In 2017
column27: the payouts should range between $4.5 billion-$5.5 billion.For investors concerned about BP's cash flow predicament
column28: consider that the company can likely ride out any extended period of low oil and gas prices. Sales this year should exceed $233 billion
column29: and the company boasts total assets north of $263 billion. BP's bonds are investment grade
column30: and there's always the chance that energy commodity prices will rally.Bottom Line on BP StockFor the price of BP stock to rally from current levels
column31: the sooner cash flow breaks even
column32: the better. There could also be positive developments on the Deepwater Horizon front
column33: including additional settlements or reductions in future payments.Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Should Keep an Eye on Tesla Inc (TSLA)Of course
column34: if oil prices do rally above $60
column35: BP stock will move upward in sympathy. Few strategists expect this to happen any time soon
column36: but very few predicted oil would drop precipitously from $100 in late 2014 and bottom out at close to $30 per barrel in early 2016.A basket approach
column37: or investing in a handful of the largest energy players in the world
column38: makes sense in today's environment. Exxon still has a reputation as one of the best capital allocators. BP is also up there
column39: and though its oil spill liabilities remain a huge headache
column40: it still has the financial strength to support one of the highest dividend yields in the industry.As of this writing

column37: with shorter production cycles.Should You Buy BA Stock?Analysts are divided on Boeing stock

column43: depends less on what you think of Trump than what you want for yourself. If you are looking for big growth

column45: but if you need retirement income

column1: Why Tesla's Model 3 Production Plans Could Go Awry;2/28/2017;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) is gearing up to put its first true mass-market   product
column2: the Model 3 sedan
column3: into production. If all goes well
column4: the first production Model 3s will roll down a brand-new assembly   line in July.It's a huge step for the Silicon Valley automaker. The Model 3   will be produced in much higher volumes than anything that Tesla   has tried to build so far. And because it's a mass-market   product
column5: the quality expectations will be extraordinarily   high.We know that Tesla has been spending heavily on an elaborate   revamp of its Fremont
column6: California factory as it gears up to put   the Model 3 into production. Last week
column7: CEO Elon Musk gave us a   look into how the company plans to ramp up its production   line.makeArticleAd();Tesla's upcoming Model 3 sedan
column8: shown in concept form last     year. Image source: Tesla.A gradual ramp-up through the first three months of   production""I feel pretty confident that we should get there by the end   of this year
column9: to 5
column10: 000 a week
column11: Musk told analysts during Tesla's   fourth-quarter earnings call. Musk went on to outline the   production schedule that Tesla has given its parts suppliers:1
column12: 000 per week in July;2
column13: 000 per week in August;4
column14: 000 per week in September;5
column15: 000 per week by the end of the year.Keep in mind that that schedule is for parts deliveries to   Tesla's factory in Fremont
column16: California. As Musk pointed out
column17: it   will take time to turn those parts into finished cars as Tesla   works to get its brand-new assembly line running -- and it'll   take more time to deliver those cars to customers.The ""term-paper problem"" that could throw off the   scheduleBut even factoring in those assumptions
column18: Musk warned that the   Model 3 ramp-up could be slowed further by what he called the   ""term-paper problem"":I was a teaching assistant in college
column19: and no matter what     date we set the exam paper for
column20: when the term paper was due
column21: it's always like there are people that are late. It's just the     way it goes. People are sometimes -- and I'm guilty of this too     -- too optimistic about the timing
column22: or they get unlucky.Tesla has set strict delivery dates with its suppliers
column23: but   Musk said that he knows that some number of them might well be   late. Even if it's just 1%
column24: those late parts could throw a big   wrench into Tesla's ambitious production ramp-up schedule. Tesla   would either have to wait for the supplier to deliver the parts
column25: pay (a lot) extra for a rush order from another supplier
column26: or try   to make the parts itself
column27: in-house. Any solution other than   waiting for the original supplier risks introducing quality   concerns -- something that Teslareally can't afford with the Model 3.So does Tesla stand a chance of making its numbers?It does stand a chance of making its numbers. But it's   important to remember that there's a whole lot that can go wrong
column28: and some of that probably will.Like any automaker
column29: Tesla depends on hundreds of different   suppliers for thousands of different parts. Things happen:   Sometimes
column30: the first batches of parts for a brand-new model don't   fit exactly right. Specifications and tooling are adjusted
column31: and   the supplier sends a better-fitting batch -- but that takes   time.The production line for Tesla's Model 3 will have much more     automation than its current lines
column32: Musk said. Image source:     Daniel Sparks/The Motley Fool.Remember also that Tesla's production line for the Model 3   will be brand-new
column33: and it will incorporate much more automation   than Tesla's existing line for the Model S and Model X. That   presents more opportunities for snags that might cost a day or   two here or there
column34: all of which can add up.Most of this will probably be sorted out before Tesla   officially begins production of Model 3s for delivery to   customers. But ""most"" isn't all
column35: and Tesla's investors -- and   customers -- will probably need to be patient as the company   works through the process.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column36: it can pay to listen. After all
column37: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column38: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column39: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Play Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Before It Swings Back North;2/28/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) initially rose after hours following an earnings report that raised as many questions as it answered. However
column3: TSLA stock then succumbed to selling pressures and ultimately fell some 7% across the week.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Lau via Flickr (Modified)AGoldman Sachs downgradeyesterday added another 5% to the recent slide to close at $246.23
column4: with shares of Tesla stock now 12% off the recent highs at the $280 level.With the faith in TSLA stock now broken
column5: the $235 level looms as an important area to hold.Certainly the ongoing questions surrounding Tesla continue to remain unanswered. The most pertinent question involves the likelihood of an additional capital raise for Tesla
column6: especially on the heels of theSolarCityacquisition and the ever alarming free cash flow burn rate. While TSLA appears to have more than adequate liquidity in the short-term
column7: eventually
column8: a dilutive secondary offering appears to be almost virtually certain.Tesla also faces uncertainty surrounding the critical Model 3 launch. Yes
column9: Tesla management is fully confident of their projections … but many analysts are expressing doubts. Certainly
column10: TSLA's past history of Tesla - over-promising and under-delivering - likely weighed on analyst opinion. James Brumley does a superb job ofdrilling down deeplyon some of these very notions.7 Ultra-Cheap Value Stocks to Buy NowWhile faith in Tesla may be difficult to gauge
column11: it is not all that difficult to see from a technical perspective.Tesla Stock ChartsIn my most recent post on TSLA stock
column12: I pointed to an over-abundance of faith in the company at the $270 level and suggested a short-term bearish trade
column13: which proved to be prescient. With shares now approaching the $235 support level
column14: my view on Tesla is decidedly less bearish.Why? Because pricedoesmatter.Click to EnlargeUsing a somewhat simplistic 9-day Relative Strength Index (RSI) methodology has proven to be quite effective in identifying short-term tops and bottoms in Tesla stock. Overbought levels in blue correspond to tops in the stocks and oversold areas in red are indicative of short-term lows
column15: as seen in the chart above.With a current RSI reading of just 32
column16: TSLA is fast approaching an oversold level.Click to EnlargeTSLA stock also bounced off the 50-day moving average at $241
column17: reversing the downtrend and closing well off the lows. This type of reversal many times bodes well in the short run
column18: especially with intermediate support looming at the $235 area.Advanced Micro Devices
column19: Inc. (AMD) Stock Is Going to Stumble SoonSo while I'm decidedly not a Tesla bull for a long-term investment
column20: as a trader
column21: I've switched to a more bullish short-term posture given the recent drubbing in shares. To position for a bounce - or at worst
column22: a consolidation - a bull put spread makes sense.How to Trade TSLA Stock HereBuy March $227.50 puts and sell March $230 puts for a 50 cents net credit.These are the traditional monthly options on TSLA stock that expire March 17. The maximum gain is $50 per spread with maximum risk of $200 per spread. Return on risk is 25%.The short $230 strike provides a 6.5% downside cushion to the $246.23 closing price of Tesla shares and is also well below the $235 support level.As of this writing
