column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Socks the Shorts With the Model 3;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNot that there was any risk of it happening
column3: but never let it be saidTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) isn't a perpetual source of news. Indeed
column4: TSLA stock holders have something new to process nearly every single day
column5: and the occasional weekend day to boot.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThis week was no exception
column6: and three of this week's developments are doing most of the driving right now:Tesla is taking a big step toward Model 3 production starting as planned.Tesla wants to enter India later this year.Short sellers are increasingly betting against Tesla stock as a rather amazing rally has unfurled since the end of November.Here's a little more perspective on all three matters owners of TSLA stock may want to digest
column7: for better or worse.Model 3 Production Beginning SoonThe details on the matter are scant to far
column8: but on Thursday morning
column9: Tesla announced it wouldshut down its California plant this monthto get ready to produce Model 3s
column10: and might begin building the prototype Model 3 as early as Feb. 20. The company anticipates full-scale production beginning later this year … in July
column11: as initially suggested by Musk.The market knew it was only a matter of time
column12: but to see it happening can elate current and would-be owners of Tesla stock. Somehow
column13: the goal of producing 500
column14: 000 vehicles per yer by next year doesn't seem out of reach.7 High-Risk
column15: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowThe company is believed to havereceived nearly 700
column16: 000 reservations- complete with deposits - for the Model 3
column17: which is expected to sport a sticker price of around $35
column18: 000.IndiaThe news came as a tweet on Tuesday - a response to a question to CEO Elon Musk via Twitter
column19: actually. In less than 140 characters
column20: Musk said hehopes to enter the Indian market by this summer.The knee-jerk response is optimism; entering new markets means more revenue potential. It's the second thought that raises questions
column21: though. India is a poor country
column22: per capita. The average annual income in India is $5
column23: 630. Worse
column24: median income is $616. It's not likely many of those consumers are even thinking about buying a TSLA vehicle.There's a curious nuance with the way India's income is distributed
column25: though.In India
column26: the richest 1% of the country controls 58% of the nation's wealth. That's one of the world's most extreme levels of wealth disparity. And when you're talking abouta country with a population of 1.33 billion
column27: it doesn't take a large proportion of the population to create a decent-sized pool of potential buyers.And for what it's worth
column28: the more manufacturing Musk can do in that country rather than import vehicles into India
column29: the better
column30: in terms of marketability. At the same time
column31: though its consumers still aren't as flush as they are in other parts of the world
column32: that's changing.Manhattan Venture Partners' Santosh Rao recently opined
column33: ""The market opportunity is too compelling to ignore. India has a growing middle class with rising disposable income. The manufacturing cost will also be relatively lower.""Short SellersTheWall Street Journal'sBen Eisen was right about one thing this week:Tesla's short-sellers are a persistent bunch.Thing is
column34: they may be a little too persistent for their own good.The 44% gain that TSLA stock has dished out since the first day of December
column35: amazingly enough
column36: wasn't a short-covering one. As of mid-January
column37: 35.04 million shares of TSLA stock were held as a short position
column38: up from the total as of the end of December
column39: and well above the mid-November tally of 31.5 million shares. That's essentially a $9.2 billion collective bet against Tesla
column40: according to calculations from S3 analyst Ihor Dusaniwsk.The bears aren't backing down
column41: betting against Tesla stock as it ticks higher. The mid-January reading is almost a record-high short interest.Big mistake.This is a stock that the market still loves to love
column42: and though it has been a love-hate relationship at times
column43: there's been more love than hate. That hasn't changed recently. Indeed
column44: if anything
column45: as production of electric vehicles scales up
column46: margins should improve. Don't forget that Teslaswung to a profit last quarter
column47: and may well surprise again later this month. It shouldn't take much more upside in TSLA stock to flush these bears out of their short trades
column48: augmenting any rally - the only way to close out a short trade is by buying the stock.The Smart Money: Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Is Already InsolventBy the way
column49: Dusaniwsk estimates that the collective short positions entered of late are have translated into unrealized losses of $2.27 billion. Those traders are apt to be getting very antsy.Bottom Line for Tesla StockTesla still has plenty of hurdles ahead. Namely
column50: it's still spending heavily on …well
column51: pretty much everything
column52: and it remains to be seen if the integration with SolarCity will bear fruit.But
column53: the potential of India is a positive for Tesla stock
column54: as is what is ultimately an ill-advised wave of short-selling of TSLA shares. The prospect of the Model 3's production beginning soon. of course
column55: is a show-stopper.Although a technical dip in the near-term may be in the cards
column56: this week's news can be scored as a pair of wins in the ledger.As of this writing
column57: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceSchlumberger Limited (SLB) Stock Could Be a Gusher. column1: Earnings Preview: Guidance Is Key for Pandora Media Inc (P) Stock;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt seems unlikely that from a fundamental standpoint
column3: there will be a lot of news in thePandora Media Inc(NYSE:P) earnings report on Thursday.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockPandora already announced last month that fourth-quarter results would come in ahead of guidance for both revenue and adjusted Ebitda. That disclosure sent P stock up 6%
column4: and would seem to limit the possibility that the numbers in the Pandora earnings report will boost the stock further.That doesn't mean there will be no news coming out of Pandora earnings. The company has set itself up for a busy 2017. The replacement of Pandora One with Pandora Plus appears to have had some success in the fourth quarter. Commentary on that initiative will be closely watched on the Q4 conference call.Meanwhile
column5: in December
column6: Pandora announced a new ""Premium"" service to compete with offerings fromSpotify
column7: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) and others.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThat product should roll out shortly
column8: potentially boosting growth in 2017. And Pandora has said it is aiming to return to Ebitda profitability in 2017. The Q4 report should give some color as to whether investors in P stock should believe the company.A Busy 2017 for Pandora StockPandora stock actually is up about 65% over the past year
column9: after coming close to all-time lows in early 2016. Those gains have come despite mixed performance in the business. Revenue is up 14% through the first nine months
column10: and likely rose a similar figure in Q4. But about half the year-to-date growth came from the acquisition of TicketFly last October. Advertising revenue also increased 14% through the first three quarters - but came solely from higher pricing. Active users were actually down year-over-year at the end of Q3
column11: and subscription revenue declined in the quarter as well.The user and subscription figures are a major problem for Pandora stock. The market simply doesn't trust that Pandora can create consistent profits based on advertising revenue alone. That's particularly true given thehigher royalty ratesthat took effect at the beginning of last year. So the move by Pandora to upgrade One to Plus - adding features like song replays - and to develop Premium are a clear step toward a subscription-based model.The plan from Pandora
column12: as detailed after the third quarter
column13: is for that type of model to provide a more stable revenue base. Moving customers to subscription-based services both helps margins and improves retention. If Pandora is successful
column14: Pandora stock likely will rise. But that remains a relatively big ""if.""What to Watch for in Pandora EarningsIn the Pandora earnings report
column15: then
column16: the most important numbers likely will come from the company's guidance. That guidance will give some color as to how successful management thinks Plus has been so far - and what kind of opportunity Premium has to boost Pandora earnings this year.But the Pandora earnings conference call also seems like it might move P stock. Management will have another opportunity to detail its strategy for 2017 and beyond. The company laid out its ""three-legged stool"" strategy - Plus
column17: Premium and Ticketfly - after the third quarter
column18: but investors weren't terribly impressed. Pandora stock fell about 14% over the next seven sessionsThe issue with P stock is that there's a real fear that Pandora's model simply doesn't quite work. The product itself is attractive
column19: as evidenced by the nearly 80 million active users. But it's not clear that Pandora can pay higher royalty rates through ad revenue alone. The company did announce layoffs ofabout 7%of its employees in a bid to improve 2017 profits. That simply raised additional concerns about Pandora stock. The most notable is: Can Pandora really compete with Apple
column20: Spotify andAmazon.com
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)?After all
column22: those companies have much larger businesses - and much more cash - than Pandora. P stock still is worth almost $3 billion
column23: yet the company has burned about $127 million in cash just in the first three quarters of 2016. Full-year Ebitda loss is likely to be huge as well
column24: and that's not counting depreciation or the additional $139 million in Pandora stock awards.Make Free Profits From Tesla Inc (TSLA) StockFor Pandora stock to appreciate in the near term
column25: the company needs to get at least close to breakeven in 2017. So full-year guidance given in the Pandora earnings report will be key. But that aside
column26: investors also will be looking for more information on the plan going forward here.Can Pandora find a niche in the music industry? Is Pandora Premium ""too little
column27: too late"" against the offerings from Spotify
column28: Amazon and Apple? And is there really a profitable business model here
column29: or are royalty rates simply too difficult to manage?Those questions can't be answered quite yet
column30: but investors will be looking at the Pandora earnings report closely to better assess the company's prospects. And it's likely the commentary on the future - not the past - that will determine how Pandora stock reacts to Q4 earnings.As of this writing
column31: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. The author does receive royalties from Pandora.More From InvestorPlace4 Energy Stocks That Are Ticking Time Bombs3 Stocks to Buy for Their Coming ReboundThe postEarnings Preview: Guidance Is Key for Pandora Media Inc (P) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: GM's Race To Win Self-Driving Car War Provides Long-Term Opportunity;2/7/2017;"Like Tesla (TSLA)
column2: Google (GOOG
column3: GOOGL) spinoff Waymo
column4: Ford (F) and a host of others
column5: General Motors (GM) is going full-force in the race to be the leader in autonomous cars.A new study shows that it's further along than previously thought
column6: which is a good sign for investors
column7: even if they're not happy with the company's fourth-quarter results.The California Department of Motor Vehicles released a number ofreportsearlier this month from various automakers and tech companies on what they're doing as it relates to self-driving cars and GM
column8: long thought to be ceding the race
column9: has vaulted its position
column10: thanks to acquisitions and heavy spending.makeArticleAd();Cruise Automation
column11: which GMboughtfor more than $1 billion in March 2016
column12: is using a bunch of Chevrolet Bolt EVs to test its software and its cars out in the field. Cruise now has more than 20 vehicles licensed in California
column13: up from just two in early 2016
column14: when it was using a couple of Nissan Leafs.This is a bright sign for the Mary Barra-led company
column15: as it looks to own the entire ecosystem of the next version of the automobile
column16: instead of ceding the race to others.It's likely to keep dealing further into in this area
column17: whether it'spartnering with Lyftor adding engineers to its self-driving car fleet in order to keep testing and building cars inDetroit.Projects like this are likely to help shareholders in the long-run
column18: even if it impacts spending in the interim.In the fourth-quarter
column19: GM earned $1.28 a share on $43.91 billion
column20: ahead of estimates $1.17 a share on $41.53 billion in sales. Despite the earnings beat
column21: investors sent shares lower on concerns of a slowdown in auto sales for 2017
column22: as well as the potential for elevated inventory levels.It's unclear what impact
column23: if any
column24: self-driving cars are likely to have to vehicle volumes in the future. There may be a need for less cars
column25: since they could be working more efficiently. Or there may be a need for a massive resurgence in sales
column26: as costs come down and regulators incentivize manufacturers to make transportation safer.It's just a huge unknown at this point.GM has been building and manufacturing cars for over 100 years
column27: giving it a leg up
column28: at least in terms of the manufacturing process
column29: over any of its Silicon Valley competitors. This is something that Barra has consistently cited as an advantage.“We have 100 years of really understanding vehicles
column30: putting them on the road
column31: making sure we have a safe
column32: high-quality vehicle
column33: ” Barra told reporters at a December press conference. “When you take autonomous
column34: electrification

column1: How the Allure of Growth Led Solar Installers Down a Destructive Path;2/4/2017;"In business
column2: getting the strategy and timing right can often   be a lot more important over the long term than having the best   product or technology. In solar
column3: many companies have failed   because they took the wrong path to market or bet on the wrong   product at the wrong time.In that vein
column4: one lesson worth looking at right now is how   some solar companies had the right long-term strategy for   residential solar
column5: but abandoned it too early in a pursuit of   short-term growth. Below is a look at how companies likeSunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) could have put themselves into dominant position   today
column6: but are instead now at a disadvantage. And how major   players likeTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column7: SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column8: andVivintSolar(NYSE: VSLR) will fit into the market.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();The shifting trends of residential solarThere's been a lot of debate over the past five years about   what the best strategy is for residential solar installers. Among   the notable questions: Is a large
column9: national footprint valuable
column10: or should companies be more focused on local or regional   markets?In general
column11: larger companies have better technology for   quoting rooftop solar system prices
column12: and better access to self   financing (leases); smaller companies tend to have lower   installation costs
column13: but less access to capital within their   control.There are a few moving pieces there
column14: but this generally   allowed large installers like Tesla and Vivint Solar to grow more   quickly and gave them an incentive to get more customers signed   up for leases or power purchase agreements (PPAs). Small   installers didn't see the same growth because of loans
column15: so   customers could buy their system weren't readily available (until   recently). This left smaller players at a disadvantage.This dynamic led to massive market share gains for major
column16: national installers from 2010 to 2015 as they broadened their   reach
column17: brought down their financing costs
column18: and lowered   installation costs. But in 2016
column19: something changed. Loans became   easier for smaller installers to offer
column20: giving them a chance to   leverage their lower costs. You can see below that growth shifted   quite quickly from large installers to smaller installers last   year
column21: a trend that will likely continue.Growth of large and medium size installers in the U.S.     Source:GTM Research Q2 2016 U.S. PV Leaderboard.This creates a couple of problems for the large solar   installers. First
column22: and most obvious
column23: is that they won't be able   to grow as quickly. And when stock prices were sky high
column24: it meant   they had a long way to fall. But the more important factor is   that they have set fixed costs like warehouses
column25: trucks
column26: administration
column27: sales
column28: and installation staff that needs to be   spread across a wide base. A more limited opportunity for growth   will make it harder to pay for those overhead costs.Installers shift to better solar equipmentOn top of the shift toward smaller installers
column29: customers are   shifting toward better solar equipment. You can see in the chart   below that mid-size and long-tail installers favor higher   efficiency and quality modules from manufacturers like SunPower
column30: SolarWorld
column31: andLG
column32: in contrast to the largest installers
column33: which are choosing   lower-cost commodity products from the likes ofTrina SolarandREC.Smaller installers are choosing higher efficiency solar     panels than their large competitors. Image source:GTM Research Module Procurement Trends in the     U.S. Residential Market.When customers are making decisions about equipment
column34: they   generally have different preferences than what SolarCity or   Vivint Solar might pick
column35: but with national installers
column36: they often   don't have a choice in the matter. Some customers prefer   efficiency
column37: some want higher quality
column38: others want U.S.   manufacturing
column39: but the decision matrix is different when it'syour home. And if you can leverage the trend from left to right in the   chart above it'll be good for business.What small installers need to surviveThe advantage small installers have in the solar industry is   lower costs
column40: in large part because they don't need to have the   same capabilities as their larger peers. A small shop with two or   three installation crews isn't going to invest the capital to   build out mapping technology to price specific installations or   custom designed racking components. They're going to lean on   suppliers for many of those products.Ironically
column41: Sunrun was once a leading technology and finance   supplier to medium and small installers around the country
column42: allowing them to offer lease financing and easily quote projects   on the fly -- capabilities that small shop might otherwise not   have. This strategy didn't require Sunrun to build out a risky   national infrastructure of installers. Similarly
column43: Clean Power Finance
column44: who eventually became financierSpruce
column45: had a similar strategy in the solar industry. These are   valuable offerings given trends today
column46: but that wasn't always the   case.Five years ago
column47: Sunrun and Spruce were betting that regional   and local installers were the future of residential solar
column48: and   today
column49: it appears they were right. But if you looked at the   market in 2014 or 2015
column50: it looked like the national companies   were winning out. Sunrun decided it needed to get into the   actual installation business to keep up with the SolarCitys and   Vivints of the world. They were chasing growth
column51: not allowing the   market to come to them -- which was the biggest mistake
column52: long   term.Following the pack comes back to bite SunrunIn 2016
column53: the home solar power market shifted away from leases   to loans and from large
column54: national installers toward smaller   companies
column55: and big  residential solar stocks took a bath as   a result. Where it looked like SolarCity (now owned by Tesla) and   Vivint Solar had the right strategy
column56: which Sunrun followed
column57: their   leadership advantages were just a temporary phenomenon that   prevailed until more competitive market driven by small   installers emerged. Sunrun could have been a leader in today's   market
column58: but now it's stuck with the infrastructure of Tesla or   Vivint without the benefits of a company serving small   installers.Sometimes
column59: companies can have the right strategy but be too   early to the market. That appears to be what happened to Sunrun
column60: which was offering the services that small and mid-size   installers need today
column61: but went off track chasing the growth its   competitors had by getting into the installation business.Today
column62: national solar companies are struggling
column63: and Sunrun is   chasing the market withhigher costs than competitorsand fewer capabilities than a company like Tesla (think energy   storage). If they'd stuck with their previous strategy of   providing technology and financing to installers rather than   trying to beat Tesla and Vivint Solar at their own games
column64: they   could have been a great stock for 2017. Now
column65: chasing growth is   coming back to bite them -- and the large residential solar   installers
column66: too.10 stocks we like better than SunrunWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: This Week in Solar;2/3/2017;"We're still a few weeks away from investors getting a peek   into fourth-quarter earnings in the solar industry and what   management has to say about 2017. In the meantime
column2: we're seeing   interesting trends in some of the industry's most important   markets and from its most visible companies. Also
column3: it may have   escaped headlines this week
column4: but Elon Musk andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)  have made a big bet on solar energy's   future.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Europe and China adapting to cheap solar     energyThe global solar industry is going through some very rapid   changes that investors should keep in mind. Most notable is the   shift of power over the last few years from Europe to China.   SolarPower Europe announced this week that solar installations in   Europe fell 20% from a year ago to 6.9 GW
column5: a level Germany alone   used to surpass on a regular basis. Subsidies have largely dried   up and now solar customers are competing on cost
column6: which isn't   terribly easy in some of Europe's less sunny countries.China
column7: on the other hand
column8: is booming
column9: with around 30 GW of   solar installed in 2016
column10: so the country is trying to find ways to   slow growth. It cut feed-in tariff rates by 19% to start this   year and is going to test a certificate program starting in July.   It's not clear exactly how the program will work except that a   MWh of renewable energy production will be worth a certificate
column11: which will then be compensated by the government in lieu of other   subsidies.As Europe becomes less important to the global solar industry
column12: China becomes more so
column13: so getting subsidies right will be key for   both regions in the long term.SolarCity is on its way outTesla Motors officially changed its name to Tesla this week
column14: and the company will soon phase out the SolarCity name   altogether. SolarCity was instrumental in bringing solar to   hundreds of thousands of people
column15: but Musk's dream of a vertically   integrated renewable energy company under one brand needs to be   under the Tesla name.The most notable upcoming change will be Tesla's marketing of   the solar roof
column16: which will directly tie Tesla's future to solar   manufacturing and installation. If it succeeds
column17: it will be   attributed to Tesla's great engineering and product development   machine. Musk has bet big on solar energy
column18: and now Tesla needs to   make it a real part of its business without the SolarCity   name.TerraForm Global catching up""Better late than never"" must be the model ofTerraForm Global(NASDAQ: GLBL) at this point. This week
column19: the company reported   second-quarter 2016 earnings
column20: which have been delayed due to   SunEdison's bankruptcy last year.Revenue in the second quarter was $56 million
column21: net income was   $6 million
column22: and cash available for distribution was $43 million.   Debt on the balance sheet was $1.21 billion
column23: offset by   unrestricted cash of $870.5 million.As TerraForm Global moves toward a potential sale
column24: it's   important to catch up with required Securities and Exchange   Commission filings and give investors a clear picture of   operations. While I'm not very bullish on shares
column25: it's good to   see a strong cash level that offsets some of the risk associated   with the company's debt. But given the uncertainty of TerraForm   Global's future
column26: I'm not confident enough to buy the stock   today.10 stocks we like better than TeslaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Tesla Just Proved How Valuable Energy Storage Can Be;2/3/2017;"The impact Elon Musk andTesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) will have on the energy industry may be larger in   the power storage segment than anywhere else. Sure
column2: his company   is a leader in electric vehicles and residential solar
column3: but in   the worlds of automakers and solar energy more broadly
column4: Tesla is   a very small player.Energy storage is another matter: Tesla has been more   aggressive in that space
column5: and could take a leadership position   very quickly. And its product could very well upend the   electricity market as we know it.Image source: Tesla.makeArticleAd();Energy storage saves natural gas from itselfThe future of energy can be seen in the emergency energy   storage system built in Southern California after the Aliso   Canyon natural gas storage field's massive leak late in 2015.   Because of that blowout
column6: which released close to 100
column7: 000 metric   tons of methane into the atmosphere
column8: operations at the facility   were curtailed
column9: and there was a chance the region wouldn't have   enough natural gas to meet its energy needs at peak times in the   summer
column10: leading to brownouts or blackouts.Most of the time
column11: the issues at the facility weren't a big   deal relative to California's power supply
column12: because there was   still enough energy overall to meet demand. But there was   the potential for a disparity during evening hours
column13: when   people get home and turn on their lights
column14: that demand could   exceed supply. And that was a concern for the grid operators.Their solution was to install a large array of batteries that   could store energy when it was abundant and easily deploy it to   the grid when needed.Sempra Energy's(NYSE: SRE) San Diego Gas & Electric contracted with Tesla
column15: Greensmith Energy
column16: and AES Energy Storage to build 70 MW of   energy storage with 280 MWh of capacity to offset the Aliso   Canyon outage. Just six months after the request for proposal   went out
column17: the projects were complete.Energy storage added an incredible amount of value to Southern   California's grid
column18: and it did so in very little time. And proving   out these capabilities will allow more energy storage growth in   the future.Filling the needs of a changing power gridThe success of the three energy storage deployments in   California is a milestone that shouldn't go unnoticed. They   filled an urgent need for the grid
column19: were rapidly deployed
column20: and   provide functionality that will allow more integration of   renewable energy sources like wind and solar.As the cost of batteries comes down
column21: applications beyond peak   shaving will provide more value to the grid
column22: and the energy   storage market will continue to grow. Tesla is already pushing   the idea of home energy storage
column23: and companies like Stem
column24: Con Ed
column25: andSunPowerare beginning to build virtual power plants that are a network of   batteries working together. And with battery costs down at least   70% over the past two years to around $200 to $250 per kWh
column26: batteries are becoming a more economic solution for challenges   the electric grid faces everyday.Building 70 MW of energy storage may not seem like an   earth-shattering project
column27: but it's a big step forward for the   grid of the future. If regulators are impressed with how the   project works

column1: Massachusetts Just Gave a Big Opening to Solar + Storage;2/3/2017;"Believe it or not
column2: Massachusetts has emerged as a leader in   renewable energy and may be trying to advance that leadership   position to energy storage. The Massachusetts Department of   Energy Resources just announced theSolar Massachusetts Renewable Target (SMART)   Final Program Designreport. This is a structure to compensate small- and medium-scale   solar and potentially storage projects in the state
column3: and it could   become a new model for states across the country.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();How Massachusetts' new solar program worksThe structure of Massachusetts' new program takes cues from   auctions around the world that have companies compete to supply   resources to the grid
column4: which makes prices more competitive. There   will be a reverse auction that will set solar prices for blocks   of solar projects ranging up to 5 MW in size. Developers will bid   a price and once the block is filled developers will all get the   same price as the highest bid that will complete the block.On top of the price bid for solar
column5: there will be adders for   smaller projects
column6: low-income neighborhood development
column7: different   installation locations
column8: and storage. I've included the storage   adder matrix below to show an example of what an adder matrix   looks like.The adder matrix for energy storage from Massachusetts     Department of Energy. Image source: Massachusetts Department of     Energy.What makes this interesting is that it gives developers an   incentive to add storage to their projects. And given the adders   are up to 7.6 cents per kWh there will be a large economic   justification for bringing more solar into the fold.Depending on the system's pricing and success
column9: this could   become a model for states around the country looking to add more   solar and energy storage to their energy mix. Prices and adders   may vary by location
column10: but the general structure looks promising
column11: especially given the competitive nature of the reverse auction   process.Who to watch in Massachusetts energy marketWho is going to win in the Massachusetts market?Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) will likely be a big player
column12: attempting to expand   its energy storage presence. I would also expectVivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR) to be a large player given its big customer base in   the state. A wildcard could beSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column13: which has a big presence in commercial solar and   has been adding energy storage to the mix
column14: but could be a partner   with third-party developers through its Equinox and Helix   products.Utilities could also have their independent power producer   arms come into the market
column15: although they may prefer just buying   projects when they're completed or working with a partner in the   development process for such small projects. What we should   expect is that when requests for proposals are due
column16: likely this   summer
column17: there will be a lot of interest.As investors
column18: this is worth watching because it could signal   the market is opening up to the value of solar + storage in   future developments. When the price of the two are low enough
column19: they'll also be able to compete for base load contracts against   fossil fuels and reduce the need for spinning reserves (which   level out the variability of solar). And for solar companies
column20: that could result in an explosion in the market's potential.   Massachusetts is certainly leading the way.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Should Volkswagen AG (ADR) (VLKAY) Buy Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA)?;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI've been hard onTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). In my opinion
column3: Tesla is a company built on one crony capitalist deal after another
column4: loaded up on government subsidies
column5: drunk on great PR and sporting a $40 billion valuation - which makes even less sense than the $32 billion it was worth when I wrote about TSLA stocka few weeks ago.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Lau via Flickr (Modified)But Tesla does make a whiz-bang vehicle.So as an investor
column6: there is no way I would buy TSLA stock. I might trade it on either side
column7: but the risk of owning the actual stock is too ridiculous to even contemplate.That's not to say
column8: however
column9: that Tesla stock can't maintain its valuation in a market that doesn't care about valuation.The question is whether or not
column10: over the long term
column11: TSLA falls in line with its true value (which is far lower)
column12: or if something happens that results in the stock vanishing off the market in an acquisition.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryWhich brings me toVolkswagen AG (ADR)(OTCMKTS:VLKAY).VLKAY is in a very unhappy place right now. In September 2015
column13: it admitted that it cheated on exhaust emission tests for its vehicles to make them appear cleaner than they actually were - punching out as much as 40 times the permissible emissions. The car maker is going to spend some $22 billion in the U.S. alone to make good with owners
column14: regulators
column15: dealers and the states.What a mess.So as an investor
column16: my mind thinks about how these two companies might have a synergy of some kind that would take care of their respective problems. Then aFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) pal piped up and wrote
column17: ""VW should buy TSLA.""What a great idea! Not only that
column18: it is actually conceivable.The first problem would be to come up with $30 billion-$40 billion in cash and/or stock to buy TSLA. For most companies
column19: that would be pretty laughable. Yet Volkswagen is not most companies
column20: because about a sixth of it is owned by theQatar Investment Authority
column21: and about 13% is owned by the State of Lower Saxony.Who better to buy out a government-subsidized company that a government subsidized company? Together
column22: these entities also control about 37% of thevoting rights. All it has to do is get another 14% of voting rights on board
column23: from German institutional investors
column24: private shareholders or other foreign institutions
column25: which account for nearly 44% of holdings.This would take care of several issues. First
column26: VLKAY would solve its terrible emissions PR crisis by folding in a ""clean"" approach to its vehicles. It can issue some claim about eventually moving all brands under its name to Tesla's electric model
column27: or in some pairing with its own initiatives.However
column28: with its manufacturing infrastructure
column29: which Tesla doesn't really have in spades
column30: it could theoretically boost the manufacturing capability of TSLA stock. Assuming actual demand for Tesla cars picks up
column31: that demand could be met.TSLA shareholders will get far
column32: far more than their shares are actually worth. Of course
column33: that wouldn't happen at the moment. Shares would have to fall 25% or so before this could even be contemplated.Square Inc (SQ) Stock Is All About the Future
column34: Not the PresentThat is more likely to happen than not considering the volatility of Tesla stock. Also
column35: every quarterly report is like a depth charge for the stock. A good report means the charge sinks to the ocean bottom undisturbed. A bad report and it detonates
column36: and could send the stock to the bottom of the same oceanThen Elon Musk makes a fortune and plows part of his money into SpaceX
column37: before convincing Chinese investors - who are desperate to get their money out of the country - to buy out that company
column38: too.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column39: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column40: has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column41: and has written more than 1
column42: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThe postShould Volkswagen AG (ADR) (VLKAY) Buy Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA)?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Google Earnings: The Market Has Made The Same Mistake Twice;2/2/2017;"Google Earnings (Shutterstock photo)As a general rule
column2: the market is pretty good about learning from its mistakes. After all
column3: there is nothing like a hefty loss to teach traders what not to do.That is a simple fact that must be borne in mind when looking for patterns in pricing; if the pattern involves a reaction to news that was ultimately proven wrong
column4: it is unlikely to repeat very often
column5: and the few opportunities when it does should be grabbed with both hands.makeArticleAd();That is what makes Google parent company Alphabet (GOOG:GOOGL) look like such a good buy after its reaction to Q4 earnings.As you can see from the chart below
column6: prior to last week’s earnings report Google (I’m sorry but I just can’t bring myself to call the company “Alphabet”) had dropped sharply on earnings misses contained in two of the previous three releases
column7: in April and October.On both of those occasions
column8: though
column9: the big drop in price was
column10: with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight
column11: an opportunity to buy the stock at a discount. There are different circumstances this time around
column12: of course
column13: but the dynamic that has made negative reactions to earnings in the past opportunities is still in place
column14: so the end result is likely to be the same.The biggest problems with the Q4 results as far as traders were concerned
column15: it seems
column16: were that cost per click was down
column17: and operating costs had risen to the point where earnings per Class A share (EPS) of $9.36 fell short of the Street’s estimates of around $9.64. Still
column18: revenues of $26.06 billion beat the estimated $25.26 billion.There was also a concern lurking in the background regarding Google taking on both Amazon (AMZN)’s Echo and Apple (AAPL)’s iPhone with recent hardware launches. Google said that they were pleased with the reaction to both Google Home and the Pixel phone without going into specifics
column19: but doubts about the wisdom of the strategy persist.I actually believe that Google has a chance of limited success in each case. The Pixel will be the most uphill struggle as the iPhone’s dominance of the mobile phone market is well established. Most estimates of sales of the phone so far are around 1 million
column20: which hardly puts a dent in the iPhone
column21: but may prove to be enough of a base to make the Pixel profitable as a niche product.Home has an easier
column22: more logical path to success as Google is the natural choice of those looking for what is
column23: essentially
column24: a free-standing search engine.Ultimately
column25: though
column26: neither Home nor Pixel is going to be the driver of the recovery in the stock price that history suggests will come soon.First
column27: the increase in operating costs that Google reported seems
column28: on a breakdown of the numbers
column29: to be the result of investment in the core business. Losses in what the company calls “Other Bets
column30: ” things like “Nest” and self driving cars
column31: were actually reduced somewhat in the fourth quarter
column32: but there was significant progress on the autonomous vehicle front.The possibilities of that field are endless and Google
column33: along with Tesla (TSLA) and Apple
column34: are generally seen as the leaders in driverless car research and technology.The other issue
column35: of falling cost per click (CPC)
column36: is also not what it seems on the surface. It reflects a continuing move to mobile that results in that metric falling
column37: but the volume of clicks increasing. The same issue was
column38: in part
column39: responsible for the April and October drops in GOOG after earnings
column40: and the chart tells the story of how long it was until investors realized that volume more than offset falling CPC.Looking at Google’s results and the market reaction to them
column41: I get a sense of déjà vu. We have actually been here before
column42: twice
column43: and each time the drop in GOOG gave investors a chance to buy cheaply. It seems that in this case the market is still learning from its mistake and over time the outcome here is most likely to be the same."

column1: 2 Things NVIDIA Corporation Needs to Prove in 2017;2/2/2017;"NVIDIA Corporation's(NASDAQ: NVDA) stock price skyrocketed 229% in 2016 and has   left investors wondering if there's more room for the company to   grow this year.NVIDIA has built out a dominant position in the graphics   processing unit (GPU) market for desktop and laptop computers
column2: but investors are also looking to new growth areas like   automotive and virtual reality for NVIDIA's future.Image source: NVIDIA.makeArticleAd();This may never measure up to NVIDIA's stellar performance last   year
column3: but there are two things that the company will need to   prove in 2017 in order to keep momentum going: continue to grow   revenues at a solid clip
column4: and show that investments in new market   segments are paying off.Keep the revenue growth goingEvery investor likes a good earnings beat
column5: and NVIDIA   delivered on that multiple last year. NVIDIA doesn't   necessarily need to beat estimates in order to continue   performing well in 2017
column6: though. Investors should look instead   for the company to deliver on its quarterly guidance and grow its   core GPU gaming business.NVIDIA's management expects revenue of $2.1 billion (plus or   minus 2%) in fiscal Q4 2017
column7: which is in line with analysts'   consensus. NVIDIA has managed to beat analysts estimates for at   least the past four quarters
column8: and it could do the same in Q4
column9: but   investors should be more focused on how the company performs in   thelucrative gaming segment.NVIDIA dominates the desktop GPU market
column10: with more than 70.9%   market share right now
column11: and it should be able to use that   position to sustainably grow revenue and earnings through   2017.NVIDIA brought in 62% of its top-line revenue from its gaming   segment in fiscal Q3 2017
column12: marking a 35% year-over-year increase.   The company needs to prove that it can keep growing its   all-important gaming segment revenue -- overall earnings -- in   order to justify its increasingly high price-to-earnings ratio of   71 (compared to the tech industry average of around 25).Tap into new marketsWhile the company's gaming revenues are the most important for   investors to watch
column13: NVIDIA will also need to prove that its   investments in virtual reality (VR) and the automotive market are   paying off.VR is expected to reach a market size of $70 billion by   2020 and have 171 million active users worldwide by next year.   NVIDIA's GPU market share position means it should have no   problem benefiting from this growing tech segment. But investors   will need to see the company's graphics cards earning more spots   in VR-ready computers.Additionally
column14: NVIDIA has to prove that it can continue   expanding its automotive ambitions. Investors got excited last   year about the possibilities NVIDIA'ssemi-autonomous driving technologieswill bring
column15: and they should expect to see more partnerships and   revenue coming from that in 2017.In fiscal Q3 2017
column16: the company grew automotive revenue by more   than 60% year over year
column17: and a new partnership withTeslashould help the companyexpand its positioneven further this year this year.Good times are likely still aheadNVIDIA likely has more room to grow in 2017
column18: particularly with   the company's core gaming business chugging along so well right   now. But investors' expectations are already sky high after   NVIDIA's run-up in 2016. If the company doesn't show that it can   grow revenues at the same pace (or close to it) and continue   expanding into new segments
column19: some investors may lose   confidence.If that happens
column20: remember to look to NVIDIA's core gaming   business. As long as everything appears in tact there
column21: NVIDIA   should continue to grow over the long term. The company's stock   run-up won't last forever
column22: but that doesn't mean this company   won't be a solid long-term investment if it continues to prove it   can dominate the graphics card market and enter new markets at   the same time.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Tesla Drops 'Motors' From Its Name as It Ramps Up Energy Business;2/1/2017;"In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission this   week
column2: Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) officially dropped ""Motors"" from its name
column3: now   taking on the corporate name of simplyTesla
column4: Inc. The change comes as the company ramps up its energy storage   business and it follows Tesla's recent acquisition of solar   company SolarCity.Image source: The Motley Fool.makeArticleAd();A fitting moveTesla CEO Elon Musk has previously noted he wanted to change   the company's corporate name to just Tesla
column5: citing the company's   growing energy offerings. To this end
column6: Tesla changed its website   from teslamotors.com to tesla.com last year
column7: after the company   purchased the domain from its owner.Recently
column8: Tesla has made its energy ambitions clearer than   ever. In October
column9: Tesla unveiled its solar roof. And
column10: in   November
column11: Tesla officially acquired SolarCity. Meanwhile
column12: Tesla's   energy storage business is ramping up quickly. Just this week   Tesla celebrated its recent80 megawatt-hour battery storage installationfor a California electric utility. This single installation is   more than three times Tesla's record first-quarter 25   megawatt-hours of energy storage deliveries
column13: which management   said spanned four continents and included 2

column16: Tesla announced a   second-generation Powerwall and Powerpack in October with higher   energy density and slightly lower costs on a per-kilowatt-hour   basis.Looking forward

column19: it's going to take more than a name change for   Tesla to truly shift its business increasingly toward energy   products. Investors should bear in mind that Tesla still   generates the bulk of its revenue from electric vehicles. Indeed
column20: even after Tesla's recent acquisition of SolarCity

column24: 000 units today to 500
column25: 00 units in 2018.   Therefore

column1: Tesla Model S Fails To Receive “Top Safety Pick” From IIHS;2/1/2017;"According toCNBC
column2: just one slip-up prevented Tesla from receiving the coveted   ""Top Safety Pick"" award:For the Model S
column3: one crash test where the electric car did     not get the highest rating of ""Good"" was the small overlap     front crash where it was given an ""Acceptable"" rating by the     IIHS.In these specific IIHS tests
column4: test dummies sustained head   injuries when their heads hit the steering wheel. The IIHS also   had concerns about potential leg injuries.makeArticleAd();""Neither of these (potential injuries) were so high that we     would expect life threatening injuries
column5: but they are too high     in our opinion to get ""Good"" ratings for those body regions
column6: said Dave Zuby with IIHS.Tesla responded by touting its sterling safety record:""We are committed to making the world's safest cars

column1: Why Investors Should Listen When General Motors Talks About Self-Driving Cars;1/29/2017;"Many investors think that autonomous vehicles (AVs)
column2: or   ""self-driving cars
column3: will transform the landscape of the   traditional auto business. While I think it's premature to pick   winners and losers
column4: it seems clear that at least some of the   winners will come from outside of the traditional auto industry   network.Some
column5: but not all. One century-old Rust Belt giant is   increasingly confident that it will be among the winners as   self-driving technology goes mainstream -- and if you've followedGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM) under CEO Mary Barra
column6: you know that when GM talks   about technology
column7: it's worth paying close attention.Why GM thinks it will be a self-driving leaderEarlier this month
column8: GM President Dan Ammann explained why the   General's management team thinks GM is well-positioned to lead in   the coming era of self-driving vehicles: ""We have been very   consistent
column9: I think
column10: in our external messaging on autonomous   vehicles and ride-sharing and what we see the opportunity to be.   We think this could be a very
column11: very large
column12: addressable market
column13: in   autonomous and ride-sharing at scale
column14: and we believe that we have   assembled all of the pieces that we need to lead in this   area.""makeArticleAd();This slide from Ammann's presentation shows those ""pieces"" as   GM sees them.Image source: General Motors.Most tech-oriented investors probably don't think of GM as a   leader when it comes to vehicle connectivity. But most of us have   seen those OnStar buttons that GM has been installing in its   vehicles for 20 years now. Put two and two together: GM has taken   the OnStar technology and connectivity platform -- and the   lessons it has learned over the last two decades -- and is   transforming it into a comprehensive platform for the connected   vehicles of the not-very-distant future.As for GM's vehicle platform
column15: the photo says it all.   Ammann:We believe we have the right vehicle platform for AV. We     think the only long-term sustainable path for autonomous     vehicles is fully electric. And we're obviously in a leadership     position with the Bolt. All of our AV development that's going     on is based on the Bolt platform.The all-electric Bolt is already in mass production at GM's   factory in Orion
column16: Michigan. That factory has plenty of capacity   to ramp up
column17: if and when demand for the little electric crossover   increases. ""Manufacturing capability"" is a big challenge for new   industry entrants
column18: but it obviously isn't going to be an issue   for an auto-manufacturing giant like GM.A Chevy Bolt with a prototype self-driving system testing     near GM's technical center in Warren
column19: Michigan. Image source:     General Motors.As for network
column20: that was a key to GM's investment in   ride-hailing start-up Lyft
column21: as Ammann explained: ""And then on the   network
column22: we have our alliance with Lyft
column23: that's one year old now.   And we think it's been very successful in terms of both the   short-term opportunities we've been pursuing in relation to   Express Drive
column24: but also
column25: obviously
column26: the ultimate goal here of   deploying autonomous vehicles into a shared network.""But does GM really have its own self-driving technology? How   can an old Detroit company keep up with Silicon Valley? Part of   the answer is that GM bought a San Francisco-based self-driving   start-up
column27: Cruise Automation
column28: last year. Here's the rest
column29: per   Ammann:So what I'd like to do now is just give you a little bit of     perspective on where we are technology-wise here. Over the last     12 months
column30: particularly through most of 2016
column31: there's been a     lot of hype around AVs and new business models and so on
column32: and     all kinds of noise and perspectives out there. And frankly
column33: what we've been doing as a company
column34: we've been really sort of     working. We've been working in the background. But we thought     it was time to give you a little bit of perspective on where     we're at.So any time any of us from the leadership team are out on     the west coast
column35: we stop by to see the Cruise team and     typically
column36: we'll take a ride and join one of the development     rides in the cars and see how the technology is evolving. And     what I'm going to show you is a video of a ride that I went     on.Amman explained that this video is from a ""regular development   ride
column37: not a special ride done just for the video. It's sped up
column38: but it includes all 22 minutes of the ride that Ammann took
column39: in   the back seat of this vehicle as the video was filming.""Twenty-two minutes
column40: fully autonomous
column41: zero driver takeovers
column42: zero driver intervention
column43: Ammann said. ""The whole ride was   entirely controlled from the Cruise mobile app.""""So there you go. It's real
column44: he said. ""From a technology   point of view
column45: we think a ton of progress has been made. There's   still a lot of work to do
column46: safety
column47: integration and so on. But   this
column48: hopefully
column49: gives you a flavor for how quickly we think this   is moving along.""The takeaway: It's a mistake to overlook General Motors' tech   right nowHere's the takeaway as I see it for investors interested in   self-driving cars and the intersection of technology and   autos.A lot of tech-minded investors
column50: analysts
column51: and pundits didn't   take GM seriously when it first rolled out the concept version of   the Chevy Bolt two years ago. How could hidebound old GM hope to   compete withTesla Motorsand other Silicon Valley darlings
column52: they asked.Fast-forward to today: The Bolt is shipping
column53: and real-world   testing has shown that it exceeds the targets GM announced when   it showed that concept Bolt in early 2015.That's one of many areas in which GM has delivered on   expectations set by Barra
column54: Ammann
column55: and the other members of the   General's management team over the last few years. That's why I   think it will turn out to be a big mistake to look past GM when   talking about self-driving cars.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column56: it can pay to listen. After all
column57: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: 3 Self-Driving-Car Facts You Need to Know;1/29/2017;"Driverless-car stocks could be gearing up for their best year   yet. But beyond company fundamentals
column2: there are regulatory   reasons to be worried about the future of autonomous vehicles.   Here are three things you need to know before you turn the key on   driverless-car stocks.Image source: Waymo (Alphabet)makeArticleAd();1. Driverless cars have killed
column3: but they may be safer than humans.Last May
column4: the driverless-car dream turned into a nightmare. ATesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) Model S owner had Autopilot engaged on a highway   when a truck drove across its path. Neither Autopilot nor the   driver noticed the trailer because of its white color against a   sunny sky
column5: resulting in the first recorded death resulting in   part from a driverless-car technology failure.While this tragic crash has rightly attracted the attention of   regulators
column6: investors
column7: and concerned citizens
column8: it's important to   put this occurrence into perspective. Every year
column10: 000 drivers   and passengers die on America's roads -- that's equivalent to one   death every 15 minutes
column11: and 94% of those are caused by human   error. Given driverless cars' overall track record
column12: the safety   comparison between human- and computer-driven cars clearly points   to an automation advantage.These sorts of empirical analyses are important for investors   and can be even more essential when alarming news (such as a car   crash) emerges that might cause a short-term stock price swing.   On the first trading day after news of the crash was announced
column13: Tesla Motors stock dropped 4%
column14: but it bounced back up for a 2%   overall increase by the end of the day. Steady investors can   ignore the swings and focus on statistics instead.2. Not all self-driving cars are created equalImage source: Getty Images.The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has defined   a five-level continuum to determine how self-driving a car really   is. At Level 0
column15: the human driver does everything. At Level 4
column16: the   human does nothing. Self-driving-car stocks have taken different   approaches to deciding just how driverless they want their cars   to be
column17: but most have come to the conclusion that semi-driverless   cars can actually be the most dangerous. That's because between   level 0 and 4
column18: humans might have to take over when something goes   wrong -- and humans are generally terrible at reacting quickly   and safely. That's why companies that aren't innovating beyond   assisted automation may soon be left behind.Those that are going for full automation
column19: such asFord
column20: Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column21: and Volvo
column22: may be the ones that   ultimately become market leaders
column23: even if their technology isn't   currently widespread. In this case
column24: investors should make sure to   not err on the side of picking semi-driverless models over   autonomous prototypes. For example
column25: Alphabet's stand-alone   company Waymo
column26: which doesn't have a steering wheel and is still   considered by most to be a prototype
column27: may actually be a better   investment than ""proven"" lane-departure warning systems
column28: readily   available on almost all high-end vehicles.3. Self-driving-car companies want to be     regulated.Image source: Getty Images.Companies are often at odds with regulators
column29: spending billions   of dollars on lobbying to ensure politicians steer clear of   market meddling. Ford
column30: Alphabet
column31: Lyft
column32: Uber
column33: and Volvo Cars are   taking an opposite approach. Last April
column34: they established the ""Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets"" to ""work with lawmakers
column35: regulators
column36: and the public to realize   the safety and societal benefits of self-driving vehicles."" Last   month
column37: the group's legal counsel penned an op-ed inThe Hillcalling for a ""single national framework"" to align the country's   regulation and cut down on conflicting local laws and regulations   that could bring driverless-car innovation to a standstill. For   an industry as emerging as driverless cars
column38: this serves as a   smart reminder that investors shouldn't consider regulation to be   evil -- rules are important and can enable the most innovative   companies to push ahead with production.The road aheadSelf-driving-car stocks are hot
column39: and in 2017 they may attract   more attention than ever before. Investors who know the facts and   stick with the stats are likely to come out ahead
column40: so be sure to   keep these three points in mind when making your next   self-driving-car stock pick.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip
column41: it can pay to listen. After all
column42: the newsletter     they have run for over a decade
column43: the Motley Fool Stock     Advisor

That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12

column1: 3 Car Models That Could Get the Ax This Year;1/29/2017;"Which car models are likely to get the ax over the next year   or so?Sometimes
column2: when an automaker plans to discontinue a model
column3: the   company makes it obvious by announcing it -- or by dropping a   strong hint: ""We're closing the factory that makes it."" But other   times
column4: it takes some analysis to figure out which of today's car   models are fated to go the way of the Edsel and Oldsmobile.Here are three models our car-minded Foolish specialists think   will disappear in the next year or so.makeArticleAd();The little car that couldn'tDaniel Miller(Chevrolet Sonic):One vehicle that could be on the chopping block sooner rather   than later isGeneral Motors'(NYSE: GM) Chevrolet Sonic. It's nothing against the Sonic   itself
column5: per se
column6: but the fact is
column7: demand for smaller vehicles is   plummeting while both demand for larger vehicles and a push   toward electrified vehicles are accelerating.The little Chevy Sonic could be cut to make room for new     electric cars. Image source: General Motors.Sales of the Chevy Sonic were down nearly 15% in 2016
column8: and it   remains one of the brand's lowest-volume vehicles. Furthermore
column9: 2016 was the vehicle's worst full year of sales
column10: with only 55
column11: 255   vehicles sold; that's down from its 93
column12: 518 peak in 2014 and far   below the mid-80
column13: 000s sold in 2012 and 2013
column14: its first two full   years on the market.Not only that
column15: but as automakers continue to push toward   electrified lineups
column16: it's worth noting that the Sonic is produced   at the Orion Assembly plant that recently received a $160 million   investment to produce the Chevrolet Bolt EV -- and one could   assume that the plant could be the future production location of   GM's next EV project.The Sonic's segment is falling out of favor with the U.S.   consumer
column17: and thanks to President Donald Trump's tweet flurry
column18: it's less likely that production will be salvaged with a move to   Mexico. That means the Sonic is likely on the chopping block   after only its first model
column19: and its production capacity could be   replaced by a forward-thinking electric vehicle to be produced   alongside the Bolt.The electric car that got left behindTravis Hoium(Nissan LEAF):I'll take the angle of models thatshouldget the ax in 2017. And my pick is theNissan(NASDAQOTH: NSANY) LEAF.One of the very clear trends taking place in the EV industry   is a move toward long-range full-electric vehicles or plug-in   hybrid drivetrains. According toInsideEVs
column20: Tesla Motors'(NASDAQ: TSLA)  Model S and Model X are No. 1 and No. 3 in   the category in sales in the U.S.
column21: with GM's plug-in hybrid Chevy   Volt taking the No. 2 spot.Sales of Nissan's LEAF have fallen as competitors have     introduced more advanced electric models. Image source: Nissan     Motor Co.
column22: Ltd.Falling behind is the Nissan LEAF
column23: which sold 14
column24: 006 units in   2016
column25: down from 17
column27: 200 in 2014. Put another   way
column28: EV sales were up 30% between 2014 and 2016
column29: and Nissan LEAF   sales fell 54% over the same time frame. What Nissan is offering   is not what the market is buying.Nissan knows it needs to increase range beyond the 107 miles   the LEAF can currently travel on a charge. But industry reports   have the unconfirmed base 2018 Nissan LEAF packing just 120 miles   of range
column30: and upgrades only pushing it to about 200 miles. With   Tesla's vehicles already pushing a high-end range of over 300   miles
column31: the LEAF is looking ancient. Add in the fact that the   Chevy Bolt is in dealerships and has a 238-mile range
column32: and that   Tesla's Model 3 is expected mid-year with over 200 miles of   range
column33: and the competition is running laps around Nissan.Nissan was one of the earliest movers in EVs
column34: but the company   hasn't adapted to the market's desire for more range. And I'm   afraid the LEAF is permanently branded as a low-range
column35: uninspired   EV that needs to be scrapped to make room for a well-thought-out   EV that can compete with the next generation of competitors.An iconic car that Americans no longer seem to wantJohn Rosevear(Ford Taurus):It was once the best-selling car in America. Its nameplate   was famously revived by Alan Mulally in one of his first acts   after becoming CEO in 2006. But here in 2017
column36: it looks likeFord Motor Company's(NYSE: F) once-iconic Taurus is on its last legs -- at least in   the United States.Today's Taurus is different from the Tauruses (Tauri?) that   were the best-sellers back in the 1990s
column37: and it's different in   ways that have hit it especially hard as buyer preferences haveswung away from sedansand toward crossover SUVs. For one thing
column38: the current Taurus is   considered a full-size sedan
column39: not midsize
column40: like its predecessors.   Ford's midsize Fusion is still a strong seller
column41: but sales of the   Taurus
column42: like those of most of its full-size rivals
column43: have slumped   in a big way. Ford sold just 34
column44: 626 Tauruses in the U.S. last   year
column45: down over 11%. (By contrast
column46: it sold 265
column47: 840 Fusions.)Once America's best-selling car
column48: the Ford Taurus now appears     headed for retirement. Image source: Ford Motor Company.It's not just about the slumping market segment
column49: though. The   design of the current Taurus has some drawbacks. Notably
column50: its   back seat is more cramped than you'd expect in a car of its size.   That wasn't considered a big deal when it was all-new way back in   2010
column51: but it's a big deal now that cushy back seats have become   an important selling point for big (and midsize) sedans. (That   back seat
column52: by the way
column53: is a big reason Ford has struggled to sell   the Taurus as a police car: Cops say that getting handcuffed   suspects into the back seat can be awkward
column54: especially if the   arrestee is struggling.)Ford could fix those drawbacks with an all-new Taurus. In   fact
column55: it did: Fordlaunched an all-new Taurus for 2016that shares its architecture with the new Lincoln   Continental. But Ford is only building it in China
column56: where large   sedans are still popular. There are apparently no plans to start   building it for the U.S. market.The all-new Taurus that Ford builds and sells in China.     Image source: Ford Motor Company.It'spossibleFord could import some examples of the Chinese-made Taurus   to replace the current model for those customers who still want a   big Ford sedan. But I don't think it's likely: I suspect the Ford   Taurus will be gone from the U.S. for good (or at least for a   while) in a year

column1: The Biggest Investment Opportunity Of Our Lifetime;1/28/2017;"Every hour of every day
column2: enough solar energy reaches earth to   replace all energy consumed in a year combined. Every drop of   oil
column3: every piece of coal
column4: and every cubic foot of natural gas;   trillions of dollars of economic value hits the earth every   hour.If we could capture just a small percentage
column5: a measly 0.03% of   the solar energy hitting the world each year
column6: we could be using   clean
column7: home-grown energy
column8: not only in the U.S.
column9: but around the   world. And the companies that can exploit this resource have the   chance to upend a multi-trillion dollar industry
column10: something so   revolutionary it may only happen once every few generations. And   it creates the biggest investment opportunity I think we'll see   in any of our lifetimes.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.The power of solar energyIt's hard to state just how big the potential for renewable   energy -- and solar energy in particular -- is around the world.   And if the political will is there it would be easy to make an   incredibly large impact on the energy industry over the next   decade. Today
column11: wind and solar power are both cheaper than   electricity from new fossil fuel plants
column12: and there's an abundance   of land in little-utilized locations like deserts
column13: open fields
column14: and oceans where renewable power could be generated. For the   solar industry
column15: energy production can even be put on rooftops   that are otherwise un-utilized around the world.We're already seeing how cost effective solar energy is in   countries around the world.TeslaMotors'(NASDAQ: TSLA) solar division SolarCity is built on selling   rooftop solar as a cost savings tool for customers.First Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR) andSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) are bidding on energy contracts around the world   that compete directly with fossil fuels. And with bids now below   4 cents per kWh
column16: they're winning over traditional energy   sources.From a cost basis
column17: solar energy is now competitive
column18: that much   is clear. And solar energy is such a small percentage of energy   production
column19: providing 1% of electricity demand in 2016
column20: that it   has a lot of growth ahead.A multi-trillion dollar opportunityI think it's important to dive into the numbers a little bit   to show just how big the opportunity is for solar energy
column21: so this   next section may get a little weedsy.The U.S. Energy Information Administration estimates that   global energy consumption will pass 600 quadrillion BTUs before   2020
column22: or in electricity terms 175.8 billion MWh.To show the upside potential for solar energy
column23: let's look at   how much solar power production there would have to be to meet   100% of the energy market's demands. If a solar power plant can   generate its full nameplate capacity 25% of the time
column24: known as   the capacity factor
column25: there would need to be 80
column26: 274 GW of solar   power production installed around the world.In 2016
column27: global solar installations were around 70 GW
column28: and   cumulative installations globally are now about 300 GW installed
column29: a tiny fraction of energy consumption worldwide.To illustrate the potential solar power could have
column30: if we   assume we want to get all of our energy from solar and a solar   power plant lasts 30 years
column31: you would have to install 2
column32: 676 GW   every year to transition the world to solar energy. To accomplish   this
column33: the global solar industry would have to grow 35x from its   size in 2016. Put another way
column34: the solar industry could grow   installations 30% every single year and it would still take   nearly 14 years to reach a rate of 2
column35: 676 GW per year. And that   figure doesn't even assume any growth.By 2040
column36: the IEA predicts annual energy consumption will be   815 quadrillion BTUs. To fill that gap between 815 quadrillion   BTUs and the 600 quadrillion BTU figure I used to calculate the   figures above a total of 28
column37: 800 GW of solar energy would need to   be installed
column38: or about 410x what was installed in 2016.It may sound absurd that solar energy could provide all of our   energy needs
column39: but it may not be all that crazy. Nearly half of   the world's energy consumption is electricity
column40: and the major use   of oil -- transportation -- is starting to be disrupted by   electric vehicles.Cheap and abundant solar could provide a greater percentage of   energy needs as the world electrifies and transitions away from   fossil fuels. The opportunity for solar is worth trillions of   dollars
column41: a huge chance for the companies who grab any significant   part of the market.Why solar profits will go up as the industry growsI've laid out how incredibly big the solar industry's   potential is
column42: but right now it may be hard to draw a line from   the hyper competitive industry we see today to a profitable   growth industry. But this is where the dynamics are changing.Solar energy bids have long struggled to be competitive with   fossil fuels and companies have had to fight each other to win   contracts. Combine that with rapid cost reduction and you have   manufacturers and developers killing each other just to gain   market share.But we're getting to the point where solar energy is starting   to compete with existing energy sources
column43: opening up bigger   markets without the same price competition. And as solar energy   passes coal
column44: nuclear
column45: and natural gas on the cost curve it   doesn't have to lower bid prices as quickly to maintain   competitive. This should allow developers and manufacturers to   slowly expand margins as they cut costs.When you add in new innovations like short and long-term   energy storage and it's possible that solar power plants will be   built to provide a base load source of electricity to the grid
column46: something that's only been dreamed about in the renewable   industry until recently.Why the investing opportunity is so bigHopefully
column47: it's easy to see why the growth opportunity is   enormous
column48: both from a volume of installation perspective and also   from a dollar perspective. As solar energy beats the cost of   coal
column49: natural gas
column50: and oil as an energy source
column51: it would make   sense that the profits and value of solar companies would go up.   But the market hasn't displayed that potential yet.The chart below shows the market caps of three of the largest   solar companies in the world
column52: First Solar
column53: Canadian Solar(NASDAQ: CSIQ)
column54: and SunPower
column55: compared toExxonMobilandRoyal Dutch Shell. You can see the oil giants are worth over 100x more than the   solar companies.FSLR Market Capdata byYChartsIf we ballpark solar energy from a revenue perspective
column56: the   opportunity is equally impressive. Bloomberg New Energy Finance   estimated that $287 billion was invested in all of clean energy   in 2016
column57: including wind
column58: solar
column59: hydro
column60: and other sources. If the   2
column61: 676 GW investment figure I outlined above ends up being true   and solar installations costs are $0.80 per watt (about a 30%   reduction from today) the total value of installations alone   would be about $2.1 trillion.It's impossible to predict how much solar stocks will rise   over the next few decades
column62: but the opportunity for the industry   is easily in the trillions of dollars annually. I think it's   clear that solar energy is the biggest investment opportunity of   our lifetimes. Bigger than computers
column63: bigger than the internet
column64: solar energy could change the world forever. And the companies   that can take a significant amount of market share could become   the new energy giants
column65: replacing the oil giants we know   today.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip
