column1: Why Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Is a Survivor;1/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsWhether it's good news or bad news forAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) shareholders remains to be seen
column3: but the e-commerce giant is   finally starting to crack down on the counterfeit merchandise   that's a little too easy to buy (usually unknowingly) through its   online-shopping sites. Last week
column4: the Chinese e-tailer sued two   vendors for selling fake Swarovski watches.The upside to the value of BABA stock is that with this official   anti-bootlegged-brands stance
column5: Alibaba's e-commerce site gains   more credibility as a venue … among consumers as well as   vendors.makeArticleAd();The downside is
column6: a big chunk of Alibaba stock was built   on sales of low-cost counterfeit goods. On balance though
column7: there's not quite as much risk to BABA stock in the   company's newest position on fakes.BABA: Enough Is EnoughAny statistic that describes the amount of fake merchandise   available via Alibaba's e-commerce platform should be taken with   a grain of salt; nobody truly knows. That hasn't prevented   counterfeit watchdog NetNames from taking a guess though; it   believes anywherebetween 20% and 80%of the goods sold via Alibaba's Taoboa aren't actually made by   the companies their logos
column8: looks and tags are supposed to   imply.NetNames' suggested range of fake merchandise sold by Alibaba   is admittedly wide
column9: but that disparity underscores the complexity   of the problem. Even if the real number is somewhere in the   middle though
column10: at 50%
column11: that's still 50% too much.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The       Experts' PicksIt's an issue that has nagged BABA stock holders for years
column12: though it has become a much more serious concern over the course   of the past year or so. In fact
column13: the problem of knock-offs became   so prevalent that Gucci parent company Kering SA filed a suit   against Alibaba in mid-2015
column14: claiming that not only did the   company not do enough to prevent counterfeit goods from   being sold at its website
column15: but thatAlibaba actually encouraged it.Kering SA's suit was just a microcosm of how other brand names   felt at the time.The lawsuit
column16: along with pressure from Chinese regulators
column17: appeared to get CEO Jack Ma's attention
column18: finally prompting him to say
column19: There's no ceiling for investing in fighting fake goods"" early   last year. Little changed in the months that followed
column20: however.   Indeed
column21: Ma was almost defiant of the backlash in June of last   year
column22: saying:""The problem is that the fake products today
column23: they make better   quality
column24: better prices than the real products
column25: the real names….   It's not the fake products that destroy them [the real designers   making authentic goods]
column26: it's the new business models.""He may well be right
column27: but it's not a philosophy that flies   with regulators or brand-names.The ongoing pressure seems to have finally sunk in
column28: though.   That
column29: or the fact that the Office of the United States Trade   Representative officially (once again)blacklisted Taobao in Decemberseems to have gotten Ma's attention. Last week
column30: Alibaba filed lawsuitsagainst two of its merchants for knowingly selling counterfeit   goods. Presumably
column31: the company will continue to file suits until   it makes the point that fake goods won't be tolerated at its   e-commerce venue.Or
column32: will it?Impact on Alibaba StockIt's easy to make examples of two vendors when there are   thousands more that may or may not notice
column33: or care. If Ma wants   to make a statement that matters
column34: he'll need to take aim more   often
column35: with a bigger gun.And therein lies the rub … it's not clear to what extent Ma   actually wants to crack down on the sale of fake goods at the   Taobao website.In the same sense
column36: it's impossible to determine exactly how   much of the merchandise sold via Alibaba sites is counterfeit;   it's impossible to determine how much business may be lost (and   not won back with sales of authentic goods) should Alibaba crimp   down on bootlegged brands. But
column37: if fake merchandise accounts for   half the goods sold by the e-commerce giant
column38: such measures may   not actually be good for business
column39: or for BABA stock.And ""half"" may be a generous estimate. In January of last   year
column40: China's State Administration for Industry and Commerce   released a study it had commissionedsuggesting that only 37% of the merchandise   available on Taobao was genuine.It's in that light that the underpinnings of the lawsuits may   not be as heartfelt as the more visible suggestion of them is. As   Nissan's William Forsythecommented late last year
column41: ""They are counting the money with their left hand
column42: and covering   their eyes with their right.""To that end
column43: it's not clear if Chinese regulators are entirely   on board with the premise either.Counterfeiting is almost a $400 billion industry   in China
column44: accounting for roughly 12% of its exports. Alibaba is a big   reason that industry has managed to grow at a time the nation   desperately needed more jobs to meet its growth goals. If Taobao   can't sell a big chunk of those goods
column45: the ripple effect could be   significant.Fortunately
column46: there's more bark than bite with the most recent   anti-counterfeiting showmanship.Bottom Line for BABA StockFor better or worse
column47: Ma isn't terribly serious about quelling   sales of sham goods via Taobao. It's one of those things where   consumers - most of them anyway - quietly know the game
column48: understanding no authentic Gucci handbag can sell for $30.Why Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Will Gain 20% in       2017The real Gucci has good reason not to like it
column49: but a buyer of   a $30 knockoff isn't apt to be a potential buyer for the real   thing. And
column50: even to the extent fake merchandise should be   combated
column51: the sheer number of those vendors makes it an almost   insurmountable task.In other words
column52: Alibaba stock holders worried the two   recently filed lawsuits mark the beginning of a much more   disruptive period for the e-commerce giant need not worry.As of this writing
column53: James Brumley did not hold a position     in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in       20177 ""New Industrial"" Stocks to Bore You to the       BankThe postWhy Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Is a   Survivorappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Will Uber Be the Hottest IPO of 2017?;1/9/2017;"Image: AFP/Getty ImagesBy now
column2: I think we all know what Uber is
column3: what it does
column4: and how it makes our lives easier. Bought too many groceries? Get an Uber. Too drunk? Get an Uber. Stressful day at work? Uber. Like magic-now
column5: it's really an expectation-any transportation woes vanish with the digital sight of a car heading your way.Launched only seven years ago
column6: Uber Technologies Inc.is an app-based transportation company headquartered in San Francisco
column7: California
column8: and operates in about 270 cities and more than 60 countries worldwide. Using the app is easy: just type in your current location
column9: where you want to go
column10: and hit request. From there
column11: Uber uses its app to receive its ride requests
column12: sending them out to drivers who transport customers to their final destination.Increased CompetitionThe emergence of on-demand rides has become a popular business venture all over the world
column13: but it has proved difficult for companies to break away from the congested pack. At the end of 2015
column14: Sidecar
column15: another on-demand car service
column16: officially stopped offering rides and deliveries.In addition to the now-defunct Sidecar
column17: companies like Lyft
column18: Curb
column19: Southeast Asia-based Grab
column20: India's Ola
column21: and especially China's Didi Chuxing have all started to eat into the ride-hailing market share
column22: becominghuge competitorsfor Uber. Didi is arguably Uber's biggest threat overseas
column23: and the ride-sharing giant conceded defeat in August
column24: selling its UberChina operationsto Didi and ending an expensive
column25: bruising battle between the two companies.Even Alphabet Inc.GOOGLis becoming a threat to Uber
column26: with plans to make its self-driving cars unit a stand-alone business. This initiative could put the company in direct competition with Uber
column27: as the lack of a driver could keep costs down in the long-term. The company's Google division also recently began a pilot program with Waze
column28: a company they acquired in 2013
column29: that enables thousands of San Francisco commuters to join carpools; Waze also offers real-time driving directions based on information from other drivers.Self-Driving
column30: Uber StyleBut Uber is right on Google's heels
column31: and asself-driving car technologybecomes more commercially available
column32: Uber has been constantly beefing up its business strategies focused on autonomous driving. Back in September
column33: it began testing its self-driving FordFFusions in Pittsburgh; engineers rode in the driver's seat
column34: ready to take over whenever things got tricky.Uber then introduced self-driving Volvo XC90s to San Francisco in December
column35: and riders who requested an uberX were matched with one of these vehicles if one was available. Just days later
column36: however
column37: the California Department of Motor Vehicles revoked the registrations for its self-driving cars
column38: as the company didn't have the proper permits.But Uber being Uber
column39: the fleet of Volvos were on their way to Arizona within days. Uber already operates a self-driving car program in the state
column40: and in 2015
column41: partnered with the University of Arizona to research mapping technology.Uber also recently acquired car start-up Otto
column42: which specializes in self-driving trucks. Otto is a 90-person company
column43: and its co-founder
column44: Anthony Levandowski
column45: will now lead Uber into the self-driving car market. Impressively
column46: Otto engineers have worked at Tesla MotorsTSLA
column47: AppleAAPL
column48: and Google
column49: and with this knowledge and expertise
column50: Uber is bound to be a top player in the self-driving car industry.ControversyWhile Uber has seen great success
column51: it's journey has been a bumpy one. The company has been in and out of the news thanks to legal and publicity issues in a number of countries. From noncompliance issues in New York City to regulatory concerns and lack of driver background checks
column52: Uber has drawn scrutiny and criticism
column53: and has even been banned in The Netherlands and in parts of Thailand
column54: India
column55: and China.It's no secret that traditional taxi services are not happy with the rise of Uber and other ride-hailing companies
column56: and many argue that Uber should be subject to the same regulations that they face. In dozens of cities it has moved in to
column57: Uber has faced intense opposition
column58: lobbying
column59: and legal challenges against it from these taxi companies.Uber has also been embroiled in along-standing battlewith its drivers. A group of drivers first sued the company back in 2013
column60: claiming they should be classified as employees rather than independent contractors. As a result
column61: Uber had been set to pay up to $100 million in reimbursement damages to almost 400
column62: 000 drivers
column63: but recently
column64: a federal judge in California ruled that the settlement was unfair.But as the saying goes
column65: any publicity is good publicity
column66: and all of the bad press has yet to really negatively affect Uber. Despitelosing over $1 billionin the first half of 2016
column67: Uber gained just as much revenue in that same time period. Its ability to raise exorbitant amounts of money is incredibly impressive for a company who is less than a decade old
column68: and this skill makes Uber that much more attractive to venture capital investors.IPO PotentialDespite these controversies
column69: investors are eagerly awaiting an Uber IPO. Many have believed
column70: or hoped
column71: the company would go public for a few years now
column72: but Uber CEO Travis Kalanick wants ""to make sure [an IPO] happens as late as possible
column73: said in an interview withCNBClast year.If and when Uber finally decides to go public
column74: its potential would depend on the broader IPO market and economic environment. According to Renaissance Capital
column75: IPOs only raised a paltry $18.9 billion in 2016
column76: with annual proceeds falling to the lowest level since 2003. Just four companies filed public offerings that grossed over $1 billion.Looking ahead
column77: it's difficult to pinpoint how busy the IPO market will be this year. Snap Inc.
column80: and other major tech giants have signaled plans to go public in 2017. And recent high-growth IPOs like Twilio Inc.TWLOand NutanixNTNXhave traded strongly since their debut
column81: a good sign for tech companies everywhere looking to make their trading debut.How Might Uber Perform?An IPO for Uber could be massive for both the company and Wall Street. It's currently valued at $68 billion after a total of nine rounds of funding worth $12.9 billion since its launch. And thanks to Uber's structure-a unique combination of transportation company
column83: and real world engineering-the company has been touted as one of the best future IPOs.It's IPO
column86: but let one number stay in your mind: $68 billion. Let me write that again: $68 billion. This number is a hard one to forget
column87: and a figure that will be on the forefront of many investors' minds come the time of its public offering
column88: as it impressively showcases just how far this startup has come in a few short years.Stocks that Aren't in the News…YetYou are invited to download the full
column89: up-to-the-minute list of 220 Zacks Rank #1 ""Strong Buys"" free of charge. Many of these companies are almost unheard of by the general public and just starting to get noticed by Wall Street. They have been pinpointed by the Zacks system that nearly tripled the market from 1988 through 2015
column90: with a stellar average gain of +26% per year.See these high-potential stocks now>>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today

(NTNX): Free Stock Analysis ReportTwilio Inc. (TWLO): Free Stock Analysis ReportTo read this article on Zacks.com click here.Zacks Investment Research"

column1: 10 Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement
column2: Not Help It;1/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe first rule of medicine is to do no harm. Your retirement
column4: like your health
column5: is something that you can't afford to screw up. And as with your health
column6: having a safe and stable retirement is generally less about doing things right and more about avoiding major mistakes.Source: ShutterstockJust as you don't have to be a marathon runner to live a long
column7: healthy life
column8: you don't have to have Warren Buffett's stock picking acumen to retire well. Just avoid excessive booze or tobacco - or taking large losses in the stock market - and you're well on your way.makeArticleAd();Today
column9: we're going to look at 10 stocks that you should probably avoid in a retirement portfolio. None are necessarily bad stocks totrade. In fact
column10: I'd argue that there is no such thing as a bad stock to trade if you're doing it with capital you're comfortable putting at risk. But there is a difference between a stock you trade for short-term profit and a stock that you're planning to use to fund your retirement.A retirement stock should be one that has survived the test of time and that is ""future proof
column11: or at least as future proof as a company can be these days. This rules out most technology stocks
column12: which often have short lives as disruptors before being disrupted themselves
column13: and stocks that depend on fickle consumer tastes.7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in     2017So with no more ado
column14: here are 10 stocks that are more likely to hurt your retirement than help it.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: Tesla (TSLA)Source:Windell Oskay via Flickr (Modified)Tesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) is a stock that I want to like. I really do. I love Elon Musk's vision for the company
column15: and I can credibly say that Musk and Tesla have done more to promote alternative energy and driverless cars than just about anyone else out there.When we enjoy an emission-free future in which our cars drive us to work while we browse our messages and sip on lattes
column16: we'll have Musk to thank for that reality.The problem is
column17: I'm not sure Tesla is going to be the company to benefit from it. Tesla may or may not even be in business a decade from now. You see
column18: while Tesla might have started the revolution
column19: its larger
column20: more entrenched competitors have been quick to muscle in. Virtually every large automaker is experimenting with driverless technology
column21: and most are working on green alternatives.Meanwhile
column22: Tesla stock trades for nearly seven times sales … and actually loses money.So
column23: while I wish Mr. Musk the best of luck - and look forward to enjoying the fruits of his labor - I don't want to put my retirement at risk by buying the stock.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: Twitter (TWTR)Source:Christopher via FlickrAnother tech stock that has changed the world
column24: yet can't seem to find a way to profit from it isTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR).Twitter has effectively remade the news industry as we know it. It's become the medium of choice for politicians
column25: celebrities and other media personalities to make major announcements … or to just rant.Yet
column26: unlike rivalFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column27: it still hasn't quite figured out its profit model yet. Facebook finds new and creative ways to squeeze more profitability out of its user base while also expanding that user base. Yet Twitter seems to have mostly stalled out. It's also been overrun by spammers and ""bot"" accounts
column28: which reduces its attractiveness to would-be advertisers.7 ""New Industrial"" Stocks to Bore You to the     BankTwitter trades for about five times sales
column29: which is more or less in line with many other large tech companies. Yet Twitter is still struggling to figure out its business model
column30: which is ridiculous this late in the game. If you want a social media stock to buy and hold
column31: go with Facebook … and dump Twitter.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: Macy's (M)Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrMacy's Inc(NYSE:M)
column32: after the beating it has taken of late
column33: might actually be a decent short-term trade. But I wouldn't want to bet my retirement portfolio on it.Macy's
column34: along with several other department stores
column35: had a lousy holiday shopping season - and this despite American shoppers eagerly opening their wallets in 2016.The issue is that Americans are doing more and more of their shopping online these days
column36: benefitting the likes ofAmazon.com
column37: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) and its online peers. Brick-and-mortar retailers in general have suffered
column38: and big department stores like Macy's have suffered the worst.I don't expect department stores to collectively go out of business. After a period of consolidation
column39: they will find their new place in a retail market in which the primary role of a brick-and-mortar store is to act as a showroom of sorts. But after the dust settles
column40: I'd recommend steering clear of department stores
column41: at least with your retirement portfolio.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: IBM (IBM)Source:Open Grid Scheduler Via FlickrInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) just can't seem to do anything right these days. Its revenues have been in decline for an almost unbelievable 18 consecutive quarters.That's four and a halfyearsof sales declines. You would think that by now the comparable sales would be so low that IBM would have an easy time posting at least modest growth … yet the losses continue.IBM is a perfect example of a company that is far from future proof. It's traditional business model was blown out of the water by cloud upstarts like Amazon andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column42: and IBM has adapted at a sluggish pace. Frankly
column43: the IBM pedigree just isn't worth what it used to be.10 of the Worst Values on Wall StreetIBM was one of Warren Buffett's biggest portfolio additions of the past decade
column44: and Buffett bought it precisely because he liked the recurring nature of IBM's income stream from long-term service contracts. Well
column45: the cloud killed that business model
column46: so it's time to move on. Dump IBM from your retirement portfolio.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: Chipotle (CMG)Source: ShutterstockI loveChipotle Mexican Grill
column47: Inc.(NYSE:CMG) burritos. I really do. I could quite literally eat one every day of my life and never get sick of them (no E. coli pun intended). But as much as I love the company's food
column48: the stock is one I'd consider risky as a long-term holding for a retirement portfolio.Food
column49: like clothing
column50: is subject to the whims of fashion. And Chipotle was one of the first chains to capitalize on the trend toward healthier eating with more organic ingredients. The problem is that there is no real durable competitive advantage there. Any Johnny-come-lately restaurant chain can jump on the organic bandwagon.Despite the beating that Chipotle stock has taken in recent years
column51: due mostly to its health scandals and poor response
column52: CMG stock is far from cheap at current prices. It trades for 44 times expected earnings. The stock price has been relatively stable for the past six months
column53: and it could be the large losses have run their course. But this is still not a stock I'd want to bank my retirement on.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD)Source: ShutterstockAlong the same line
column54: I'd recommending dumping shares ofBuffalo Wild Wings(NASDAQ:BWLD).As a seller of primarily wings and beer
column55: Buffalo Wild Wings has definitely not ridden the healthy and organic eating wave that pushed Chipotle to success. No
column56: this company's success is tied more to timeless appeal of beer and football
column57: and the company has been in operation since 1982.30-plus years of service might suggest that Buffalo Wild Wings has survived the test of time and that it might actually be a decent long-term retirement stock. I disagree.Buffalo Wild Wing's nationwide expansion is a more recent endeavor
column58: and its success has brought a host of competitors
column59: includingWingstop Inc(NASDAQ:WING). The fact is
column60: wings and beer got to be trendy a few years back
column61: and the space is completely saturated at this point
column62: not unlike the Tex-Mex space was 15 years ago. Diners got burned out with Tex-Mex
column63: and I think wing shops are at risk of similar diner burnout.5 Stocks to Buy for a Big JanuaryBuffalo Wild Wings isn't wildly expensive
column64: trading at 23 times expected earnings. But I'd steer clear of it as a retirement stock.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: Whole Foods (WFM)Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Whole Foods Market
column65: Inc.(NASDAQ:WFM) has the same problem that Chipotle does
column66: and I'm not talking about food safety issues.Like Chipotle
column67: Whole Foods was early to the healthy and organic movement. You could even argue that they were afounderof the movement and one of its biggest early beneficiaries.The problem
column68: as with Chipotle
column69: is that there is no real durable advantage there and nothing to stop its rivals from selling the same products … and doing so more cheaply.I like Whole Foods and I can credibly say that the average American eats healthier today in no small part due to the store's influence. But that doesn't mean I want to bet my retirement on it.WFM trades for 21 times expected earnings
column70: which is a bit rich for a grocery store stock. Yes
column71: Whole Foods is a premium store. I get that. But virtually every grocer in town is gentrifying its product lines
column72: and you also have a budding new competitive threat from Amazon with home delivery … in some cases done by aerial drones.Buy Whole Food's produce if you like
column73: but I'd steer clear of the stock.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement: Altria (MO)Source:Peyri Herrera via Flickr (Modified)Even 10 years ago
column74: I probably would have considered Marlboro-makerAltria Group Inc(NYSE:MO)to be a rock-solid retirement stock.After all
column75: people have been smoking tobacco products since the Americas were discovered over 500 years ago. One might think that a half millennium is long enough to survive the test of time.But unfortunately for Altria
column76: the times really have changed. Due to rising health costs
column77: virtually every government in the world has made it their objective to reduce smoking
column78: particularly among teenagers. And it's actually working; American teenagers are more likely to have used an illegal drug over the past year than smoked a cigarette.It's not necessarily a deal breaker to buy a stock in slow decline
column79: so long as the stock is priced right. I've made good money trading tobacco stocks over the past 20 years when their prices have gotten sufficiently beaten down.The 10 Best Contrarian Stocks to Buy in the New     YearThe problem is
column80: tobacco stock are far from cheap today. Altria trades for over 20 times expected earnings and yields just 3.5%. That's simply too high a price to pay for a company in terminal decline.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement:Coca-Cola (KO)Source:Leo Hidalgo via Flickr (Modified)Along the same lines
column81: I'd have to add the iconicThe Coca-Cola Co(NYSE:KO) to the list. Now that governments have successfully beaten down tobacco use
column82: they've moved their attention to the so-called obesity epidemic and its chief culprit: sugary sodas.And adding to this is the general trend toward healthier eating. Among the more fashionable sort
column83: drinking a Coke is just so … déclassé.Hey
column84: I like a cold Dr. Pepper as much as the next Texan
column85: but we seem to be in the minority. Soda sales have been in decline for 11 consecutive years and counting.Now
column86: Coca-Cola sells a lot more than just Coke and Diet Coke. The company has profitable businesses in bottled water
column87: sports drinks and fruit juices. But it's hard to get enthusiastic about the company's prospects when its namesake product is in decline
column88: with no sign of respite.At current prices
column89: KO trades for 21 times earnings and yields 3.3%. That's not ridiculously expensive by any stretch
column90: but it's not cheap enough given the company's growth problem. So for now
column91: I'm recommending you dump Coca-Cola from your retirement portfolio.Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement:iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond (TLT)And finally
column92: I'm going to recommend that you steer clear of bond index exchange-traded funds like theiShares 20+ Yr Treas.Bond (ETF)(NASDAQ:TLT).Bonds have traditionally been an important part of most retirement portfolios
column93: and even at today's low yields I think you could make a solid argument for including bonds. But including bonds and including bond ETFs are two very different things.It comes down to interest rate risk. A bond has no real interest rate risk if held to maturity. Rising yields will cause the market price to fall
column94: but it doesn't really matter if you're not planning to sell. The bond will mature at its par value no matter what happens to prices between now and then. But bond ETFs don't have a fixed maturity. There are presumed to be perpetual. So if we were to enter a long period of rising yields (such as during the 1970s)
column95: your bond ETF would get killed.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The     Experts' PicksConsidering that one of the primary roles of bonds is toreducerisk of loss
column96: that seems like a lousy bet. So if you own TLT
column97: consider dumping it and replacing it with a proper ladder of individual bonds.Charles Sizemore is the principal ofSizemore   Capital Management
column98: an investments firm based in Dallas. As of this writing he had   no position in any stock mentioned.The post10 Stocks That Will Hurt Your Retirement

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) iPhone 10th Birthday Also Marks the End of an Era;1/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsHappy birthday to the iPhone! As difficult as it may be to recall a time when the popular
column3: defining smartphone fromApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) wasn't around
column4: it was ten years ago today the Steve Jobs vision for a portable
column5: connected computer became reality.Source:via AppleEven more difficult to recall amongst the iPhone 10th birthday chatter is the fact that the device arguably turned a struggling
column6: so-so company into an icon
column7: and turned AAPL stock into one of the most fruitful investments of the past decade.makeArticleAd();Perhaps most difficult of all
column8: though
column9: is the fact that after seeing what a game-changer the iPhone has been - for the company as well as society - in just ten years
column10: amostly disappointing response to the iPhone 7calls into question the marketability of the upcoming iPhone 8. Some AAPL shareholders are understandably concerned we may not even bother to remember the phone's 20th birthday.Phone 7 Marks End of Apple's Smartphone ReignThere's no denying the iPhone has earned its stripes. As they say
column11: though
column12: nothing lasts forever. A combination of time
column13: saturation and competition has finally caught up with the iPhone.7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in     2017The evidence of this slowdown started to materialize with the response to the iPhone 6s late last year. It was the first iteration of the iPhone that not onlydidn't sell as well as its predecessors
column14: but also the first to see a dropoff in sales in the two quarters following its launch.Some of the company's staunchest supporters explained that most consumers were holding out for the iPhone 7
column15: which would be a superior device.Maybe there was some truth to the idea. The same party line is being recycled now
column16: however
column17: with would-be iPhone buyers now reportedly holding out for an iPhone 8. It leads one to wonder if the consumer response to the iPhone 8 will be as lackluster as the response to the iPhone 7 has been
column18: with the bulk of them holding out for what will be the iPhone 8s or the iPhone 9.And that's when it hits AAPL investors right in the gut… at some point
column19: the company has to sell iPhones right here
column20: right now
column21: and grow those sales as Apple managed to all the way through the iPhone 6.Perhaps the crux of the problem isn't would-be buyers waiting for the next version. Perhaps most everyone who is going to own any smartphone has a phone they can live with for a while. Perhaps competitors have finally figured out how to make a smartphone that's just as impressive as the iPhone used to be compared to alternatives. As mobile industry consultantChetan Sharma observed:""Apple has the strongest ecosystem
column22: with its hardware
column23: software and app and content stores. iPhone users looking for an upgrade stick with Apple. But in a year when Samsung dropped the ball in a huge way
column24: Apple didn't have a phone with a compelling enough feature set to lure Samsung owners away.""And make no mistake - the iPhone 7 hasn't been flying off the shelves the way it was expected to. Two weeks ago
column25: the Nikkei Asian Review reported the companycut its planned Q1-2017 production of the iPhone 7 by 10%compared to iPhone production from a year earlier [production of the iPhone 6s].Let's also not forget that in September

column1: Another Reason Tesla and Trump May Be a Better Fit Than First Thought;1/7/2017;"After Donald Trump was elected to be the next president of the   United States in November
column2: shares of electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA)  fell about 5% during the next seven days.   Some investors may have been concerned about how a   Republican-controlled White House and Congress could impact   electric-vehicle and solar incentives -- both of which play a   role in Tesla's business.But concerns about Tesla's prospects during a Trump presidency   have eased after the President-elect invited Tesla CEO Elon Musk   to his Tech Summit meeting
column3: and even appointed him to his   Strategic and Policy forum. Indeed

We are building the biggest factory     in the world right here
column8: creating U.S. jobs... I think we may     see some surprising things from the next administration. We     don't think they will be negative on fossil fuels... but they     may also be positive on renewables.While it's impossible to know exactly how the Trump   administration may ""be positive on renewables

column1: This Week in Solar;1/6/2017;"After a year of both progress and stock market turmoil
column2: the   solar industry is likely facing a year of transition in 2017.   Companies are cutting costs so they can stay afloat
column3: and   positioning themselves for growth with new products. This week
column4: a   few companies moved in different directions in relation to those   goals.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Solar ends 2016 in a great positionIf you're hoping to see more solar power produced around the   world
column5: you should be very encouraged by new data fromBloomberg New Energy Finance. The group recently reported that the cost of building a solar   power plant is down 62% since 2009
column6: and new contracts in Chile   and the UAE have been signed for less than 3 cents per kWh
column7: a   price that would beat any new coal plant.Solar is already highly cost effective in sunny countries
column8: but   what's even more encouraging is that costs will likely be lower   than coal in nearly every country within a decade. It's easy to   see how solar could be cost effective today in Chile
column9: Dubai
column10: or   states in the American Southwest
column11: but the fact that it's becoming   price competitive in the U.K.
column12: Canada
column13: and U.S. states like   Minnesota has to be encouraging for the industry.The Gigafactory finally gets off the groundA lot has been written aboutTesla's(NASDAQ: TSLA) Gigafactory over the last few years
column14: but this week   Tesla and Panasonic announced the facility is actually producing   battery cells. Eventually
column15: the low-cost
column16: high-performance 2170   cells jointly developed by the two companies will end up in   Tesla's Model 3. But for now
column17: those coming off the assembly line   will be put into the Powerwall 2 and Powerpack 2.2017 could be a big year for Tesla's energy storage business   as utilities put rates in place that make home energy storage   more viable
column18: and large-scale storage solutions start to be good   options for utilities themselves. And now
column19: some of those   batteries will be coming from Tesla's Gigafactory.Is another residential solar growth story going     bust?Last summer
column20: residential solar company Sungevity seemed to   have found a bailout from Easterly Acquisition Corp.
column21: which would   have performed a reverse merger to take the company public. As   part of the deal
column22: Sungevity would have gotten access to $200   million of capital
column23: which could have kept it afloat while   management tried to steer it toward profitability.After the first of the year
column24: the reverse merger is off
column25: and   Sungevity seems to be in serious trouble. This isn't going to   upend residential solar as we know it because Sungevity had just   a 1.6% market share
column26: according toGTM Research. But it's a sign of how difficult the business has been for   companies in the past year. Tesla's SolarCity had to lower its   guidance multiple times
column27: and most companies had to pivot to   offering loans instead of long-term lease deals. Sungevity's   potential collapse is a another reminder of how hard it is to   make money in the rooftop solar business.Canadian Solar monetizes assetsThe year 2017 is going to be a tough year for solar panel   manufacturers and developers as demand sags and panel prices   continue slump. One of the ways companies are preparing for that   is by monetizing assets they have on their balance sheets.Canadian Solar Inc.(NASDAQ: CSIQ) did that just before the end of the year
column28: selling   20 MW of Canadian projects for $115 million and two more power   plants in China for $32.2 million.The cash can now be used to pay down debt
column29: reducing risk for   the business
column30: or sit on the balance sheet to create a cushion. No   matter how you look at it
column31: an infusion of $147.2 million is good   for Canadian Solar long term.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: Tesla's (TSLA) Gigafactory Starts Battery Cell Production;1/5/2017;"Tesla Motors
column2: Inc.TSLAhas initiated lithium-ion battery cells production at its Gigafactory in Nevada in collaboration withPanasonic Corp.PCRFY. The cylindrical 2170 cells will be used in the Tesla's Powerwall energy storage products. These cells have been jointly designed by Tesla and Panasonic.makeArticleAd();Tesla intends to start producing batteries for the Model 3 sedans later this year. In July 2016
column3: the company held the official opening of the partly-constructed Gigafactory as per plan. Tesla expects 31% of the factory construction to complete by the second quarter of 2017.In order to deal with the shortage of lithium-ion batteries
column4: Tesla is building a Gigafactory in collaboration with partners like Panasonic. The automaker will receive tax incentives of $1.3 billion over a period of 20 years from the Nevada government for the construction of the factory. Tesla expects to wrap up construction work by 2017.By 2018
column5: Tesla expects cost of its batteries to reduce by over one-third due to large-scale production at the Gigafactory. In the same year
column6: Tesla expects the annual lithium-ion battery production of the Gigafactory to reach around 35 gigawatt hours
column7: which is equal to the total global production in 2014.Moreover
column8: the company has the capacity to increase production to around 150 gigawatt hours. The automaker expects the factory to provide economies of scale
column9: reduce logistics wastes

column1: Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Has Nothing to Fear From Faraday Future;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOne of the big reveals at this year's Consumer Electronics Show happened yesterday
column3: before the show's official Jan. 5 open. And withTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) stock down 1.5% today
column4: are Tesla's shareholders getting the heebie-jeebies?Source: Faraday FutureFaradayFuture
column5: the mysterious electric car startup thatshowed off a non-functional concept carat last year's show was back.makeArticleAd();This time the company had the Faraday Future FF 91
column6: a working
column7: ultra-fast electric car that demonstrated its autonomous parking capability
column8: while boasting a slew of class-leading features.Faraday Future FF 91At CES 2017
column9: Faraday Future showed off its newFF 91 electric vehicle. One prototype was shown parking itself in downtown Las Vegas via a live video feed. A second unit onstage performed a similar stunt.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The     Experts' PicksThe vehicle packsan incredible 1
column10: 050 horsepowerin its electric motors with high-density battery packs good for a class-leading 378-mile range. Bluetooth integration
column11: a smartphone app and facial recognition cameras are key to everything from opening the doors to learning driver preferences.The Faraday Future FF 91 is equipped with more than 30 advanced sensors for autonomous driving
column12: including cameras
column13: radar
column14: ultrasonic sensors and a retractable Lidar unit.Taking Aim at TeslaThe comparisons to Tesla and its current line-up of premium electric vehicles showed that Faraday Future is hoping to steal some thunder - and some customers.Faraday Future claims its new car has the densest battery pack available
column15: with 130 kilowatt-hours of energy. Tesla meanwhile
column16: just introduced a 100 kilowatt-hour battery pack in August
column17: an optional upgrade to the 90 kilowatt-hour pack offered with the Model S starting in 2015. The higher density battery pack means the Faraday Future FF 91 gets superior range (378 miles compared to 315 miles for the Tesla) and faster speed. Faraday is also promising wireless charging is coming at some point.The Faraday Future FF 91 was pitted directly against a Tesla Model S and Tesla Model X in a race (which concluded offstage and wasn't independently verified). The Faraday Future FF 91 won
column18: boasting a supposed new production car speed recordof 0 to 60 mph
column19: at 2.39 seconds.Should Tesla be Worried?The Faraday Future FF 91 was at least a working automobile - unlike last year's stationary display model - but it's not quite ready for prime time.There were glitches
column20: including an embarrassing moment whenthe car refused to start moving on stageduring a self-parking demonstration.Jalopnikalso noted assembly flaws and a reluctance to show the interior of the car
column21: signs that the Faraday Future FF 91 isn't yet production-ready.Then there is the disastrous state of the company itself
column22: described in a feature article inThe Vergeas""an electric carmaker on the brink of collapse.""If the company survives to begin production
column23: asBusiness Insiderpointed out last year

column25: something that is obviously good for Tesla. And from the appearances of the Faraday Future FF 91
column26: the company is currently aiming at a premium market
column27: while Tesla is pinning its future on mass production of the affordable Model 3.Car lovers with deep pockets can nowreserve an FF 91 for $5
column28: 000- and yes

column31: the prototype was imperfect and even if it does get its act together

column1: As Calpers Flails
column2: Don’t Bank on Your Pension;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMillions of Americans are partially or wholly banking on some form of pension funds for retirement
column4: whether they they work for a large corporation
column5: a municipality or a given state. The problem is that many of these pensions - such as Calpers
column6: which is the pension and health benefits system for well more than a million of California's public employees - are underfunded.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWhat's ""underfunded"" mean
column7: exactly? It means many of these pension funds do not have adequate assets to pay out the full 100% of benefits due to their workers for the entire period of time they are projected to have to do so.That means that all government workers need to be aware that they cannot
column8: and should not
column9: assume their pension funds will provide for them in retirement.Instead
column10: you need to have alternative plans in place
column11: and that means investing on your own right now. Start learning the basics
column12: and start setting money aside. (Andsign up for a stock advisory newsletter like The Liberty Portfolio
column13: which I'll be launching shortly.)Calpers - the California Public Employees' Retirement System - has been in the news quite a bit this past year. Andbecause it is only 76% funded
column14: it is a clarion call to government workers to wake up before it's too late. As theNew York Timesreports. Calpers is ""considering cutting its investment return assumption.""Ya think?The 10 Best Contrarian Stocks to Buy in the New YearIn 2012
column15: it cut the assumption by 0.25% to 7.5% annually
column16: while returning 5.1% annually over the past 10 years
column17: according to theNY Times. Last week
column18: itdropped the expected returnsto 7%. Along with it
column19: Calpers is monkeying around with what higher rates local governments are going to have to pay to get the $139 billion unfunded liability to go down. Employers may face a 30% to 40% increase in payments. That's just insane
column20: because that money means more tax increases.Let's face it: Getting the unfunded liabilities down to zero will never happen. It's like any government program - once the debt or unfunded portion gets past a certain point
column21: the ship has begun taking on water.So what can middle-aged employees do to anticipate a reduced pension payout?Invest.Investing on Your OwnThe investment approach will need to be different from that of the Calpers fund. Page 99 of the its financial report shows that ""your"" money is alreadyspread around many of the top equity namesalready:Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL)
column22: Exxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM)
column23: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column24: Johnson & Johnson(NYSE:JNJ) andAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T)
column25: just to name the top five.Without seeing a complete set of portfolio holdings
column26: it is difficult to say where I think Calpers is underweighted inappropriately. However
column27: considering the overall returns of the fund compared to theS&P 500 Indexand other benchmarks
column28: it sure looks poorly managed overall.I tend to believe that most funds and managers are underweighted in value stocks
column29: small caps and in preferred stocks. I think most are vastly overweighted
column30: and wrongly so
column31: in bonds. Preferred stocks and baby bonds (also known as exchange-traded debt) offer higher yields with comparable risk to government bonds.So what might be the best strategy if you are a Calpers pensioner? The first thing you need is more complete information.Go ahead and order the complete set of holdings. Hopefully they will break down the asset allocation in that filing. Asset allocation is crucial
column32: because if you are middle-aged
column33: getting the right balance is key. As for what actually is the right balance
column34: that's something you have to decide yourself based on your risk profile. There are many ways of determining that.We certainly know that you need not invest in large cap stocks like AAPL
column35: XOM
column36: MSFT and the familiar names. No
column37: my guess is you'll need small-cap value and growth names
column38: or exchange-traded funds for that exposure. You'll need individual preferred stocks
column39: which I think are better than the ETFs offered
column40: and which I will discuss inThe Liberty Portfolio.The Dirty Secret to Trading Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) StockThese equity names and ETFs will expose you to a bit more risk
column41: but I don't think you need to plow tons of capital into those names. I think that otherwise
column42: prudent choices in preferred stocks
column43: baby bonds and some real estate investment trusts should pay off over the long term.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column44: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column45: he has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column46: and has written more than 1
column47: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' Picks5 Stocks to Buy Ahead of the ""January Effect""The postAs Calpers Flails

column1: Nothing Can Stop the Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Freight Train;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlthough many analysts are putting aqualified success anglefor this year's retail holiday season
column4: there's no hiding the ugly truth - retail stocks are languishing.Source: ShutterstockSure
column5: the Black Friday weekend got off to agreat start
column6: but that has much to do with stores opening on Thanksgiving Day.makeArticleAd();Brick-and-mortar retailers are still finding it difficult to attract shoppers. The one bright spot is e-commerce. Unfortunately for everyone else
column7: that is a domain becoming increasingly swallowed up byAmazon.com
column8: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN).A cursory look at major retail stocks gives you all the info you need to know. Shares ofWal-Mart Stores
column9: Inc. (NYSE:WMT) andTarget Corporation(NYSE:TGT) have given up a significant portion of their post-election rallies.For the month of December
column10: WMT slipped 1% below parity
column11: while TGT fell by more than 7%. And it wasn't just discount retailers
column12: either. High-end names such asNordstrom
column13: Inc. (NYSE:JWN) andWilliams Sonoma
column14: Inc. (NYSE:WSM) have absorbed horrible losses in the markets.5 Stocks to Buy for a Big JanuaryEven AMZN stock was not immune from the pain. Since closing at an all-time high in early October
column15: Amazon stock has given up more than 11%. Worse yet
column16: shares didn't seem to gain much traction. While AMZN closed out the year up 11%
column17: that may be little comfort to those who are assessing the nearer-term momentum. AMZN stock has been sandwiched between its 50- and 200-day moving averages for some time
column18: suggesting pensiveness among the bulls.A Challenging Environment for AMZN StockI think anybody can appreciate the lack of confidence toward AMZN stock. Wall Street is about making profits
column19: not pontificating about prior achievements. If there's one thing that can disrupt Amazon stock
column20: it would be declining consumer sentiment. To that end
column21: reduced advertisementsby retailers is a worrisome sign.Click to EnlargeThis is where hard data can help distinguish between either a natural correction for AMZN stock
column22: or something more permanent. According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column23: e-commerce is anunstoppable force.In the six years from 2000 through the end of 2005
column24: online retail sales totaled $326.6 million. In last year alone
column25: that figure jumped to $341.5 million. By default
column26: this just feeds into the Amazon stock machine.But more so than the raw numbers
column27: the growth rate in online retailing continues to impress. Of course
column28: nothing will come close to the nascent years of e-commerce. In the 2000s
column29: online sales grew annually by 21%. But over the past six years
column30: the growth rate is still a robust 15%. Since all indications point to a superior performance in the fourth quarter of 2016
column31: that rate is only going higher.This is simply great news for AMZN stock. Admittedly
column32: though
column33: its success is coming at great cost to the overall industry. Whiletotal retailsales exclusive of food services is a massive entity
column34: the percentage of shoppers doing business online is skewing unfavorably for the brick-and-mortars.A prime example is the immediate fallout from the Great Recession. Retail overall saw negative growth in 2008 and 2009
column35: particularly seriously during the latter. In contrast
column36: e-commerce growth was hit hard
column37: but never dipped into the red thanks to companies like AMZN. In addition
column38: aggregate retail sales this decade average an anemic 4.5%.Amazon Demonstrates Why It's the BestI think we also need to acknowledge another basic reality - AMZN is a freak of nature. Despite difficult circumstances for its land-based competitors
column39: the e-commerce giant finds new ways to leap above the fray. Case in point is the more thanone billion productsthat were pushed out the door due to its Prime and Fulfillment services. That has to be a major letdown for Amazon stock competitors
column40: who are trying to find some way of remotely keeping pace.An even greater challenge is addressing the in-house sales that the Seattle-based company generates. Demand for the Echo speakers that are an accessory to Amazon's Alexa voice recognition software jumped nine fold from last year's holiday season. According to their senior management team
column41: the Echo was flying off the shelf despite a significant boost in production. If there's just one reason to buy AMZN stock
column42: that might be it.Finally
column43: the most impressive element of the organization is that they haven't lost their hunger for innovation.Amazon Go- the firm's foray into the ultra-competitive grocery sector - is nothing short of astonishing. Layered with consumer-centric technologies that represents a paradigm shift in shopping
column44: AMZN takes integration to a new level. Thus
column45: an investment in AMZN stock is an investment into the future.The Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a     Make-or-Break StrategyI can only come to one conclusion. Amazon stock is as sure of a long-term bet as anything else in the markets. Not only is it dominating its own industry
column46: AMZN is disrupting others. It is both retailer and producer - and it does both things amazingly well.Finally
column47: it has enough moxie and leverage to compete in utterly foreign sectors. Again
column48: there's nothing out there quite like AMZN stock.As of this writing

column1: GoPro Inc (GPRO) Announces Karma Drone Re-Launch in 2017;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCES 2017 is in full swing and many tech companies are there showing off their new gear. Some are using the event and its concentration of journalists to explain what went wrong last year and what their plans are to make things right.GoProInc(NASDAQ:GPRO) is in the latter camp.Click to EnlargeSource: GoProThe company chose the Consumer Electronics Show to announce it will re-launch the GoPro Karma drone in 2017.makeArticleAd();GoPro was one of the top tech news stories of 2016
column3: but not in a good way. Seeking to diversify beyond action cameras
column4: GPRO released the GoPro Karma
column5: its first entry in the drone market. However the the Karma dronewas a disaster from the start
column6: despite an innovative folding design.The release itself was months later than expected. And once the Karma drone was officially unveiled
column7: DJI- the Chinese company that leads the consumer drone market - announced a compact folding drone of its own.5 Stocks to Buy for a Big JanuaryThe DJI Mavic included a 4K camera while costing the same as the entry-level GoPro Karma (which did not include a camera)
column8: effectively undercutting its price by several hundred dollars. Adding insult to injury
column9: the DJI Mavic was availablebeforethe GoPro Karma could hit store shelves.Then things went from bad to worse for GPRO. The GoPro Karma drones it did sell starting in September began falling out of the sky. This forced the company to recall the Karma drone.GPRO Stock Takes a BeatingGoing into the holiday shopping season
column10: GPRO was facing a PR issue with its recalled Karma drone. It had no drones to sell
column11: leaving consumers looking for big-ticket
column12: high-tech gifts to buy the DJI Mavic instead.Following the Karma recall
column13: the company was forced tolay off 200 employees(15% of its staff) and the company's president left amid the restructuring. Earnings were missed - badly - and GoPro stock took a beating.The company desperately needs some good news to kick off 2017.GoPro Karma Will Re-Launch in 2017Rather than demonstrate new products at the Consumer Electronics Show
column14: GPRO is there ""demonstrating recent product breakthroughs."" The biggest breakthrough of all for the company is a resolution to the Karma drone crisis.GoPro chose CES 2017 to announce it willre-launch the Karma drone in 2017. According to GoPro
column15: the issue that brought its drones out of the sky has been identified as ""power loss due to a mechanical issue related to securing the drone's battery.""GoPro says it has fixed the design flaw and is currently finishing up testing. It says further details will be provided in February outlining the plans for the GoPro Karma worldwide re-launch.2016 was not a great year for GPRO. Demand for action cameras softened even as additional competitors entered the market and smartphones began to emerge as a threat:Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) released a water-resistant iPhone 7 that could shoot 4K video and 120 frames per second slow motion 1080p video. There were manufacturing challenges with its new Hero5 camera and the Karma drone recall capped things off. After the dust settled
column16: GoPro stock shed over 50% of its value in 2016.However
column17: GPRO was able to sell the Karma Grip (handheld camera stabilizer) component of the Karma drone separately in time for Christmas
column18: and the company reportedGoPro camera sales up 35% on Black Fridaycompared to the previous year.If it is able to successfully re-launch the GoPro Karma in 2017 it will have missed out on the 2016 holiday shopping season
column19: but will have most of the year to build up sales and recognition leading into next Christmas.The Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a     Make-or-Break StrategySince announcing the Karma drone re-launch
column20: GoPro stock is up over 2.5%
column21: reflecting the possibility that the company is finally putting a terrible 2016 behind it.As of this writing
column22: Brad Moon did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceCES 2017: The Hottest Headlines From Media Day     13 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in     2017The postGoPro Inc (GPRO) Announces Karma Drone Re-Launch in 2017appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Tesla Motors
column2: Inc. Stock Soared in December;1/5/2017;"What happenedShares of electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) soared 17.5% in December
column3: according to data   provided byS&P Global Market Intelligence. The stock's rise helped it recover some of its pullback earlier   in the year.The Tesla Model S. Image source: The Motley Fool.makeArticleAd();So whatThere's no surefire reason for Tesla's 17.5% gain during the   month
column4: but one did stand out as the most likely catalyst for at   least a portion of the gain.Tesla stockhad pulled back in the weeks following the U.S. presidential   election
column5: perhaps because investors were concerned about how   Tesla could be impacted during Trump's time as president. Trump   has expressed disbelief about global warming and outlined actions   for eliminating some government spending related to climate   change. But sentiment about how Tesla might fare with Trump as   president turned rosier when the president-elect startedcozying up to Elon Musk. Trump invited the Tesla CEO to his tech summit meeting in New   York City
column6: and even appointed him to his Strategic and Policy   Forum.So
column7: Tesla stock may have simply rebounded in December from a   sell-off spurred by an overreaction to Trump's election. Of   course
column8: there were probably other factors driving the rebound
column9: such as theS&P 500's overall 2% gain during this period
column10: but Trump's warming up to   Musk was likely one of the main catalysts for Tesla stock during   the month.Now whatInvestors shouldn't read too much into month-to-month moves   like this
column11: but it is notable to see Trump keeping Musk close to   his side. Still
column12: investors may want to keep an eye on any   political action during Trump's presidency that could impact   Tesla.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column13: it can pay to listen. After all

column1: The Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a Make-or-Break Strategy;1/5/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe new year is shaping up to be a make-or-break year for electric vehicle innovatorTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA). That's because we finally get to see whether CEO Elon Musk's vision of a fully integrated clean-energy company - spanning production
column3: storage and end-use of renewable energy - can come to fruition. Needless to say
column4: TSLA stock holders will be watching with eyes as wide as dinner plates.Source:OnInnovation via FlickrLast year
column5: the major piece of the puzzle was the bailout buyout of fellow Musk company
column6: SolarCity. That deal will supposedly tuck in the generation part of the plan.makeArticleAd();But right now
column7: the story is all about storage. Tesla finally flipped the switch on its massive battery production facility - dubbed the Gigafactory.Without it
column8: there's no way Tesla Motors can deliver on its lofty long-term goals. Nor can the company support the lofty price on TSLA stock
column9: either.The Gigafactory not just a battery farm. It's a critical piece of the Tesla Motors story.Tesla's Big Plans for Its Big GigafactoryLithium batteries make the world go 'round. Storage of energy is a key component in basically everything
column10: from solar panels to your smartphone. And lithium battery production has long been dominated by Japan
column11: China
column12: and other southeast Asian nations;roughly 88%of the world's battery production comes from the region.Tesla's problem is an ambitious goal of delivering 500
column13: 000 vehicles in 2018 … which will take a ton of lithium batteries. Current production isn't up to snuff
column14: by alot. There's a significant shortfall.Like most Elon Musk solutions
column15: Tesla's fix for its battery problem is a large one.5 Stocks to Buy for a Big JanuaryA few years ago
column16: TSLA partnered withPanasonic Corporation (ADR)(OTCMKTS:PCRFY) and started construction on a massive plant in the Nevada desert. The dubbed Gigafactory would design and build the needed batteries to arm itself - and potentially other vehicle makers
column17: electrics firms and others - with the needed batteries to store energy. Over the spring
column18: Musk and TSLA predicted that the facility would be able to crank outnearly 50 gigawatts worth of production by 2018- more than the world currently produces.On Wednesday
column19: Tesla Motors turned on the third of the Gigafactory that is completed and started production of batteries.The Gigafactory Is CriticalThe Gigafactory's launch is a significant moment for TSLA stock
column20: because it will help determine Tesla's ability to survive
column21: and how healthy that survival will look.Without the Gigafactory
column22: Tesla simply can't deliver on its EV production goals. The rest of the world does not make enough batteries
column23: period. Plus
column24: a lack of supply leads to another issue: affordability. The Model 3 is supposed to be an electric car for the masses that takes Tesla Motors from a hobby car for the rich to a staple for your average Joe.But current battery prices are too high to make the $35
column25: 000 vehicle profitable. And despite its cult stock following
column26: Tesla still is a publicly traded company
column27: and TSLA stock holders will increasingly demand profits.By building its batteries in-house
column28: Tesla should be able to drive down costs for the critical component and make the Model 3 a profitable endeavor. One would hope so
column29: considering that TSLA took out around$5 billion in debtto build the facility.Equally as important is TSLA's other plans for the facility. Musk & Co. are planning on building battery packs for energy storage from renewables and other sources. That includes its Powerwall and Powerpack batteries that store energy from its SolarCity and utility customers.This is a double-edged sword.Macy's Inc (M) Stock Plunges on Disastrous     Holiday Sales
column30: Job CutsEven amid a shortfall in batteries
column31: battery prices tanked last year. According toBloomberg's New Energy Finance unit
column32: prices for lithium batteries sank by 22% in 2016 and are estimated to fall by another 15% this year. That's great for Model 3 profits and sales to utility customers
column33: but not great for its actual battery production arm. If Tesla plans on selling its battery packs outside its doors - and it does based on its estimated production size and recent deals - then it needs to find the perfect price in the middle. Not too hot and not too cold.That needs to happen soon
column34: too. The first things rolling off the Gigafactory line are storage batteries
column35: not vehicle packs.This Is Everything to TSLA StockTesla's Gigafactory is a much-needed gamble. Without it
column36: Musk can't achieve his vision of having an integrated clean energy company. Tesla will never be able to sell enough cars cost-effectively
column37: get solar panels on everyone's roofs and provide energy storage for larger utility companies.Obviously
column38: if it can't do that
column39: TSLA stock is sunk. Tesla Motors already had enough mishaps on its own without SolarCity and the Gigafactory weighing it down under certain worse- and worst-case scenarios.Thus
column40: the Gigafactory is a make-or-break strategy in a make-or-break year for Tesla Motors. If Tesla's past is any indication
column41: things won't go perfectly smoothly - but they must go at least somewhat according to plan to keep TSLA from hurtling toward the earth.As of this writing
column42: Aaron Levitt did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Growth Stocks Set to Pop in 2017The 12 Best Fidelity 401k Funds to OwnThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The     Experts' PicksThe postThe Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Gigafactory Is a Make-or-Break Strategyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Options Traders Expect Huge Moves in Tesla (TSLA) Stock;1/5/2017;"Investors in Tesla Motors
column2: Inc.TSLAneed to pay close attention to the stock based on moves in the options market lately. That is because the January 20th
column3: 2017 $50 Put had some of the highest implied volatility of all equity options today.What is Implied Volatility?Implied volatility shows how much movement the market is expecting in the future. Options with high levels of implied volatility suggest that investors in the underlying stocks are expecting a big move in one direction or the other. It could also mean there is an event coming up soon that may cause a big rally or a huge sell off. However
column4: implied volatility is only one piece of the puzzle when putting together anoptions tradingstrategy.What do the Analysts Think?Clearly
column5: options traders are pricing in a big move for Tesla shares
column6: but what is the fundamental picture for the company? Currently
column7: Tesla is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) in the Automotive - Domestic industry that ranks in the Bottom 23% of our Zacks Industry Rank. Over the last 60 days
column8: no analysts have increased their earnings estimates for the current quarter
column9: while one analyst has revised the estimate downward. The net effect has taken our Zacks Consensus Estimate for the current quarter from a loss of 56 cents per share to a loss of 72 cents in that period.Given the way analysts feel about Tesla right now
column10: this huge implied volatility could mean there's a trade developing. Often times
column11: options traders look for options with high levels of implied volatility to sell premium. This is a strategy many seasoned traders use because it captures decay. At expiration
column12: the hope for these traders is that the underlying stock does not move as much as originally expected.Looking to Trade Options?Each week

column1: The Simple Reason I Won't Buy Tesla Motors Stock;1/4/2017;"Tesla CEO Elon Musk. Image source:OnInnovationvia Flickr. Copyright 2010 The Henry Ford. Republished underCC BY-ND 2.0.There is a simple reason I won't buy shares ofTesla Motors Inc.(NASDAQ: TSLA) : I don't trust founder-CEO Elon Musk.Let me explain. It's not that I think Musk is fundamentally   dishonest
column2: but rather that his grand unifying vision for his   company has blinded him to his responsibility to minority   shareholders and to the risks he is asking them to bear. The   Tesla Motorsacquisition-rescueof SolarCity Corp. is all the evidence I need to support that   proposition.makeArticleAd();In a deal with as much potential for conflict of interest as   this one
column3: I think Musk had a personal obligation to spell out the   enormous risks associated with the acquisition in a clear and   forthright manner
column4: instead of letting the lawyers address them in   legalese in the pages of a securities filing. He didn't.A tangled webIf you're reading this article
column5: I assume you're probably   familiar with the conflicts of interest I refer to above
column6: but let   me recap the most obvious ones for those readers who aren't:Musk is the co-founder
column7: chief executive
column8: chairman and     largest shareholder of electric car manufacturer Tesla Motors
column9: with a 20.8% stake.Musk was also the chairman and largest shareholder of solar     power system manufacturer SolarCity.Lyndon Rive
column10: SolarCity's then-CEO and board member
column11: is     Musk's cousin. Rive's co-founder
column12: his brother Peter Rive
column13: was     SolarCity's chief technology officer and a board member.Allow me to draw on one of the lessons that 50 years of   stewardship ofBerkshire Hathawaytaught CEO Warren Buffett. As he wrote in his golden anniversary   annual letter (emphasis mine):Several of my subsequent errors also involved the use of     Berkshire shares to purchase businesses whose earnings were     destined to simply limp along.Mistakes of that kind are deadly... Too often CEOs seem blind to an elementary reality: The     intrinsic value of the shares you give in an acquisition must     not be greater than the intrinsic value of the business you     receive.A losing exchangeTesla gave away 0.11 of its shares for every SolarCity share.   Here is what I think they received in return
column14: in terms of   intrinsic value: zero. That's what I think SolarCity is worth as   a going concern. It isn't profitable
column15: either under GAAP   (generally accepted accounting principles) or on a cash basis.   The most recent estimates have SolarCity recording an accounting   loss of close to a billion dollars in 2017
column16: following an   estimated $925 million loss in 2016.By the end of the third quarter of 2016
column17: SolarCity's cash had   declined to $259 million from $373 million 12 months prior --   despite having issued debt and equity totaling $849 million (net   basis) over that period. Yet Teslatouted as a financial benefitof the acquisition that it ""is expected to be additive to Tesla's   cash balance... We expect SolarCity to add more than half a   billion dollars in cash to Tesla's balance sheet over the next 3   years."" Here's to wishing!Apparently
column18: I'm not the only with genuine skepticism regarding   the equity value Tesla shareholders received in acquiring   SolarCity. In themerger proposalit filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Aug. 31
column19: Tesla revealed thatfifteeninstitutional investors had passed on acquiring SolarCity or even   simply making an equity investment in it
column20: and that the company   was facing a liquidity squeeze. On its most recent financials
column21: the company's Altman Z-score of -0.20 indicated a significant   risk of bankruptcy.""[A] match made in market heaven""With the acquisition by Tesla
column22: SolarCity has found a lifeline   such that financial distress is no longer imminent. However
column23: to   justify the acquisition on any basis other than as a rescue   operation
column24: you have to buy into Musk's vision of the rich   synergies between the two businesses. I don't. As New York   Universityfinance professor and valuation expert Aswath Damodaranwrotein September:I don't think that Tesla's Solar City acquisition passes     [either] the smell test (for conflict of interest) [or] the     common sense test (of creating value)
column25: but I am not a     shareholder in either Tesla or Solar City and I don't get a     vote. When Tesla shareholders vote
column26: given that owning the stock     is by itself an admission that they buy into the Musk vision
column27: I     would not be surprised if they go along with his     recommendations. Tesla shareholders and Elon Musk are a match     made in market heaven and I wish them the best of luck in their     life together.(Note: Tesla shareholders approved the acquisition on Nov. 17
column28: and the deal closed five days later.)Like Damodaran
column29: I'm not a Tesla shareholder. I respect Musk   for his entrepreneurial vision and for what he has achieved
column30: but   there is a fine line between visionary drive in emerging   industries and recklessness. As far as I'm concerned
column31: buying or   holding Tesla Motors shares at this point has more to do with   blind faith than investing.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Tesla Motors wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of Nov. 7

column1: Why Tesla Motors' Guidance Misses Should Concern Investors;1/4/2017;"Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) said that it delivered about 22
column2: 200 vehicles in   the fourth quarter of 2016
column3: a number that left it short of its   own guidance for both the quarter and the full year.It's far from the first time that Tesla has missed its own   guidance
column4: of course. Investors appeared to take this latest   shortfall in stride. But the trend suggests that Tesla might miss   some key deadlines
column5: and that could have much more serious   consequences for the stock.""Short-term production challenges""Tesla's guidance had called for ""just over 25
column6: 000"" deliveries   in the fourth quarter and at least 80
column7: 000 for the full year. But   its fourth-quarter shortfall left its tally for the full year at   76
column8: 230 vehicles delivered to customers.makeArticleAd();Now in its fifth year of production
column9: Tesla's Model S may be   facing declining demand. Image source: Tesla Motors.In a statement late on Tuesday
column10: Tesla said that ""short-term   production challenges starting at the end of October and lasting   through early December"" left it scrambling to make up lost   production late in the quarter.Tesla blamed the ""challenges"" on its transaction to install   new hardware for its Autopilot driver-assist system. The company   said on October 19 that it would begin shipping all of its new   vehicles with thehardware necessary for fully autonomous   driving
column11: allowing it to gradually enable self-driving capabilities in   those cars with software updates over time.Tesla last reaffirmed its fourth-quarter guidance in a   shareholder letter on October 26. Apparently
column12: the ""production   challenges"" started in the days immediately following the   letter.Another in a long list of missed goalsTesla has a long history of missing its own targets
column13: whether   for sales totals
column14: profits
column15: or the timing of key product-related   events. CEO Elon Musk has acknowledged that the company sometimes   falls short
column16: saying that he sets ambitious goals for the company   as a way to motivate employees and suppliers.That may work
column17: but it makes it challenging for investors to   evaluate the company's stated business plans. Musk has said that   Tesla will begin production of its compact Model 3 sedan sometime   in 2017
column18: but many analysts feel that's unlikely.In a note on Tuesday before Tesla announced its delivery   totals
column19: Barclaysauto analyst Brian Johnson said that there's a high probability   that the company won't be able to deliver any Model 3s in   2017.Why Tesla's routine misses could eventually be trouble for   the stockViewed in the context of its past results
column20: Tesla's 2016   delivery total is impressive even if it fell short of Musk's   goal. But it's still far short of the hundreds of thousands -- or   millions -- of annual deliveries that Tesla will need to be a   viable automaker over the long term.Tesla has said that it has nearly 400
column21: 000 preorders for the   Model 3. But more and more big automakers are announcing plans to   bring long-range electric vehicles to market over the next few   years. (Just yesterday
column22: Ford Motor Company(NYSE: F) said that it will begin production of anelectric SUV with 300 miles of rangeby 2020.)If the Model 3 is delayed
column23: which seems likely given Tesla's   history
column24: that could mean that those orders won't be filled until   late 2018 or 2019. How many of those customers will give up and   choose an electric vehicle from a major automaker instead?Tesla had a significant technological advantage over the big   automakers when it first launched the Model S in 2012. But the   risk to Tesla as an investment has always been that the big   automakers might close the electric-vehicle technology gapbefore Tesla can get to sustainable scale
column25: leaving the upstart Silicon Valley automaker in an uphill   battle for market share against better-funded competition.That risk could become reality if the Model 3 is delayed   significantly. Tesla has built a great brand and the Model 3   will find buyers no matter what happens. But the longer it waits
column26: the harder it will be for Tesla to ramp up to the millions of   deliveries a year that it will need to support its current   sky-high valuation.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
