column1: 3 Things You Should Know About the Solar Sector;12/21/2016;"The solar sector can be an enticing and risky space for   investors. There's tremendous growth in the industry andtrillions of dollars in potential revenue
column2: but companies come and go rapidly as the landscape changes.   Before jumping in
column3: here are three things every investor should   keep in mind.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Understand the importance of external policiesSean Williams: One of the most important things to know about solar stocks is   that external policies can have a big impact on the industry.   Three really good examples are OPEC's policies
column4: the EPA's   policies
column5: and U.S. Solar Investment Tax Credit.Solar panel makers thrive when there's both demand and urgency   for their products. This means when fossil fuel prices are high
column6: the urgency for consumers and businesses to switch to solar is   there. When crude andnatural   gas pricesfall
column7: solar panel supply can increase and the urgency to make the   transition to a green energy solution decreases. Over the past   two-plus years
column8: we've witnessed solar panel supply increase and   urgency decline as crude and natural gas have hit multi-year   lows. However
column9: with OPEC recently agreeing to cut production and   crude prices surging on the news
column10: it's possible we could see   demand for solar begin creeping back into the industry.Within the U.S.
column11: policies from the Environmental Protection   Agency can certainly have an impact on the solar industry.   Tougher carbon emission regulations have encouraged utilities to   switch away from coal-fired electrical generation and toward   alternatives
column12: such as cleaner-burning natural gas and   solar-powered systems. Of course
column13: president-elect Donald Trump's   stance that some EPA regulations and oversight should be pulled   back could work against the solar industry in the near-term.Finally
column14: we have the U.S Solar Investment Tax Credit (SITC)
column15: which allows for a 30% dollar-for-dollar tax credit on the cost   of the panels and installation. In late 2015
column16: the SITC was   extended through 2019
column17: providing an impetus for Americans to   invest in home-solar systems. The SITC will begin throttling down   in 2020 before disappearing completely for consumers by 2023.   These subsidies can be a strong tool that encourage or discourage   solar investment.As a solar industry investor you'll need to keep your eyes on   the policies and subsidies that could impact the valuation of the   companies you own.Solar is a big growth industry
column18: but also very cyclicalJasonHall: Today
column19: solar still generates a very small percentage of total   electricity around the world
column20: meaning there's likely to be huge   growth for decades to come. Factor in an expected   one-billion-person expansion of the power-hungry global middle   class over the next couple of decades
column21: and there's a wonderful   growth market for long-term investors to profit from. One has to   look only at power generation in the United States alone to see   the potential:US Primary Energy Productiondata byYCharts.However
column22: investors must also understand the nature of the   solar industry's likely growth to have the best chance at   profiting. The best way to understand solar panel manufacturing   is that it's a wonderful long-term growth industry
column23: but it will   also be highly cyclical from year to year
column24: with ups-and-downs in   the short-term even as long-term demand increases. This is   particularly true in the utility and commercial/industrial   segments
column25: where the amount spent on large
column26: expensive projects can   shift dramatically up or down from year to year.At the same time

column28: expensive
column29: and largely a cost-driven
column30: commodity business. This   makes operating leverage critically important
column31: and any solar   manufacturer that's unable to respond to shifts in demand before   the market shifts can swing from solid profits to steep losses   very quickly.For this reason

column38: and   California are impacting the industry on a local level.That's why having a flexible business model is really key to   solar companies. Manufacturers need to be able to move supply to   where it's needed all around the globe

column40: and finance   companies need to be flexible in the products they offer.One example of a company handling this well isSunPower Corp(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column41: the high efficiency solar panel manufacturer.   The company sells solar panels into nearly every major solar   market
column42: so when Germany was a big installer it had a presence   there and now that China is growing it has solutions there.   SunPower can also go big or small
column43: providing solutions for   rooftop solar customers and utilities looking for massive power   plants. This doesn't guarantee success
column44: but it allows a   flexibility to change the business as market conditions   necessitate.Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) subsidiary SolarCity has been on the opposite end   of the spectrum. The company is almost completely focused in the   U.S. and has tied itself to the lease/power purchase agreement   finance model. When states like Nevada change policy the company   has to lay off workers and shut down operations. And when   customers started demanding loans this year the company had   trouble adapting

column1: Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Institutes ‘Supercharger Idle Fee’;12/19/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) doesn't want customer hogging its superchargers.Source: ©iStock.com/ChenRobertTo stop customers from leaving their cars parked at supercharging stations
column3: Tesla Motors Inc is introducing a supercharger idle fee. This fee will charge customers 40 cents for each minute they leave their cars at the stations once charging is complete.makeArticleAd();The supercharger idle fee isn't designed to make Tesla Motors Inc any money. Instead
column4: the company claims that it just wants to make sure that the superchargers are available to those that really need them. Ablog postfrom TSLA compared leaving a charged car at a supercharging station to sitting at a gas pump once fueling is complete.Tesla Motors Inc is hoping to help customers avoid the supercharging idle fee in a couple of ways. The first involves its app. The app will notify customers when their car is almost charged
column5: and again once it is fully charged. The second way is waiving fees for customers that move their vehicles away from the stations within 5 minutes of reaching full charge.Tesla Motors Inc also says it hopes to avoid this process completely in the future. The company has an interest in creating vehicles that can someday drive themselves away from the supercharging stations once they have a full charge.Tesla Motors Inc announced last month that it plans tobring an end to free supercharging. This change will go into effect on Jan. 1
column6: 2017. It will only apply to customers that buy their cars after this date. However
column7: these customers will still get 400 kWh of free supercharging credits each year.More From InvestorPlaceThe 7 WORST Stocks to Buy for 201710 Dangerous High-Yield Dividend Stocks to     Avoid5 Stocks to Buy for DecemberThe postTesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Institutes 'Supercharger Idle Fee'appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: It’s Energy Storage's Time to Shine;12/18/2016;"Power storage has been a major topic of discussion within   energy industry circles
column2: particularly in connection with   renewable energy
column3: as technological advances appear poised to   bring with them a new level of innovation. Affordable storage   would allow for more renewable power sources on the grid
column4: create   a path for customers to leave the grid
column5: and even allow for new   innovations around dynamic loads in energy.The inconvenient truth is that until recently
column6: energy storage   didn't have any financial justification. Theideaof value was there
column7: but there was no actual value to create.   Rooftop solar power systems create energy and can offset demand   from other sources. The best energy storage systems can do is   move demand from one hour of the day to another
column8: but doing that   was so expensive
column9: it didn't make financial sense.What's changed recently is that utilities are starting to put   rate structures in place that will make energy storage more   economically viable. Ironically
column10: their moves -- designed to   reduce the appeal of solar -- are providing the impetus for   innovation in the energy storage industry.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Where storage is hitting the grid todayThe initial uses of energy storage systems have been primarily   in commercial buildings and utility applications. A commercial   building can use storage to reduce demand charges -- fees based   on the peak consumption in a building every month. And utilities   are running pilot programs and even using stored power to patch   holes in the grid
column11: as Southern California Edison did earlier this   year when it couldn't provide enough peak power to customers   after the Aliso Canyon natural gas leak.Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) swooped in and quickly built an 80 MWh energy   storage system to fill the gap.These are important applications
column12: but they're also just the   tip of the iceberg. As costs fall and technology improves
column13: we'll   see energy storage play a bigger role across the country.GTM Research estimates that 260 MW of energy storage will be   built in the U.S. in 2016
column14: but that figure will jump to 478 MW in   2017 and 2
column15: 045 MW by 2021.Image source:GTM Research.Developers are just starting to scratch the surface of energy   storage's potential.What the future of storage looks likeThe economics of energy storage start to make sense as the   price of batteries come down. And that's when we'll see greater   adoption.In residential solar
column16: customers will be able to use storage   systems to consume more of the energy generated directly from   their rooftop systems
column17: rather than selling it back to utilities.   This was the intention of Tesla's Powerwall
column18: and withSan Diego Gas & ElectricandPacific Gas & Electric-- two of the largest utilities in California -- transitioning   from traditional net metering to the time of use rates in Net   Metering 2.0
column19: there will be more value to be extracted from good   storage systems.Sunrun(NASDAQ: RUN) andSunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR) are also bringing their own storage solutions to   homeowners
column20: so look for the adoption of residential energy   storage to grow tremendously in 2017.Commercial energy storage will continue to be driven by   demand-charge reductions
column21: but we could see more energy storage   systems installed for self-consumption as well.The segment to watch in 2017 is really utility scale storage.   We will likely see large batteries distributed throughout the   grid
column22: capable of relieving pressure on the grid locally. I also   expect energy storage will begin being included in renewable   energy bids in the future. The large concentration of solar in   California has already led to a power consumption pattern that   has been dubbedthe duck curve: Demand on the grid drops off during day
column23: followed by a large   increase as the sun goes down (taking solar out of the equation)   and most people get home from work. Energy storage systems built   in conjunction with renewable energy plants can help make the   duck curve less dramatic for the grid.Energy storage may start turning a new leafThe energy storage industry is in a similar position to where   solar was in 2010. column1: Microsoft: Trump's Trade War Could End Badly;12/18/2016;"ByBlue Harbinger:Despite bygones
column2: tech leaders and president elect Trump struck a friendly chord at this past Wednesday's Tech Summit held at the Trump Tower in New York. However
column3: gleaning potential policies from the topics discussed (and Trump's campaign rhetoric) could spell trouble for several of the Tech Summit attendees
column4: Microsoft (MSFT) in particular.This article provides a brief review of Microsoft's evolving business
column5: several valuation metrics worth considering
column6: and an overview of the potential impacts (positive and negative) of new policies that may come out of the Trump Administration such as those that would artificially create more US tech jobs
column7: lower corporate tax rates
column8: pressure interest rates higher
column9: allow overseas cash repatriation
column10: and utilize punitive tariffs with international trading partners.OverviewmakeArticleAd();Microsoft's business consists of three segments: Productivity and Business Processes (consists of Office and Dynamics)
column11: Intelligent Cloud (consists of public
column12: private and hybrid server products and cloud services
column13: includes Azure)
column14: and More Personal Computing (consists of Windows
column15: devices
column16: gaming
column17: search advertising
column18: Bing and eventually LinkedIn). And for reference
column19: the following charts show the revenue and operating margin breakdown and growth trajectory of each segment.(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(click to enlarge)(source: MSFTearnings slides)More Personal Computing is the biggest in terms of revenues
column20: but has lower margins and is therefore the laggard in terms of operating income. And with regards to revenue growth
column21: More Personal Computing (-1%) is also the laggard versus the other segments (+8% and +10%) on a year-over-year basis as shown in the following table.(click to enlarge)(source: MSFTearnings slides)With regards to Cloud
column22: Microsoft seems to be the number two player (behind Amazon Web Services) in an extremely competitive space. Notwithstanding any mistakes
column23: Cloud should provide Microsoft continued growth. Additionally
column24: Microsoft's Productivity and Business Process Application provide some strong advantages and barriers to entry versus peers
column25: as does the Windows operating system.For more perspective
column26: the following graph shows how Microsoft's Windows for PCs is becoming a smaller part of Microsoft's revenue
column27: and server products and tools are accelerating.And from a bottom line standpoint
column28: Microsoft's net income remains healthy as revenues remain strong
column29: as shown in the following chart.(click to enlarge)Additionally
column30: Microsoft has provided a positive outlook whereby revenue in two of its three segments is expected to grow (Productivity and Business Processes plus Intelligent Cloud
column31: but not More Personal Computing).(click to enlarge)Valuation MetricsFrom a price-to-earnings standpoint
column32: Microsoft remains reasonably priced as shown in the following chart (taking the tech bubble era with a grain of salt).(click to enlarge)Additionally
column33: a basic discounted free cash flow model suggests Microsoft has some price appreciation potential. Specifically
column34: if we discount Microsoft's 2016Free Cash Flowof $25 billion
column35: by its 11.85% weighted averagecostof capital and assume a 9.1% 5-year annual growth rate (this is the average estimate of the 8 professionalanalystssurveyed on Yahoo Finance)
column36: and a conservative 3-5% growth rate thereafter
column37: then Microsoft is worth $465.0B to $580.4B after adjusting for outstanding long-term debt (-$60.2B) and cash and short-term investments (+$136.9B). On a per share basis
column38: this amounts to a valuation between $59.76 and $74.61
column39: which gives Microsoft current share price roughly 8% upside versus the midpoint of the range.Worth noting
column40: Microsoft pays a healthy dividend. The dividend yield currently sits at around 2.4% (as shown in the following chart) which is above average for Microsoft and above average for an S&P 500 company
column41: particularly one in the technology sector.(click to enlarge)A higher than average dividend yield from a blue chip company like Microsoft can be a signal from management that they believe their stock price should be higher (which would mathematically bring the dividend yield closer to the historical norm
column42: ceteris paribus). Worth noting
column43: Microsoft's dividend payments are well covered as shown in the following chart.(click to enlarge)In essence
column44: Microsoft is a stable company with an above average dividend and the potential for more growth and share price appreciation.New Administration PoliciesIt is worth considering the potential policy changes (and their impact on Microsoft) that might come out of the Trump Administration following this past week's ""Tech Summit"" (attended by Alphabet (GOOGL) CEO Larry Page
column45: Tesla (TSLA) and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk
column46: Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook
column47: Facebook (FB) COO Sheryl Sandberg
column48: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella
column49: Cisco (CSCO) CEO Chuck Robbins
column50: IBM (IBM) CEO Ginni Rometty
column51: Intel (INTC) CEO Brian Krzanich
column52: Oracle (ORCL) CEO Safra Catz
column53: and Amazon (AMZN) CEO Jeff Bezos
column54: to name a few).Specifically
column55: we consider policies that may artificially create more US tech jobs
column56: lower corporate tax rates
column57: pressure interest rates higher
column58: allow overseas cash repatriation
column59: and utilize punitive tariffs.1. More US JobsFor starters
column60: one of Trump's biggest themes is US jobs creation. However
column61: the types of jobs he's talking about (middle class manufacturing jobs) aren't going to help Microsoft
column62: and his views on highly skilled international workers may actually harm Microsoft significantly. For example
column63: Trump has been critical of H1B visas
column64: claiming they take jobs away from Americans. In our view
column65: H1B jobs help Microsoft attract the talent it needs to remain successful. Forexample…""Microsoft is an outspoken opponent of the cap on H1B visas
column66: which allow companies in the U.S. to employ certain foreign   workers. Bill Gates claims the cap on H1B visas makes it   difficult to hire employees for the company
column67: stating ""I'd   certainly get rid of the H1B cap."" Critics of H1B visas argue   that relaxing the limits would result in increased unemployment   for U.S. citizens due to H1B workers working for lower   salaries.""Additionally
column68: Trump may attempt to force more manufacturing jobs into the US
column69: rather than allowing US companies to trade more freely with international partners (for example
column70: Trump wants to see Apple's iPhone manufactured in the US
column71: despite daunting economical headwinds). Generally speaking
column72: international trade can increase productivity and efficiency by allowing each partner to focus on what they're best at
column73: and then allowing trade so each partner can obtain what it needs. Policies restricting international trade could particularly impact Microsoft considering ""as of June 30
column79: 000 internationally; and also according to Microsoft ""Our international operations provide a significant portion of our total revenue…"") (2016 Microsoft Annual Report). Overall
column80: Trump may be able to create some new US jobs with his pro-growth agenda
column81: but if he restricts free trade and H1B visas he could significantly hurt Microsoft in particular.2. Lowering Corporate Tax RatesWith regards to lowering corporate tax rates (another one of Trump's consistent themes)
column82: this is a no-brainer (in a good way) for US business
column83: but it may help Microsoft less than some of its peers given its already relatively low effective tax rate as shown in the following chart.(click to enlarge)The theory is that by lowering taxes on corporations
column84: it will make them more competitive internationally. It will also
column86: prevent companies from relocating to other countries with lower tax rates and taking away US jobs when they relocate. However
column88: Microsoft already has a lower effective tax rate than many of its peers. Lower corporate tax rates could help Microsoft on the margin
column89: but competitively less so than its peers. Arguably
column90: Trump could spur the overall economy by lowering tax rates across all market sectors which would eventually trickle down to Microsoft
column91: but in the immediate term a lower corporate tax policy is likely to help Microsoft less than other companies.3. Raising Interest RatesThe Fed sets interest rates
column93: but Trump's aggressive growth agenda could speed up the economy resulting in the Fed acting sooner to raise rates faster and this could actually help Microsoft given its large cash balance that currently earns very low interest (i.e. higher interest rates mean Microsoft could earn a higher rate of return on its cash). And granted
column94: much of the $137 billion in cash on Microsoft's balance sheet is overseas
column95: but in theory the US can lead interest rates around the world higher if it's successfully able to accelerate growth.4. Repatriating Non-US CashAs the following chart shows
column96: Microsoft has a very large amount of foreign cash. And given the currently high tax rates to repatriate this cash
column97: companies aren't doing it.If the Trump Administration were to orchestrate a tax deal whereby companies could pay less tax
column98: then they'd likely be willing to bring that cash back to the US. This would be a ""win-win"" in the sense that the lower tax rate would allow companies to bring the cash back to the US and create more US growth and US profits
column99: while still allowing the government to collect some revenue from the lower taxation rate on the repatriation. This is a potential Trump policy that actually makes sense and could benefit Microsoft.5. International TradeDonald Trump has expressed a combative attitude towards international trading partners. For example
column100: he is not happy with China
column102: he wants to:""...label China a currency manipulator.""""…bring trade cases against China
column103: both in this country and   at the WTO. China's unfair subsidy behavior is prohibited by the   terms of its entrance to the WTO.""""Use every lawful presidential power to remedy trade disputes   if China does not stop its illegal activities
column104: including its   theft of American trade secrets - including the application of   tariffs consistent with Section 201 and 301 of the Trade Act of   1974 and Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962.""However
column105: if Trump starts a trade war with China
column106: China has the ability (and a track record) to inflict pain on US companies. For example
column108: China openly allowed pirated copies of Microsoft Windows to be sold in most big cities for only around $1 (clearly this was not good for Microsoft). And it would be easy for China to allow similar cases going forward if Trump takes any aggressive actions. As another example
column109: China is already flooding US markets with too much steel and aluminum which is keeping prices artificially low and hurting US producers. As yet another example
column110: China has a reputation for manipulating its currency thereby making its exports very inexpensive.If Trump starts a trade war with China (he did threaten a 45% tariff during his campaign)
column111: or any other country for that matter
column112: it could end badly for all US companies
column113: especially those with significant non-US business
column116: and international operations provide a significant portion of Microsoft's total revenue).ConclusionThings could end badly for a lot of tech companies
column118: if the new administration follows through on some of its aggressive policy ideas
column119: particularly with regards to international trade. However
column121: we've still ranked Microsoft #7 on our list of top7 Tech Stocks Worth Consideringbecause we suspect cooler minds will prevail
column122: thereby making Microsoft attractive because of its strong evolving business
column124: and relatively attractive valuation.See alsoThe Market Simply Can't Go Much Higheron seekingalpha.com"

column1: Should Automakers Fear a Trump Presidency?;12/16/2016;"The U.S. auto industry has been experiencing a bull run for the last few years. Sales in 2016 are likely to be 17.5 million autos

President-elect Donald Trump's policies on imports and economic relations with other countries are expected to impact the industry significantly.One China PolicyThe U.S. auto industry may face challenges in the world's second largest economy due to political reasons. Trump's out-of-protocol decision to acknowledge communication from the President of Taiwan goes against the ""One China Policy"". This may hurt the U.S.-China trade relations. Trump asserted that the U.S. is not bound by the policy that categorizes Taiwan under ""one China"". This is likely to impact the friendly relations that have lasted for decades.While China is not expected to create any military pressure on the U.S.

column1: Why Elon Musk's Inclusion in Trump's Tech Summit Matters;12/16/2016;"Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA) and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk and President-elect   Donald Trump don't exactly see eye to eye. column1: Trump Team: Twitter Inc Too Small for Tech Invite (TWTR);12/16/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsTwitter Inc(TWTR) - DonaldTrump's favorite communication tool - is said to have played an   important role in his victory
column3: but surprisingly
column4: the   President-elect left Twitter off the invitation list for a   meeting of technology company executives on Wednesday.A spokesman for Trump's transition team toldReuters
column5: ""They weren't invited because they aren't big enough.""makeArticleAd();Twitter's Exclusion a SurpriseTwitter has a market cap of $13.85 billion. This makes it much   smaller thanFacebook Inc(FB) andAmazon.com
column6: Inc.(AMZN)
column7: both of which were invited to the New York meeting.Tesla Motors Inc(TSLA)
column8: with a marketcapitalizationof $31.92 billion
column9: was the smallest company in attendance
column10: notesFortune.Trump made prolific use of Twitter's platform throughout his   election campaign. Also the company actively participated in   high-profile discussions on policy issues such as cyber-security   and the spread of violent online propaganda. Trump was able to   reach out to millions of voters and speak his mind to them   because of Twitter. He leveraged his sizable following on the   platform to circumvent traditional media to speak directly to the   public and to bash his opponents.During the meetings held to address technology concerns under   the Obama administration
column11: Twitter was a regular participant   and an important one
column12: considering its rampant use by terrorist   groups such as the Islamic State.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017Therefore
column13: Twitter's omission from the meeting is very   surprising.Why Twitter wasReallyOmittedTwitter rejected an advertising deal with Trump's campaign in   October.Fortune
column14: citing a source familiar with Trump's relationship with   Twitter
column15: said the company had to bear the brunt of it in the form   of CEO Jack Dorsey not being invited for the meeting.In the fall
column16: the micro-blogging company received a proposal   from the Trump Campaign and Republican National Committee (RNC)   to spend $5 million on campaign advertising. The agreement   required the company to provide custom emojis
column17: or icons that   appear with a certain phrase
column18: for certain hashtags.Initially
column19: the company approved anemojifor the hashtag #crookedhillary that showed a running stick   figure holding a moneybag. Later
column20: the company objected to it
column21: notesCBS News. To turn things favorable
column22: Twitter offered a discount on   ads and a chance to redesign the emoji.However
column23: the new design (a moneybag with wings) also faced   objection from Dorsey on October 7.The 7 Best Tech Stocks in the World""We believe that political advertising merits a level of   disclosure and transparency that branded political emojis do not   meet
column24: and we ultimately decided not to permit this particular   format for any political advertising
column25: the company said at the   time.The postTwitter Inc Is Too Small To Get Invited To Tech   Meeting: Trump Teamappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We     believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief     that value investing can outperform the market
column26: hence the name     ""ValueWalk."" column1: Readers’ Choice: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Will Be 2017’s Best Stock;12/16/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsEditor's note: This column is part of our Best Stocks for     2017 contest. The public pick for the contest isAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).This year as we complied our expert picks for theBest Stocks of 2017
column5: we also wanted to hear from you
column6: the reader. Our poll was   close for a while
column7: with companies likeTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column8: Bank of America Corp(NYSE:BAC) andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) - whichLouis Navellier picked as his top stock for the   year- all in the running.makeArticleAd();But in the end
column9: as it so often does
column10: Amazon.com
column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) took the lead.There are a multitude of drivers that brought Amazon to the   point it's at. Everyone knows about the broad strokes that have   led to AMZN stock returning nearly 1
column12: 800% in the past 10 years
column13: trumping theS&P 500by 1
column14: 700 percentage points!And based on our poll
column15: a lot of people think Amazon is going   to continue that outperformance through 2017.Looking at what AMZN stock has in store
column16: it's hard to argue   the point.Amazon has built a solid foundation with its core e-commerce   business. It has built a profit center out of its Amazon Web   Services cloud offerings. And AMZN - always willing to try new   things - is pressing forward with its Amazon Go brick-and-mortar   stores
column17: among other initiatives.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017Now
column18: we'll see if Amazon can press past our 10 expert picks in   theBest Stocks for 2017contest.Amazon Keeps InnovatingSo
column19: what's new?Amazon wants people to add grocery shopping to the long list   of things that are now easier thanks to the power of apps withAmazon Go. The idea is you scan theapp on your phone
column20: then grab what you need and go … no fuss
column21: no muss.Analysts differ as to how big an impact Amazon Go will have
column22: but there's no denying that it's emblematic of what has made   Amazon such a good company for so long. AMZN stock keeps finding   new ways to streamline the process of commerce.In other words
column23: it keeps finding new ways to make it easier   for you to buy things from Amazon.Speaking of which
column24: there's Amazon Prime … which also makes it   easier to buy things from Amazon
column25: but that the company has used   to expand its reach into your household. While plenty of people   pick it up for the shipping deals
column26: it has also been growing its   video offerings in an attempt to usurp streaming kingNetflix
column27: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX).In fact
column28: near the end of 2016
column29: Amazon Prime Video reached out   to a total of 242 countries
column30: with a late
column31: low-cost push.Amazon is poised to start taking on the leader in the space
column32: not only through ubiquity but through quality.After all
column33: Amazon justsnuck past Netflixin number of Golden Globe nominees received. Stellar original   programming is not solely Netflix's purview anymore
column34: and people   are taking note.Then there's Amazon Web Services.Synergy Research estimatesthat AWS' market share for infrastructure as a service (IaaS) is   approaching 50%
column35: and it holds a sizeable but smaller lead in   platform as a service (PaaS). And independent of its rivals
column36: AWS   is simply growing by leaps and bounds. AWS revenue skyrocketed   58% year-over-year in the second quarter
column37: and followed that up   with 55% growth in Q3.The 10 Best Index Funds to Buy for 2017
column39: 2019 …Speaking of growth
column40: analysts see revenue growth of over 20%   both next quarter and next year. Earnings are likewise expected   to see some major increases - 37% in the current quarter and a   whopping 62% in the first quarter of next year.Would that be enough to take first place in theBest Stocks of 2017contest?At the least
column41: readers are pretty confident that we   haven't seen everything that AMZN stock has to show us for the   coming year yet.As of this writing

column1: 2 Risks Qualcomm Will Face After Acquiring NXP Semiconductors;12/16/2016;"Qualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) seems to have opened the door to automotive riches   with its pending acquisition ofNXP Semiconductors(NASDAQ: NXPI) . NXPcurrently holds14.5% share in the automotive semiconductor market
column2: which is   expected to be worth $36 billion by 2019
column3: and Qualcomm is buying   the lead in this fast-growing market with its pending $47 billion   purchase of NXP.However
column4: Qualcomm's NXP acquisition does not ensure that the   former will become the dominant player in the automotive   semiconductor business
column5: as it will face a stiff challenge fromInfineon Technologies(NASDAQOTH: IFNNY) . Additionally
column6: Qualcomm might face   integration and margin challenges once the merger is   complete.makeArticleAd();Why Infineon could pose a strong challengeInfineon Technologies is the second-largest supplier of chips   to the automotive industry with an estimated market share of   10.4% to NXP's 14.5%. This means that Infineon does not lag NXP   by a huge margin. What's more
column8: Infineon led NXP in two   of the three subsegments in the automotive semiconductor   market.Image source: Infineon Technologies.Infineon led NXP in the market for power and sensor chips in   the automotive industry last year. These two markets were worth   $11.3 billion. In comparison
column9: NXP led Infineon by a huge margin   in the microcontroller segment
column10: which was alone worth $6.5   billion.In the long run
column11: Infineon can close the gap on NXP as it is   the leading supplier of drivetrain solutions to electric   vehicles. Infineon supplied its drivetrain solutions to seven of   the top 10 electric vehicles in terms of sales last year. It   counts the likes ofTesla Motors
column12: BMW
column13: Chevrolet
column14: Volkswagen
column15: and BYD Tang as its customers. This puts Infineon in a strong   position in this market as it projects that sales of electric   vehicles will grow from just 400
column16: 000 units in 2015 to 10 million   units in 2025.Along with pending growth in the number of electric vehicles   -- which accounted for less than 1% of market share in 2015 --   the amount of semiconductor content is also expected to grow.   Infineon forecasts that the semiconductor bill of materials in an   EV will be as much as $705 per vehicle by 2025. In comparison
column17: the chip content in each vehicle last year was $332
column18: according to   NXP.EVs will carry higher chip content as compared to   internal-combustion-engine-based vehicles becausethe electric drivetrain used in EVs contains a lot of electronics   for power switching. The electronic systems in a hybrid   drivetrain route power from the battery to the motor through an   inverter
column19: while no such electronic systems are needed in an   internal-combustion engine.According to McKinsey
column20: the average hybrid drivetrain contains   10 times the semiconductor content as compared to an   internal-combustion drivetrain. As a result
column21: the demand for   insulated-gate bipolar transistors
column22: or IGBTs
column23: will continue   increasing as they play an important role in EV power   systems.Infineon enjoys a strong position in the IGBT market with a   market share of 27.6%. In 2015
column24: the IGBT market was worth $3.94   billion
column25: according to Infineon
column26: and some estimates put it at $6   billion in revenue by 2018.So
column27: Infineon could bridge the market share gap over NXP in the   long run on the back of EV growth.Integration challengesQualcomm's acquisition of NXP will have a negative margin   impact on the former. This is because Qualcomm's gross margin   profile is higher than that of NXP. For example
column28: in the recently   reported third quarter
column29: NXP posted a non-GAAP gross margin of   50.5%. In comparison
column30: Qualcomm's gross profit margin in the third   quarter stood at 58% .Thus
column31: as Qualcomm begins to integrate NXP after the merger is   complete in 2017
column32: the gross margin might start deteriorating. The   higher gross margin profile of Qualcomm is a result of its   fabless manufacturing model as it outsources its chip   manufacturing to foundries such asSamsung.On the other hand
column33: NXP has a foundry-based business model. It   has 14 chip manufacturing facilities
column34: along with seven packaging   and testing facilities. However
column35: these facilities can't   manufacture chips for Qualcomm as they are ""outdated
column36: according   toMarket Realist. This reduces one potential synergy from the acquisition.Despite this hiccup
column37: the NXP acquisition is expected to   deliver $500 million in annual cost synergies for Qualcomm within   two years after the closure of the transaction. However
column38: 65% of   the savings will be on the operating expense side as Qualcomm   will be able to use NXP's existing relationships to sell its   automotive and Internet of Things products.Qualcomm will also reduce its cost of goods sold as the   combined companies can negotiate for lower raw material prices   from suppliers. The reduction in the cost of goods sold will   account for 35% of the cost-saving synergy from the acquisition.   The reason the cost of goods sold synergies will be significantly   lower than the operating expense reduction is because Qualcomm   will not make much gains on the manufacturing side of the   business due to the difference in the foundry business.Also
column39: given the legacy nature of the foundries
column40: it is likely   that NXP won't be getting Qualcomm's money to upgrade them. This   is because Qualcomm has a different business model of outsourcing   its manufacturing
column41: and investing in NXP's foundries would lead to   an increase in costs.Although NXP will definitely add another dimension to   Qualcomm's business
column42: we've seen that it will also have a negative   gross margin impact and pose integration issues. Additionally
column43: the threat from Infineon cannot be ignored.So even though Qualcomm is making a smart move by acquiring   NXP Semiconductors
column44: it is not guaranteed a smooth journey toward   automotive riches.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column45: it can pay to listen. After all
column46: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column47: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column48: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of   them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of Nov. 7

column1: Why Tesla Motors Inc (TSLA) Stock Is on My Buy Radar;12/16/2016;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsShares ofTesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA)
column3: while still lower by close to 18% year-to-date
column4: have shown   good absolute and relative strength over the past week and a   half. Although still not out of the woods just yet
column5: TSLA stock is   increasingly coiling up for a potentially better move to the   upside.Earlier this week
column6: I met with a few client investors. Among other   things
column7: we discussed the importance of exercising patience in   trading and investing. Tesla stock was one of the example stocks   I discussed because although TSLA is beginning to look more   technically sound for a next leg higher
column8: it has been a painful   equity for impatient traders expecting explosive moves (in either   direction).makeArticleAd();One of the best lessons I ever received from a former trading   mentor was that sometimes there are simply no   high-probability trades to be had in any given stock or index
column9: for an extended period of time. Patience is a virtue both in life   and in trading. The best traders I have met throughout my career   have an uncanny ability to simply sit on their hands until the   best probability trade flashes. Specifically
column10: they let the   stock price come to them (i.e.
column11: to their price levels of interest   where they see a good risk/reward equation).They don't chase
column12: and that would be my advice on TSLA   stock.TSLA Stock ChartsWith that in mind
column13: on Tesla's multiyear weekly chart
column14: note   that since early 2014
column15: shares have largely been stuck in a   sideways (albeit sometimes volatile) trading range. TSLA has seen   some over- and under-shooting of this range here and there.But in the bigger picture
column16: the stock is stuck in a wide   trading range where dips were to be bought and rallies to be   sold.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017Over the past month or so
column17: TSLA stock has once again found   support at the lower end of the trading range
column18: which currently   also coincides with the red 200-week simple moving average. From   a momentum perspective
column19: we see at the bottom of the chart that   the blue Relative Strength Index (RSI) indicator is slowly   starting to turn higher as well.Click to EnlargeWhile this all looks more promising
column20: it's no cigar just yer. I   still need to see a better and stronger bullish reversal off the   horizontal support area around $185.When I last discussed Tesla stock onNov. 28
column21: I highlighted the very early stages of selling exhaustion   and said that less risk-averse active investors could consider   taking initial long positions in the stock against the $180 area   as a stop-loss.So far
column22: this support area is holding
column23: and TSLA shares   have seen a new rally with a marginal high against the late   November highs.On the daily chart
column24: we see that over the past couple of   trading days
column25: Tesla Motors attempted to break past diagonal   resistance from the April highs. While the MACD oscillator at the   bottom of the chart is also slowly curling higher
column26: shares still   are trading below their blue 100-day SMA.Click to EnlargeAs a general rule
column27: better odds of trading stocks from the long   side occur when a stock is trading above both its yellow 50-day   and the blue 100-day SMAs
column28: and those moving averages are   sloping higher. So far
column29: both moving averages are still   sloping lower.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Great Short       Right NowThat said
column30: the less conservative trader could still consider   playing TSLA stock from the long side at these levels
column31: using the   $215 area as a next upside target over the next few weeks.Any strong bearish reversal from here should act as a   stop-loss signal.Like what you see? column1: Why Electric-Car Fans Should Watch Lucid Motors Closely;12/15/2016;"Electric-car start-up Lucid Motors unveiled its first product   in a media event in California on Wednesday. Lucid's Air is a   sleek high-performance sedan that will have specifications and   pricing calibrated to compete directly withTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) .This is significant
column2: and investors interested in electric and   self-driving cars should sit up and take note. The Lucid Air is   no flight of designer fancy. It's a serious product
column3: and Lucid is   a serious company that stands an excellent chance of succeeding.   Read on.makeArticleAd();The Lucid Air is an electric luxury sports sedan that promises   long range
column4: thrilling performance
column5: and advanced self-driving   capabilities. Image source: Lucid Motors.About the carThe Lucid Air is a big luxury sedan that promises to combine   extreme high performance with a roomy
column6: comfortable
column7: and quiet   interior equipped with a lot of advanced technology.Like the top Tesla models
column8: the Lucid Air should be very fast
column9: at least in a straight line. It might be even faster: Lucid   claims ""best-in-class energy density"" for the Air's 100   kilowatt-hour battery pack
column10: which it says will give the Air ""in   excess"" of 300 miles of range.Once the Air is in production
column11: a 130 kWh battery pack will be   available as an optional upgrade. That will offer ""up to"" 400   miles of range and ""up to"" 1
column12: 000 horsepower. Both figures are a   step ahead of what Tesla's current top-performing models can   deliver right now.Image source: Lucid Motors.Lucid's battery packs will use a new lithium-ion battery cell   developed by the Samsung SDI unit ofSamsung Electronics(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) that promises ""breakthrough battery life
column13: according to Lucid's chief technology officer
column14: Peter   Rawlinson.The Air's motor and transmission unit was developed entirely   in-house
column15: Lucid said. It claims that it's ""smaller
column16: more   efficient and more power-dense than competitors
column17: while   potentially more reliable."" (The word ""potentially"" is doing a   lot of work in that sentence. But as we'll see
column18: Lucid's engineers   are not new to the car business.)Inside
column19: Lucid promises ""executive seating"" with cushy
column20: reclining rear seats that offer comfort and legroom comparable to   first-class airline seats. A 29-speaker audio system will provide   active noise cancellation to ensure that it's a quiet space.As you'd expect from a Silicon Valley automaker
column21: self-driving   technology will be built in. Lucid will aim to have the Air   equipped with ""Level 4"" self-driving capability at launch
column22: pending approval by U.S. regulators. ""Level 4"" systems can take   full control of the vehicle under most (but not all) conditions
column23: with little to no involvement from the human driver.The Lucid Air's back seat is scaled for adult comfort. Image   source: Lucid Motors.Lucid hasn't finalized pricing for the Air. But it said that a   fully loaded ""launch edition"" will be priced around $160
column25: with standard versions starting around $85
column26: 000. Lucid hopes to   get the starting price down to around $65
column27: 000 in time.If all goes according to plan
column28: production of the Air will   begin in late 2018. But some big things have to happen in order   for that plan to pan out.Is this vaporware
column29: or is it for real?It's for real. This is not vaporware. It could turn out to be   a big deal. But there are some caveats that come with that   statement.For starters
column30: Lucid is a real company
column31: founded in 2007. It has   about 330 employees
column32: many with past experience at Tesla or at   large global automakers. Its chief designer
column33: Derek Jenkins
column34: was   formerly the director of design atMazdaNorth America. And Peter Rawlinson
column35: the chief technology   officer
column36: came to Lucid with one of the greatest electric-car   resume credentials possible: He was chief engineer on the Tesla   Model S.In some ways
column37: the Lucid Air can be thought of as the Model S   2.0. It's averyserious
column38: advanced design that reads in many ways as a redesigned   Model S informed by experience. And it's clearly very close to   production-ready. It's not a show car.The shape of the Air's roof allows plenty of rear-seat   headroom. Image source: Lucid Motors.But that's where the caveats come in: Right now
column39: Lucid doesn't   have a factory in which to build the Air or anything else.It has a site for a factory
column40: in Casa Grande
column41: Arizona
column42: selected   for its proximity to key auto-industry suppliers in Mexico. It   has a package of subsidies promised by the Arizona state   government
column43: and a detailed plan to start constructing the $700   million facility in the second quarter of 2017.But it will need to raise money to make the factory a fully   functional operation. Lucid has said that future fundraising   rounds are planned

column7: but the reported GAAP number was just 80 cents per share. What looked like a miss on expectations turned out to be a beat. Adobe has now beaten earnings estimates for 12 consecutive quarters.Net income for the quarter came in at $399.613 million
column8: onrevenue of $1.608 billion.While Adobe pays no dividend

column11: as after-hours trading went on

A few of those who enjoyed the ride decided to take profits.Adobe Stock: A Bargain Measured in MinutesThe initial negative reaction in ADBE shares caused analysts to call the numbers a good opportunity to buy the stock
column13: which is up 15% over the last year and 275% over the last five years.As I wrote in previewing the numbers

column15: selling more of its graphics and marketing software via subscription instead of through physical media.All segments of the company showed growth. About two-thirds of revenue comes from digital media tools
column16: and 30% from marketing

column18: The Cloud

column20: past use of the software almost guarantees renewals
column21: and costs for maintaining files on cloud goes down over time.Adobe entered the cloud era with a big lead in creative software
column22: and has used its advantages to grow in marketing software. The one revenue problem remains the ""document cloud
column23: essentially a storage service
column24: where revenue is stagnant as customers take advantage of cloud economics.Still to come is revenuefrom Sensei- a set of intelligent services announced last month that are being built into its cloud platforms that can help marketing departments avoid mistakes like putting the wrong city background on an ad
column25: using images for which the department does not have rights or edit facial expressions without switching models.Sensei also will combine imaging and marketing functions so that clients can tweak campaigns on-the-fly

column1: 3 Growth Stocks You Should Avoid in 2017;12/15/2016;"Image source: Getty Images.There's no sugar-coating it: Growth stocks have been the   shining stars over value stocks since the Great Recession ended.   Although aBank of America/Merrill Lynch study found that value stocks have outperformed   growth stocks over the past 90 years with an average annual gain   of 17% versus 12.6%
column2: the low-interest-rate environment over the   past eight years has allowed growth stocks access to cheap and   bountiful capital to rapidly grow their business.But just because low interest rates favor growth stocks
column3: it   doesn't mean you can throw a dart and land a winner. Some growth   stocks are better off avoided in 2017. Here are three such growth   stocks that I'd suggest keeping you distance from next year.makeArticleAd();Tesla MotorsOne high-profile growth stock that I'd strongly suggest   investors leave parked on the sidelines in 2017 is electric   vehicle manufacturerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) .This isn't to say Tesla isn't without its positives. Tesla   obliterated Wall Street's earnings estimates in its third-quarter   report
column4: it wound up paying off about $600 million in debt
column5: and   its Model S sedan continues to gain market share. Perhaps most   importantly
column6: Tesla's production levels were a record of 25
column7: 185   vehicles
column8: a 92% year-over-year increase and a 37% improvement   from the sequential second quarter. Yet
column9: in spite of an expected   quadrupling in sales between 2015 and 2019
column10: I'd advocate keeping   your distance from Tesla because of three major risks.Tesla Model S. Image source: Tesla Motors.The first risk involves increasing competition. Just a few   years ago
column11: Tesla's Model S was the clear leader in mileage range   and luxury. However
column12: other automakers have made a commitment to   bringing more efficient EVs to market. We're seeing improved   mileage ranges between charges
column13: as well as more power and luxury   withBMW
column14: Porsche
column15: and Mercedes-Benz offering new concepts that could   reach the market before the end of the decade. While Tesla's   market share dominance is likely to continue in the near term
column16: it   could begin to be chipped away beyond 2017.Secondly
column17: I'd be concerned about Tesla's ramp-up in spending   which is likely to keep it as a cash-flow negative company for   years to come. No one said building a Gigafactory was going to   cheap
column18: or that expanding its annual production from 100
column19: 000   vehicles to 500
column20: 000 vehicles was going to go off without a hitch.   But Tesla has also racked up more than $3 billion in debt
column21: even   after paying off $600 million. Its debt-to-equity of 118% further   confirms the weight on the company's shoulders.Lastly
column22: the valuation remains something out of a horror film.   Tesla commands a $34 billion market cap despite only producing   about 100
column23: 000 vehicles a year and losing money. Conversely
column24: a   company likeGeneral Motors(NYSE: GM) produced 9.8 million vehicles in 2015 and made an   adjusted profit of more than $5 per share. Personally
column25: Tesla   looks like a no-brainer growth stock to avoid in 2017.BioMarin PharmaceuticalAnother growth stock that I don't believe has what it takes to   excel in 2017 is rare-disease drug developerBioMarin Pharmaceutical(NASDAQ: BMRN) .On the surface
column26: BioMarin has a lot to like for longer-term   investors. Its focus on rare-disease drugs means it'll face   minimal competition and that it'll probably have excellent   pricing power if its therapies are approved by the Food and Drug   Administration. BioMarin already has five rare-disease drugs   approved by at least one major regulatory agency around the   world
column27: and all of its therapies focus on ultra-rare diseases.   Between 2015 and 2019
column28: Wall Street is forecasting that BioMarin's   sales will essentially double from a reported $890 million to   approximately $1.8 billion.Image source: Getty Images.However
column29: there are also two drawbacks to BioMarin. To begin   with
column30: incoming president Donald Trump in his latest interview   withTimesuggested that he would lower drug prices in the United States
column31: which is a point he previously stated on the campaign trail.   Trump's only policy mention related to drug prices
column32: thus far
column33: was   outlined in his seven-point healthcare reform. Within his   proposal
column34: Trump opines that consumers should be able to look   overseas for their medicines
column35: since similar drugs in overseas   markets are typically priced lower than the U.S. It's unclear if   Trump's call for lower drug prices will have any traction in   Congress
column36: but rare disease drugmakers like BioMarin that have   drugs exceeding the $300
column37: 000 annual cost barrier are clearly on   Trump's radar.An even more immediate issue could be BioMarin's ongoing   losses. To some extent the company's steep full-year losses can   be forgiven since it's reinvesting back into its pipeline. Then   again
column38: waiting until 2019 to see a full-year profit doesn't seem   worthwhile for a company with a $14 billion market cap when you   can go out and open a position in a number of rare-disease   drugmakers that are already healthfully profitable
column39: such asAlexion PharmaceuticalsorShire.There appear to be far better options in biotech in 2017 than   BioMarin Pharmaceutical.FitbitFinally
column40: investors would probably be wise to step away from   fashionable growth storyFitbit(NYSE: FIT) as we head into 2017.Like the growth stocks above
column41: Fitbit does have positives that   can be taken away. For example
column42: Fitbit announced in its   third-quarter earnings report that new products accounted for an   amazing 79% of its quarterly revenue. Furthermore
column43: total revenue   increased 23% year over year
column44: 60% of its customers were new
column45: and   20% of its customers reactivated after being inactive for 90 or   more days. This would imply strong new traffic to the brand.Image source: Fitbit.But I'll also admit that I was wrong advocating that Fitbitcould be poised for a reboundback in October. Despite heavily reinvesting in its new products
column46: the launches of those product
column47: and marketing
column48: all Fitbit got out   of it was significantly lower margins and a reduced profit   forecast. There's no denying that revenue rose 23% in Q3 2016   from Q3 2015
column49: but just 11% of that was an increase in units sold.   The remainder was comprised of price increases on its products.   This would suggest that interest in Fitbit's products could be   ebbing
column50: even with a lot of extra money being spent on innovation   and marketing. The company's lowered fourth-quarter guidance   could imply a year-over-year decline in units sold
column51: with a higher   average selling price of those units leading to growth.Fitbit will also need to overcome the stigma of wearable   technology that it's nothing more than a fad. In other words
column52: can   Fitbit get customers to continually upgrade their device in the   same fashion that consumers upgrade their smartphones every year   or two? Based on the data released during the third quarter
column53: it   doesn't look as if Fitbit's products are resonating enough with   existing customers yet. That could change
column54: but I wouldn't look   for 2017 to be the year we see this ramp up in upgrades.Though Fitbit is on track to see its sales climb by more than   50% between 2015 and 2019
column55: I'd suggest keeping your distance from   this growth stock in 2017.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column21: '');Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column22: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column23: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column24: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column25: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column26: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs   experienced notable outflows »"

column1: U.S. Solar Record Installations: The Future is Getting Brighter For Clean Energy;12/15/2016;"According to a new report by GTM Research and the Solar Energy   Industries Association
column2: the third quarter of 2016 was a record   quarter for the U.S. solar industry. 4.14 GW of solar was   installed
column3: nearly as much as all of the solar installed in 2013   (4.76 GW). For all of 2016
column4: the researchers predict 14.1 GW of   solar will be installed
column5: enough to power 2.3 million homes.This is an interesting finding considering the challenges   solar stocks have faced this year.First Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column6: SunPower(NASDAQ: SPWR)
column7: Tesla(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column8: andVivint Solar(NYSE: VSLR) have all seen their stocks plunge for a variety of   reasons. And it's those details within the report that are worth   examining.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.The biggest solar segment by a long shot77% of all solar installed in the U.S. last quarter was   utility scale
column9: which has helped First Solar and SunPower as two   of the country's largest installers. But we knew late 2016 was   going to be good as developers completed projects contracted to   go online by the end of the year.Image source: GTM Research and Solar Energy Industries   AssociationQ4 2016 Solar Market Insight.An interesting takeaway from the report is that 2017 is   shaping up to be a little better than expected. Corporate   customers are buying energy from solar projects
column10: and a policy   known as PURPA that allows clean energy projects to be built if   they're lower cost than the avoided cost of fossil fuels is   driving adoption.The low cost of utility solar is starting to take hold
column11: and   over the next few years it's the cost advantage that will drive   greater adoption. For now
column12: it's good news that 2016's record year   may not be followed by a completely terrible 2017.Commercial solar is becoming a strengthOne major bright spot was commercial solar
column13: which was up 15%   sequentially and 37% from a year ago. This report includes   community solar in the commercial
column14: or non-residential
column15: segment
column16: so that helped the growth figures.What's worth pointing out is that commercial customers are   finding solar attractive to purchase and developers are figuring   out ways to finance projects. That's a new trend in 2016
column17: and as   costs come down and financing becomes available we could see a   boom in commercial projects in the same way we saw in residential   solar from 2010 to 2015.Residential solar is having a tough timeSpeaking of residential solar
column18: it's becoming harder and harder   to sell incremental rooftop solar systems
column19: a challenge that led   to a shrinking market in the third quarter. Installations were   down 10% sequentially and 2% from a year ago.There were strengths in new markets like Utah
column20: Texas
column21: and   South Carolina
column22: but big markets like California are actually in   decline. National installers like SolarCity and Vivint Solar are   also dealing with a ""quicker than expected"" customer shift from   leases and power purchase agreements to loans.Despite the decline in residential solar last quarter
column23: this   remains a segment with a lot of potential long-term. A relatively   small number of states -- including California
column24: Massachusetts
column25: and Arizona -- have long accounted for most rooftop solar demand
column26: and as more states open up the segment will grow. But it could be   a choppy transition
column27: particularly for companies without flexible   business models to adapt to customer preference.What we learned in Q3 2016Overall
column28: the solar industry is hitting record levels primarily   because of its cost competitiveness in a growing number of   states. And investors should take some comfort in the fact that   demand for utility projects in 2017 is growing and commercial   demand is picking up steam.With that said
column29: the next year or two will be challenging for   residential solar as well as utility demand in some states.   Investors will want to look at the industry cautiously

column1: Why Magna International May Soon Build a New Auto Factory;12/14/2016;"Auto-industry supplier and contract manufacturerMagna International(NYSE: MGA) may soon build a new auto factory
column2: a key executive   said this week.Magna's primary business is focused on making components for   the big global automakers. But it also manufactures complete   vehicles: The company's Magna Steyr unit runs an auto factory in   Austria that has made vehicles for several different automakers   over many decades.Apparently
column3: demand is growing for these services -- and that   has implications for all automakers
column4: as well as some companies   that might be looking to enter the auto industry.makeArticleAd();Mercedes-Benz G-Series SUVs roll down the production line at   Magna's contract auto factory in Graz
column5: Austria. Image source:   Magna International.What Magna saidThe head of Magna Steyr's European business
column6: Guenther   Apfalter
column7: told a German trade magazine this week that demand may   be strong enough to warrant construction of a factory near its   existing plant in Graz
column8: Austria.Right now
column9: the Graz plant builds Mercedes-Benz G-Class SUVs   forDaimler AG(NASDAQOTH: DDAIF) . It recently wrapped up production of the   Mini Countryman forBMW AG(NASDAQOTH: BAMXF)
column10: and will begin building BMW's 5 Series   starting next spring. Later in the year
column11: it's expected to begin   building the battery-electric Jaguar I-Pace SUV forTata Motors(NYSE: TTM) . Another yet-to-be-announced model from Jaguar Land   Rover is also headed to Graz
column12: possibly in 2018.Apparently
column13: there's demand for even more
column14: and one factory   might not be enough. In a German-languageinterviewwith Germany'sAutomobil Produktion
column15: Apfalter said that the Graz factory is likely to hit its   maximum production capacity by the end of 2018
column16: if not   before.""We are looking at potential locations in Europe
column17: North   America
column18: and China
column19: for a new factory
column20: Apfalter said. ""Should   Graz overflow
column21: a new plant nearby would be an option
column22: possibly   in Slovenia.He said a decision was likely sometime in the next few   months.Why this is important for the whole auto industryThere are huge contract manufacturers for many things (like   cellphones) in Asia. But auto manufacturing requires hugely   expensive specialized tooling
column23: some of which is specific to a   given model. There are no contract manufacturers for cars --   aside from Magna Steyr.For decades
column24: Magna Steyr has had a profitable business making   vehicles for the big automakers. Sometimes it's a small-volume   model like Mercedes' highly specialized G Series
column25: and sometimes   (as with the BMW 5 Series) Magna provides extra production   capacity to help meet strong demand. The Graz facility can build   internal-combustion
column26: hybrid
column27: and fully electric vehicles.With companies fromAppletoAlphabetto a host of start-ups contemplating various ways to enter the   auto business
column28: demand for contract auto manufacturing could   increase sharply in coming years.Magna's strong hint that it will add a second factory to its   contract-manufacturing operation suggests that it wants to   position itself as an option for those new industry entrants.   That could be very profitable for Magna -- and very helpful to   upstart would-be automakers.The upshot: Another area to watch as the auto industry   evolvesBuilding a new high-volume auto factory from scratch can be a   billion-dollar investment
column29: out of the range of many start-ups and   emerging companies.Tesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) has essentially bootstrapped its factory
column30: expanding from a small production line as its business (and   income) has grown. But that has been a slow process
column31: and other   potential market entrants might not be willing to wait.For companies that want a high-quality contract manufacturer   for vehicles
column32: Magna Steyr is (right now at least) the only game   in town. Its hints that it will soon invest the considerable sums   needed for a second factory suggest that it knows a lot of new   business is on the way. For those interested in the ongoing   transformation of the auto industry

column1: General Motors' Chevy Bolt Just Officially Beat Tesla Motors to Market;12/14/2016;"General Motors(NYSE: GM) said that it delivered its first three Chevrolet Bolt   EVs to paying customers on Tuesday
column2: fulfilling a promise made by   CEO Mary Barra that sales of the innovative electric car would   begin by the end of 2016.What GM said about the first Chevy Bolt salesGM said that the first Bolts to be sold at retail were   delivered to three customers at Fremont Chevrolet in Fremont
column3: California. All three customers had previously owned hybrid or   electric vehicles.makeArticleAd();Bobby Edmonds
column4: William ""Bill"" Mattos
column5: and Steve Henry became   the first three customers to take delivery of new Chevrolet Bolt   EVs in Fremont
column6: California
column7: on Tuesday. Image source: General   Motors.One customer
column8: who purchased a Bolt to replace aBMWi3
column9: said that he was attracted to the electric Chevy by its range   and technology
column10: and by the fact that GM is an American   company.GM executives were understandably pleased. ""All of the hard   work that the Chevrolet team have put into designing
column11: engineering   and building the Bolt EV brings us to this truly satisfying   moment of making the first deliveries to customers on time
column12: as   planned
column13: said Alan Batey
column14: president of GM North America and   Chevrolet brand chief. ""Chevrolet is proud to offer a vehicle   like the Bolt EV
column15: with ground-breaking technology wrapped in a   modern design that is also fun to drive at an affordable   price.""For now
column16: GM is building and shipping only a small number of   Chevy BoltsGM is rolling its little electric crossover out slowly
column17: currently building about 100 Bolts a day
column18: according to an   Automotive News report.GM's factory in Orion
column19: Michigan is reportedly building about   100 Bolts a day. It has the capacity to ramp up significantly if   demand is strong. Image source: General Motors.Shipments are ramping up
column20: too. GM said that more Bolts are   currently in transit to dealers in California and Oregon
column21: set to   arrive before the end of December. Dealers in a few other   markets
column22: including New York
column23: Massachusetts
column24: and Virginia
column25: will   receive their first Bolts sometime this winter.More will be rolled out in the spring
column26: and GM expects the Bolt   to be available at ""Bolt EV-certified"" Chevy dealers nationwide   by about the middle of 2017.GM has a window of opportunity to poach buyers from   TeslaThe Bolt's price tag ($37
column27: 495 before a $7
column28: 500 federal tax   credit) and range (EPA-estimated at 238 miles) have made it an   appealing alternative to a high-pricedTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA) Model S or Model X
column29: at least on paper -- and put   it a big step ahead of mass-market-priced electric vehicles from   other automakers.But the Bolt -- by design -- is very different from the   high-performing and sleekly styled Teslas. The Teslas were   designed to compete head-to-head with German luxury cars
column30: but the   Bolt was created with ride-hailing and car-sharing duties in   mind: It's essentially a 21st century taxicab.The Bolt is a fine choice for someone who wants an electric   commuter car with good acceleration and a roomy back seat
column31: but   nobody will call it sexy like a Model S.That would put the Bolt at a disadvantage (at retail
column32: at   least) if Tesla had a car in the Bolt's price range. That car
column33: the Tesla Model 3
column34: is in development. Tesla hopes to have it in   production by the end of 2017
column35: though many analysts think mid- to   late 2018 is more realistic. Either way
column36: that gives GM a window   of opportunity.The Bolt isn't a Tesla -- but unlike Tesla's upcoming   ""affordable"" Model 3
column37: it's available now. That gives GM a chance   to poach some buyers from the Silicon Valley automaker.One last thought: The location of the first Bolt EV sales was   no accidentBy the way
column38: I don't think it was a coincidence that the first   Bolts were delivered in Fremont
column39: California. Tesla's factory is   in Fremont
column40: and I think GM enjoys giving its electric rival a   poke in the eye. After all
column41: GM did beat Tesla to market with an   affordable long-range electric car.Don't get too offended
column42: Tesla fans: GM has done this kind of   thing with its crosstown Detroit rivals (and vice-versa) for   decades. Extending it to Tesla is arguably a mark of respect.10 stocks we like better than General MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Is Uber Missing the Mark In This Key Area?;12/14/2016;"After deploying some of its ""self-driving"" Uber vehicles in   Pittsburgh in September
column2: the company is now deploying about five   autonomous Volvo XC90 SUVs in San Francisco
column3: Uber announced on   Wednesday. Uber's aggressiveness in testing autonomous technology   highlights the company's vision for a self-driving ride-hailing   service.Uber's self-driving Volvo. Image source: Uber.makeArticleAd();""The promise of self-driving is core to our mission of   reliable transportation
column4: everywhere for everyone
column5: Uber   emphasized in a blog post on Wednesday. ""As demand for   ridesharing continues to skyrocket
column6: the future of transportation   will be a mix of human drivers and self-driving cars.""But there are a couple catches to Uber's new ""self-driving""   cars in San Francisco.Are these vehicles really autonomous?""San Francisco
column7: your Self-Driving Uber is arriving now
column8: reads   an Uber's Wednesday morning blog post. This bold statement
column9: however
column10: isn't quite accurate.Later in the same post Uber says
column11: ""For us
column12: it's still early   days and our cars are not yet ready to drive without a person   monitoring them."" Like Uber's vehicles deployed in Pittsburgh
column13: these new ""self-driving"" vehicles require a driver to sit up   front to ensure the ride goes normally. If something goes wrong
column14: these operators need to take over the wheel.Furthermore
column15: there's a debate about whether Uber even has   permission to operate vehicles like this in San Francisco. The   state of California requires companies testing self-driving   vehicles to obtain a permit to test these vehicles
column16: and Uber   doesn't have one.Going into Uber's launch of its five self-driving vehicles in   San Francisco on Wednesday
column17: the ride-hailing company is aware of   the controversy. Uber acknowledged the issue in its blog post:   ""Finally
column18: we understand that there is a debate over whether or   not we need a testing permit to launch self-driving Ubers in San   Francisco. We have looked at this issue carefully and we don't   believe we do.""California rules don't apply to their situation since the   permit is intended for cars that drive without someone   controlling or monitoring them
column19: according to Uber.But the California DMV disagrees
column20: reportsThe Wall Street Journalon Wednesday. ""Twenty manufacturers have already obtained   permits to test hundreds of cars on California roads. Uber shall   do the same
column21: said the DMV.Permit or not
column22: Uber is clearly adamant about pushing the   envelope when it comes to deploying and testing autonomous   technologyTesla's advantage over UberInterestingly
column23: Uber's questionable strategy for testing   autonomous driving technology in Pittsburgh and San Francisco   highlights a major advantage electric-car makerTesla Motors(NASDAQ: TSLA)
column24: which alsoplans to launch its own self-driving ride-hailing   service
column25: has over Uber.Tesla demonstrated a self-driving Model S. Image source: Tesla   Motors.By beginning toinclude sensors for autonomous driving in every   vehiclein October
column26: Tesla is able to operate its vehicles' new   sensors in ""shadow mode
column27: collecting data from every new   vehicle's driving and determining how systems would have   performed in different situations. Not only will this shadow mode   data help Tesla refine its self-driving software before it is   released
column28: but it will also help serve as a benchmark for   regulators to illustrate how the technology can increase safety
column29: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said.Therefore
column30: while Uber's San Francisco launch highlights a   debate about regulatory challenges with testing self-driving   technology
column31: the more notable takeaway may be the weakness in   Uber's overall approach. Uber's small number of vehicles for   testing autonomous driving technology in Pittsburgh and San   Francisco pales in comparison to Tesla's current production rate   of 100
column32: 000 vehicles annually. Tesla's biggest advantage over Uber   in preparing to launch an autonomous ride-hailing service may be   its ability to generate far more data from self-driving   sensors.10 stocks we like better than Tesla MotorsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
